PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.
Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to offences against the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to Senator Messner in his capacity, I think, as Minister representing the Attorney-General, or is it Senator Chaney? There seems to be some misunderstanding on the front bench about who will take this catch. The other day I raised a question about whether the Federal law authorities would confer with the States, particularly New South Wales, in regard to the activities of the purveyors of racial hatred, that is, the National Front and particularly 'the Skull' and his friends in Sydney. I just wonder whether anything has happened since I raised this question in the Senate.

—I am not the Acting Attorney-General in the absence of the Attorney-General but rather I am representing the Acting Attorney-General, the Honourable Neil Brown, in the Senate. So, whilst I am sure that the Honourable Neil Brown would have an immediate and precise answer to that question, I am afraid I do not. I do recall the matter which was raised with very great enthusiasm by the honourable senator, who expressed very deep concern about some of the activities which have been occurring in Australia. He took a view which, I think, perhaps went rather beyond the traditional view of what is the role of government and the law enforcement authorities with respect to the treatment of various opinions in the community, some of which of course are repugnant to the great mass of the Australian community. So I must say that my view on the matters which were raised by the honourable senator is that, whilst I share his repugnance about them, some of the measures which he had in mind may go beyond what we would want to do in a democratic society. In any event, the matter the honourable senator has raised is very serious. I will ask the Acting Attorney-General whether he can advise me on any action that has been taken since the question was asked. But I think all honourable senators would be aware that where action with the States is required it is not possible to have an instantaneous reaction. I would also just draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the Human Rights Commission may well be a body which might have some interest in the area raised by the honourable senator.

—I direct my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Having recently visited the Burdekin Dam site in north Queensland and being aware of the concern about, and in some instances criticism of, the lack of co-operation from the Commonwealth for the project. I ask: Will the Minister advise what commitment has been made by the Commonwealth Government and the arrangements with the Queensland Government for the continuing development of this important Burdekin project?

—Let me say, with all the emphasis I can command, that there is absolutely no ground for any criticism at all of the Commonwealth's role in this matter. The Commonwealth reached agreement with the Queensland Government in August of last year on the building of the Burdekin Dam and its associated works. The Commonwealth has agreed to provide all the funds for the construction of the dam. The cost is estimated at approximately $85m in 1980 terms. The Queensland Government is to provide the infrastructure and preliminary work necessary for the construction of the dam; for example, the access roads. That is estimated to cost around $15m in mid-1980 terms. Construction of the dam will commence when preliminary works which are being carried out by the Queensland Government have reached the necessary stage. I understand this will be some time in 1982-83. The situation is quite clear. The Commonwealth has reached an agreement. It is emphatically sticking to that agreement. The job at the moment is for the Queensland Government to get the preliminary works into position, and the Commonwealth Government will then take the next step in 1982-83, with the construction of the dam.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Following his exhaustive fact-finding tour of the United States to determine the effects of herbicides on the Vietnam veterans, has the Minister received, since his return, a letter from the Vietnam Veterans in Congress group which stated its disappointment that the Minister had made no effort to see the group which is vitally concerned with this matter? I ask: Whom did the Minister consult in the United States so that he was able to say emphatically that he had searched high and low for information but apparently was not able to find any?

—I think a couple of months ago I had a question from Senator Keeffe in connection with the letter that I had received from the Vietnam Veterans in Congress group. I have since tabled my reply to that letter which I think the honourable senator will find in Hansard if he cares to look it up. In very short terms, let me say that I did not see that particular group in any special consultation. Its representatives, along with those of other veterans organisations, were invited to an evening function which was sponsored by the Embassy in Washington. I would have had the opportunity of meeting them there. However, the representatives of that organisation did not attend that function. I guess we could spend the rest of Question Time talking about the broader question of whom I consulted, but it might suit the purposes of Senator Elstob if I were to provide him with a copy of my itinerary.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Considering the wide-ranging problems being experienced by mining companies and the mining industry in the Northern Territory, can the Minister advise the effect that reductions in mining and non-delivery of uranium shipments are likely to have on royalty payments to Aboriginal organisations? Can the Minister also advise whether it is correct that members of the Northern Land Council have said that because of the confrontation on Darwin wharf there is now no urgency or necessity to continue with the Jabiluka and Koongarra negotiations because it is futile to endeavour to dispose of the uranium?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator asks two questions. Any diminution in activity at Gove will result in diminished royalties from that operation. To that extent, there will be diminished income coming into the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account and to Aboriginal communities. If the reduction in activity at Gove is as has been suggested in the Press, the extent of the diminished royalties could be quite significant. As other uranium mining projects come on stream-for example, Ranger and the others-there will be extra royalties. The net effect of this upon Aboriginal communities is hard to judge at this stage.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of the honourable senator's question relates to some assertions as to what the Northern Land Council may have said about the question of negotiations. There has been no indication to me from the Northern Land Council which in any way confirms the story referred to by Senator Kilgariff in his question. I have had no indications that the Northern Land Council is not continuing with the negotiating process. As far as I know, the negotiating team from the Northern Land Council and the team from Pancontinental Mining Ltd continue to work on an agreement and continue to negotiate. I would be very surprised if they were prepared to stop negotiations on the basis of some extraneous factors which may or may not be in operation at the time when their agreement eventually is concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Did the Government take into account the repressive nature of the military dictatorship in Pakistan before approval was given for a Pakistani cricket team to tour Australia this summer? Does the presence of the Pakistani cricket team in Australia indicate that the Commonwealth Government condones the Pakistani dictatorship's complete removal of civil liberties, the contrived execution of a former Prime Minister and the continued persecution of the Bhutto family?

—I think this question would more appropriately have been directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Of course, the Government does not condone any of the matters, alleged and proven, to which Senator Colston has referred. In many cases the Government finds itself in situations, such as that of the Russian Olympic Games, where for example our sportsmen act alongside people of that country and many other countries in which there is very great tyranny and oppression. Sadly enough, we cannot overcome such conditions throughout the entire world. I will bring the question to the Foreign Minister's attention and, if there is anything to be added, he can comment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's statement relating to the decision of the Australian Government on a conditional commitment of Australians to the international peace monitoring force in the Sinai. In particular I ask about the maximum period for Australian involvement. There has been speculation that this maximum period would be one year or, at most, two years. I ask: When will this matter be decided? Secondly, I ask about both Canada and the United Kingdom committing themselves to involvement being a prior condition for Australia's involvement. When is it expected that these countries may resolve the question of their involvement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take the second part of the question first. Throughout the Australian community, there appears to be a general acceptance of the desirability of having a peace force in the Sinai. There are those-including this Government-who hold the view that it would be, of course, infinitely preferable if that force could be a United Nations peace force. But, in the knowledge of the Russian veto, that cannot be; and, therefore, the great bulk of people who have accepted the view that there ought to be a peace force believe that, in the absence of a United Nations peace force, there should be the most widely balanced peace force possible.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's view was that that should be the goal to be achieved. Specifically, the Government was keen that there should be a major European commitment and that that commitment preferably should be based around the United Kingdom and supported, in the wider sense, by Canada. The interesting situation, although not fully confirmed, is that it looks as though there is a likelihood of a peace force on an even broader base than had previously been thought. It looks very likely that France, under its new socialist President, will commit itself. I believe there is evidence that Italy will. I believe there is evidence that the Netherlands will. There is a strong likelihood of the United Kingdom committing itself. I cannot speak about Canada, but the participation of Canada in itself, whilst desirable, would not be imperative if the base were as broad as now seems to be emerging. Indeed, one would have noted a significant comment from, I think, a Syrian diplomat, namely, that there would be merit in such a peace force. So there is a strengthening view in many facets of the world that this peace force should take shape and take part.

Secondly, I do not think-I would need to refresh my recollection-that any fixed time limit has been set in the matter. If I recollect correctly, there was some thought that the withdrawal by the Israelis might be by something like April of next year, but I take it that the peace force would be there for such length of time as was necessary and no longer. If there is anything further to add to the answer I will ascertain it for Senator Teague.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology whether his attention has been drawn to the recent advice from Sir Geoffrey Badger, the Chairman of the Australian Science and Technology Council, that Australia must respond quickly to new technology. In view of the Government's current attacks on research in universities, particularly in the area of new technology, can the Minister explain why the Government is ignoring Sir Geoffrey's learned and valuable advice?

—I have not seen any recent statement by Sir Geoffrey Badger but I am aware of the quite major contributions that he makes to public comment in Australia about science policy generally and the very important role that he plays through ASTEC and other bodies. It is quite incorrect to assert that this Government does not support university research. Unlike most other countries, in Australia the Government is the major supporter of research. More than 70 per cent of all research carried out in Australia is supported directly by government, either through the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the Australian Research Grants Committee and the National Health and Medical Research Council or through a variety of other bodies. The record of this Government is one of continuing and substantial support for research and I reject completely the quite unwarranted assertions in the honourable senator's question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. At a time when Australia's role in the Pacific is increasing, I draw the attention of the Minister to the notification of the intended closure of the Consul-General's office in Lae and ask whether this is not a retrograde step. In view of the strategic importance of, and the high level of assistance given to, our nearest neighbour, Papua New Guinea, will the Government reconsider, possibly in the future, its decision to close that office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will draw the attention of the Foreign Minister to Senator Watson's request with regard to the Consulate in Lae and ascertain from him whether there is any reason for him to reconsider the proposed closure, as requested. If there is a response from the Minister I will see that Senator Watson is advised.

—I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs whether it is a fact that the HMAS Bataan transported Britain's Lord Fraser, of the Royal Navy, to board the USS Missouri in Tokyo Bay on 2 September 1945 for the signing of the surrender. If so, how does this tally with the Minister's agreement with an honourable senator in this place that the HMAS Bataan and three other Australian warships-Shropshire, Hobart and Warramunga-arrived in Tokyo after the signing of the surrender? Is the Minister aware that the servicemen from these warships, while on shore leave during this period, visited Nagasaki and photographed the devastation? Can the Minister discover from the records the name and location of the submarine base south of Tokyo that the Bataan visited within three weeks of arriving in Tokyo and reassure the Senate that these sailors were not exposed to serious radiation levels during this voyage?
—The question contains a number of very detailed matters that demand investigation, so I ask Senator Jones to put his question on notice.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations read the report in this morning's Age regarding the possibility of another national ports stoppage? Can the Government offer any hope of averting that and other such stoppages which, in particular, are rapidly strangling increasing numbers of Tasmanian primary and secondary industries? Will the Government undertake to assist wherever practicable in heading off strikes such as the one now looming?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the report in the Age, although I was advised that there was a report on that subject on the front page of that newspaper this morning. I have some information with respect to the matter which I received from the office of the Minister for Industrial Relations. I was advised yesterday that, in the dispute which has been going on for some little time over a claim for an increase of $40.20 a week-that claim was put forward on 30 September 1981-the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia and the employers have broken off negotiations and there is a likelihood of industrial action. At a meeting yesterday the employers advised the Waterside Workers Federation of their reaction to the $40.20 a week wage claim. They indicated that that part of the claim based on undistributed increases in national productivity should be processed through the Australian Council of Trade Unions with national employers and before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. They put the view that that was the appropriate avenue through which the claim should be progressed.

ANSWER.PARA: There was also a claim for $25.30 aimed at bringing classifications into line with rates in industry generally. The employers agreed to have further discussions and to join in proceedings before the Commission on that, but they were not prepared to make any offer. The Federation has pressed for an offer to be made and for a negotiated settlement to be secured before any approach is made to the Commission. That was rejected by the employers. As I understand it, a report is to be presented to stop work meetings of the Federation. The first of those meetings is to be held in Sydney today. It is quite likely that there could be industrial action following those meetings. Obviously, the Government will do what it can to assist in the resolution of that dispute. Again, this is a situation in which, if the trade union movement is not prepared to use the processes which are available to it in order to test claims of the sort presently being put forward, but insists on taking strike action, there is a limit to what the Government can do to bring about a settlement of the dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that one-year life insurance bonds are still alive and well as a significant form of tax avoidance in the community, not only in the guise of the original-I hope now notorious-Eagle bonds issued by the Australian Eagle Insurance Co. Ltd, but also in the form of, purportedly, insurance bonds issued by a number of other insurance companies, friendly societies and building societies these days? The companies involved include Mercantile Mutual Life Insurance Co. Ltd and most recently the Manchester Unity organisation, with its so-called tax-free bonus bonds. Why has no progress apparently been made on this whole matter, since Senator Durack told me on 27 November last year that the matter was under review by the Treasurer? Why, again, has no progress been made since the Minister herself told me on 8 September-now seven weeks ago-that the Treasurer would give me as soon as possible an up to date report on exactly what was proposed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have not received a report from the Treasurer on this matter, but I will refer it to him again and seek an early response from him on the matters raised by Senator Evans. I am not aware of what action the Treasurer has been able to take or what progress he has been able to make, but I will see that an early response is given.

—I preface my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health by stating that under the present health care system the specialist role that the psychologist plays in assisting people to overcome the minor and major life crises that beset some people in this rather stressful world in which we live is given no formal recognition and, in fact, that the current arrangements within the health care system make it virtually impossible for many people to avail themselves of the help which psychologists can offer. Can the Minister advise whether, in fact, any arrangements are being made by the Department of Health to recognise the valuable contribution that psychologists can and do make within the health care system in Australia? When is it proposed to include claims for refunds or benefits for such services within the health insurance arrangements?

—A few years ago optometrists' services were included in the payment of rebates. That was a major breakthrough in the provision of benefits for medical services as it was the first time that the availability of benefits had been extended beyond the medical and dental professions. As the honourable senator will be aware, rebates are available for medical services, for some dental services and for optometrical services. The extension of rebates to the other valuable therapies-occupational therapy, physiotherapy, social work services or clinical psychology-would represent a major policy decision and would have great budgetary implications. These decisions would have to be taken by government within that kind of context, having regard to all the benefits that people might gain and all the costs that would be incurred. It is the kind of matter which government takes under view from time to time. At present it has not been possible to extend the benefits to clinical psychologists, physiotherapists or the other therapies which might be involved. It is a matter which I will refer to the Minister for Health. I know that it is the kind of matter which continues to attract his attention and which he continues to examine at frequent intervals.

—I preface my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs by reminding him that on 17 September I raised in the adjournment debate the matter of a mail van being burnt south of Meningie. The answer I received from Senator Baume was that the van was carrying mail and some 96 bags of mail were destroyed. Why is it that the Minister's Department took up to three weeks to honour cheques which were payable by it to recipients of repatriation benefits in the Mount Gambier area, when the social security cheques which come under the jurisdiction of Senator Chaney were able to be paid almost immediately to people who went to the Department of Social Security and said that they had not received their cheques? People who were expecting their repatriation benefit cheques had to wait up to three weeks. What was the reason for the inordinate delay in making payment to these people and causing them some undue suffering?

—This is the first time it has been drawn to my attention that there was any problem arising from the mail van accident near Meningie. It had not been drawn to my attention before that there had been any delays in processing replacement cheques for repatriation beneficiaries. I will certainly inquire into the matter and find out the reasons. I hope that they will be satisfactory in relation to Senator McLaren's question.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED CANBERRA CASINO AND CONVENTION CENTRE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory. I refer to the proposals to establish a casino in Canberra. Is it being argued that Canberra needs a convention centre and that the only way such a structure could be built would be to associate it with a casino? What consideration has been given to the use of the present Parliament House building after 1988? Would it not be an admirable convention centre and one we could have without getting a possibly unwanted casino at the same time?

—I understand that there has been no detailed consideration of the use of this Parliament House building after 1988. However, the preliminary studies by the National Capital Development Commission indicate that it would be difficult and extremely costly to refurbish the building for the kind of purpose Senator Hamer has in mind. With regard to whether it is realistic to expect that a convention centre could be built and operative before 1988 if a decision were to be made soon, I think the Minister does regard it as realistic that such a decision could be taken and that such a convention centre could be erected.

—Mr President, my question is directed to you. With regard to the statement by the Leader of the Government in the Senate-I refer to Hansard of 27 October 1981, page 1649-that what is done in respect of the cut in the Parliamentary Library's funds is a matter for the Presiding Officers and the Joint House Department to determine, can he state for how long it has been the policy for the Joint House Department to determine internal matters of the Parliamentary Library or any other parliamentary department, and is this policy a result of recommendations in the report of Urwick International Pty Ltd? Are discussions currently proceeding for the amalgamation of the departments of the Library, Hansard and Joint House and, if so, can you supply us with details of these?
—I will give consideration to all the points that the honourable senator has raised in his question and respond accordingly.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. I preface it by expressing concern at the lack of Government help given to those who show initiative in seeking work opportunities by their own efforts. Will the Minister therefore give consideration to paying relocation assistance to those unemployed people who show initiative by moving interstate to obtain employment without having prior registration with the Commonwealth Employment Service? Will subsequent registration be possible to enable relocation assistance to be obtained?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will need to refer that question to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs to see whether further assistance could be given to those who, on their own account, seek employment opportunities and whether any amendment of existing legislation would be required to enable this to be done. As I understand it, the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs has a number of programs for the assistance of those seeking employment opportunities and it may be that some further assistance can be comprehended within the procedures at present. If this is found to be of assistance and if Senator Watson wishes to have discussions with the Minister about it or to make further representations through me, I will see that the matter is given early consideration.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALES TAX ON RECORD PRODUCED BY DEBNEY PARK HIGH SCHOOL

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It is a somewhat parochial question for Victorian senators. I refer the Minister to the fact that Debney Park High School is seeking to raise some $30,000 to $40,000 for a music scholarship fund, which is to be raised by selling a record featuring the Debney Park High School band, about which I think the Minister knows. I refer to the fact that almost all those involved in the project have given their services freely but, despite representations, the Treasurer has refused to exempt the record from sales tax, which amounts to 37c for each $2 record. I ask: Will the Minister take up this matter with the Treasurer again and make further representations to him about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is a fact that there is a provision in the sales tax law that exempts goods for use and not for sale by a university or school not conducted for the profit of an individual. However, that exemption does not extend to goods produced for sale by a school and there is no other relevant exemption in the law. The Commissioner of Taxation does not have a discretion in these matters. To do what has been suggested by Senator Button would require a change in the income tax law so that the record concerned could be exempt from tax. The record will be sold in the market-place and it will be in competition with other records. It could be felt that there would be some inequity in giving an exemption to this particular record.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I recognise the validity of what has been put forward by Senator Button on behalf of those at the school who have this very worthy object in mind. I will refer that matter again to the Treasurer to see whether he can give any assistance in this particular instance. I think that we would all support what has been done by those associated with this project. As I say, there is no discretion under the present law and an amendment to the law would be required if some beneficial assistance were to be given.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Education been drawn to the recent report of research carried out by Dr Graham Dettrick of the Gippsland Institute on the lack of mathematical attainment of primary school teachers? Is he aware that Dr Dettrick's test showed that only 39 per cent of primary students tested lay in the same ability band as 69 per cent of their teachers, which roughly means that four out of 10 pupils have the same mastery of mathematics as seven out of 10 of their teachers? Did the Minister see Dr Dettrick's conclusions that a substantial proportion of teachers urgently require the support of in-service education in primary mathematics; that the pupil group most disadvantaged by lack of teacher competence is the above average group; that teachers are often using inappropriate cognitive strategies, which in my terms means that they do not know how to teach mathematics; that women teachers particularly require support and encouragement to continue mathematics; and that there are no significant differences in mathematical competency between one, two and three-year trained primary teachers? Does the Minister agree with Dr Dettrick that teacher performances are largely the product of past community actions and beliefs about what is good, necessary, sufficient and affordable in mathematics education? Is it therefore not more important to give greater gravity to assessing the present situation and to plan strategies for improving the quality, particularly of mathematics, in education?

—Contrary to the interjections of members of the Australian Labor Party, the question of the standards reached by students, particularly the help given to above average students, and the training given to teachers is of great importance, so I direct myself to it. I am aware of Dr Bremer's article in, I think, the Australian newspaper, which I understand was related to the interim report on a mathematics in-service guidelines study prepared by Dr Dettrick. The essential recommendation arising out of the report is that there is an urgent need for widespread and systematic support for teachers in the area of primary mathematics and, as an adjunct to that recommendation, that there is reason to believe that subject-based in-service education could be of considerable value to some teachers. That is very important. Whilst I have not examined the report in detail, it is clear that the thrust of its recommendations is compatible with the findings of several recent Commonwealth inquiries in the area of education. The report of the national inquiry into teacher education made the point that 74 per cent of primary school teachers in Victoria had a background in the humanities rather than in sciences. It suggested that at the pre-service level teacher education institutions have the responsibility of ensuring that their graduates are properly equipped to carry out effectively their professional duties and that the responsibility for continuing professional development rests ultimately with the teachers themselves. The States, which are primarily responsible for the provision and administration of educational services, should ensure that adequate opportunity exists for teachers to make a choice. The Commonwealth is maintaining its support of in-service teacher education and will provide some $17.5m to the States for this purpose in 1982. I commend Senator Archer for drawing the question to the attention of the Senate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. On Tuesday the Minister was asked by Senator McLaren for a guarantee that neither the Prime Minister nor his wife and family or any of the other Cabinet Ministers with extensive farming interests were holding income equalisation deposits and therefore benefiting from their own decision to lift effective interest rates to 23.75 per cent. In reply, the Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: Senator McLaren may be sure that the Prime Minister, in his supervision of the disclosure provisions in respect of his Ministers, and the Ministers themselves will observe impecably the rules regarding self-interest or pecuniary interest.

Since not everyone will agree with the Prime Minister's undefined notion and unstated rules of what is or is not acceptable self or pecuniary interest, will Senator Carrick get a prime ministerial guarantee that Ministers and other people concerned are not holding IEDs and, in particular, that the Prime Minister's wife's family, which received government money at 4 1/2 per cent, is not lending it back to the Government at an effective interest rate of 23.75 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of the impact of decisions made by Cabinets and governments, both on Cabinet Ministers and on the community at large, was dealt with at length by the Bowen Committee of Inquiry Concerning Public Duty and Private Interest. For example, it pointed out that decisions would be made from time to time in which groups of members of parliament would benefit, as would the whole community. Where a piece of legislation is of general benefit, quite clearly an individual member of parliament, as a member of the community, would be capable of benefit. I think I construe the Bowen Committee report in that way. For example, a farmer-there are some amongst us, even on the other side- gets the benefit of superphosphate and nitrogen subsidies.

ANSWER.PARA: People can hold Commonwealth bonds. Indeed, the day to day decisions of the Cabinet on interest rates affect the interest rates on Commonwealth bonds. In that sense it is not any different to IEDs. Basically, it is necessary to see whether what Senator Walsh asks in the substance of his question infringes the principles of the Bowen Committee report. I will invite a study of that matter and then I will draw the report, in general terms, to the attention of the Prime Minister. Cabinet has accepted the Bowen Committee standards regarding pecuniary interests. General disclosures are made to the Prime Minister. The interests of individual Ministers, as to their professions or investments, are known and the decisions are so made. In due course the provisions will be extended to this chamber so that all honourable senators, including those opposite me, can disclose whether they might be getting beneficial help from IEDs and the particular interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask Senator Carrick a supplementary question. Is it a fact that income equalisation deposits are held by about only 5,000 people? Does he define a benefit exploited by 5,000 people as 'a general benefit'? Is he refusing to ask the Prime Minister for a guarantee that none of the people named in my question holds these income equalisation deposits?

—I do not know whether only 5,000 people hold IEDs. I imagine that 50,000 or 100,000 people could if they so chose. If that is so, and if my recollection is right, I understand that the Bowen Committee report says that this would be a benefit on a wide scale. Lest what I am saying is not a primary conclusion of the Bowen Committee report, I will invite a study of it. I will also direct the other aspects of the question to the Prime Minister. I am not refusing to do anything. I am simply saying that we set up a committee on pecuniary interests. We applied the recommendations of that Committee to the Ministry and we will apply them to the rest of the Parliament. I have also always said that those who seek disclosure in others should be first of all frank themselves in getting up to disclose their own interest.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer the Minister to an article in today's Australian Financial Review entitled 'Aussat offer to PNG could endanger Outback TV'. Aussat is the Australian communications satellite. The article goes on to state that there is a limited number of high powered channels in HACBSS-the Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite System-and that one of these channels may be offered to and accepted by the Government of Papua New Guinea for a national television service with the consequential effect that one of the channels dedicated to outback services will disappear. Why is the assumption always automatically made that the outback is expendable? Why cannot Sydney or Melbourne with their surfeit of existing radio and television channels hold back until those Australians in less populated areas have a basic service?

—I am not certain that the assertions in the newspaper article which gave rise to Senator MacGibbon's concern are in fact correct. If the assertions are not factual, then the consequential worry may not be necessary. My understanding is that the design of the satellite had made provision for some domestic communication services for Papua New Guinea. That has been the idea from the beginning. The Papua New Guinea Government has still to decide whether it wishes to exercise that option. I understand that the option did include provision for switching one of the 30 watt transponders into the Papua New Guinea beam if that Government wanted to introduce domestic broadcasting services by satellite some time in the future. As that has been one of the design options from the beginning, it is appropriate that that offer should be made to Papua New Guinea. The reason for the higher powered transponder is similar to the reason which led to the inclusion of several of those high powered transponders. If I remember correctly a question asked by Senator Button, there were three others in the original satellite design. I will check with the Minister for Communications whom I represent as to whether there are any other features which would lend any credence to a particular vulnerability for the people of the outback. I will certainly convey Senator MacGibbon's well known concern for the people living in non-metropolitan Australia and seek to get any further information I can from the Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is the Minister aware that if the Australian Gallery Directors Council goes into liquidation, numerous exhibitions currently touring Australia will be left stranded-for example, the Aboriginal Australia exhibition for which a world tour had been planned? Is he aware that up to 50 exhibitions scheduled to tour Australia will be cancelled and that the major victims of these cancellations will be regional galleries? What is the Government prepared to do to prevent the liquidation of the Australian Gallery Directors Council?

—I am not aware that the Australian Gallery Directors Council is about to go into liquidation. I will certainly seek some information on that. I seem to recall that one of the exhibitions at least-the Aboriginal art exhibition-was privately underwritten. If I am correct, American Express was involved in underwriting that exhibition. I understand the honourable senator's expression of concern. I will seek to find out the facts in relation to the status of the tours and the exhibitions by the Council. I agree with the honourable senator that we would certainly want the Australian people to have maximum access to these exhibitions and particularly, from my own portfolio interest, the very fine exhibition of Aboriginal Australia which is on tour.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. It has been brought to my notice that procedures to react to the dumping of manufactured goods in Australia are so complicated that nine months or even 12 months can elapse between when a complaint is received and when action can be taken. This must be of considerable concern to some local manufacturers. Will the Government investigate ways of streamlining procedures even to the extent, which I believe to be possible, of establishing a system which can stop goods entering this country even if there is a chance at all of their contravening anti-dumping laws?

—I am not particularly aware of all the details of the anti-dumping procedures. However, I am aware that there are different rules and different systems applying in particular industries. For instance, in the steel industry there does exist an anti-dumping evaluation committee which has power to act very quickly in these circumstances. As to the general range of commodities that would need to be covered and is covered in Senator Thomas's question, I would need to refer that to the Minister to obtain for him an early reply.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction to the desperate situation of the building industry in Tasmania and the urgent need for what Commonwealth construction work there is there to get under way, in particular, the new Federal law courts building in Hobart. I ask: Is it a fact that the letting of tenders for this project is held up because the Government's conditions will not allow any site allowance which may be granted by the Arbitration and Conciliation Commission to be part of the rise and fall conditions of the contracts? Is it also a fact that none of the tenders is in accordance with that condition? Will the Government change its mind about this condition and not try to usurp any decisions of the Arbitration Commission which may grant site allowances in accordance with the law? Will the Minister also acknowledge that it is crazy economics to hold up projects for that reason while costs are rising every day?

—Because of the detailed nature of numerous matters in the question concerning the form of tenders, agreements and contracts, I think I need to refer the question to the Minister for Housing and Construction to obtain a reply for the honourable senator.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister answer the question in general terms about the Government's attitude to decisions by the Arbitration Commission on site allowances and indicate whether that ought to be included in the conditions of such jobs, especially as I understand that a couple of jobs in the Australian Capital Territory are similarly affected?
—I believe this really is an appropriate question for the Minister for Industrial Relations. I will undertake to refer the matter to him.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Did the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission recommend that the ABC cut its commitment to its orchestras, whose administration should be taken over by a new body to be called Music Australia? Would this Dix proposal involve the setting up of a new Commonwealth statutory authority? Would the individual orchestras, under the Dix Committee's recommendations, be run by instrumentalities, possibly six more new statutory authorities, of the various State governments? What was the expertise available on the Dix Committee to make such radical recommendations affecting the future of music in this country? Is it true that the Committee was reluctant to undertake this part of the investigation? Will the Minister, before he makes a decision on this recommendation, have its feasibility, desirability and economy assessed by a group of people with some expertise in music and music administration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probable that the questions are questions of management rather than questions relating particularly to musical matters. To the extent that they may relate to management decisions, it may not be appropriate for the implied criticism in the question to be applied to the Dix Committee or to its members. They are people who are experienced in business, in law and in the arts. It is a Committee with considerable management expertise and the suggestions, which are really administrative suggestions, I think, should be given some weight because of the background of the members of the Committee.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a fact that there has been a recommendation from that Committee that responsibility for the orchestras be transferred to the States. For example, the State Government of which Senator Hamer's brother was recently Premier may wish to have the management of the orchestras within that State. That may not be entirely inappropriate. It is also true, as Senator Hamer indicated, that the Committee recommended the setting up of a new body called Music Australia to have an overriding role in co-ordination and assistance. The Government is considering the recommendations of the Dix report, nothing more, and the setting up of the new body is one of the recommendations. The recommendations relating to the orchestras are among those which are under consideration at present. I understand that the Government is perfectly happy to consider any representations put to it from expert or interested bodies in relation to this or any other matter which is covered by the Dix report.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EUROPEAN PENSIONS FOR AUSTRALIAN CITIZENS: EXEMPTION FROM TAX

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does paragraph 23 (kc) of the Income Tax Assessment Act provide that income received from West Germany as compensation for Nazi persecution is exempt from tax, but that the exemption does not extend to similar pensions received from other European governments? If this is indeed correct, will the Government consider drafting new legislation to correct this anomaly by extending the scope of exemptions to cover those pensions not now covered?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Sibraa has posed a matter of policy. I will see that the matter is referred to the appropriate Minister and that consideration is given to it. I think that in terms of the question the matter would not be easy to resolve. I will see that some consideration is given to it and whether there is any policy change that the Government may consider fit to be made.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to the new River Murray Waters Agreement, now agreed in principle, and particularly to the important aspect that for the first time water quantity quotas for the States will take into account the quality of tributary inflows. Is there a timetable for determining the details of this part of the scheme?

—When the Prime Minister, the Premiers and I met recently, the arrangement was that this scheme should start immediately and should not await the implementation by law arising out of the work of the Crown Law Office. The intent of the scheme is to start now. Of course, there is a very fundamental situation, quite apart from the water monitoring, which concerns testing. A punitive arrangement has been accepted if in fact the water quality should degenerate. This is a discounting arrangement and, therefore, there is an incentive for the States concerned to keep the quality of their water high. As I understand it, that arrangement is current now. I think it will be an enormous advance in the whole of the concept of the management of the River Murray.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy in his own capacity or as Minister representing the Prime Minister. The question refers to an article earlier this week in the Australian Financial Review which was headlined 'Uproar over Cooper Basin pipeline contract'. Can the Minister say whether the Prime Minister has received from the Queensland-based pipeline construction company, Red Ru Pipeline, a telex alleging that it has missed out on the contract to construct the Cooper Basin liquids pipeline despite being the lowest tenderer and, it claims, initially the first choice of the partners involved in the scheme? If the contract is to be awarded to another company, specifically the big Italian government controlled pipeline constructor company, Saipem, is this a breach of ethics and contractual procedures as alleged by Red Ru's managing director? Finally, is there anything at all that the Federal Government can do to ensure that Australian companies get favourable consideration over large overseas companies when it comes to the allocation of tenders by companies such as the Cooper Basin Liquids Scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer the last question first. I say only that I was pleased to confirm the contract to Red Ru-I think, to Mr Nicholas-to build the Young-Wagga Wagga pipeline which was completed recently. I was equally pleased to commend him and his workers publicly for a job well done, done well on time and of high quality. So, in fact, the Commonwealth Government takes those things into account. I do not know whether the Prime Minister received a telex; I imagine he did because I did. I read the telex. In substance I think it said what Senator Haines has said. Of course, the question of the letting of contracts for the Cooper Basin-Whyalla pipeline strictly is a matter for the South Australian Government. I would imagine that, like all governments, that Government would have very effective tendering arrangements and conditions, tested over the years, so that its ethical standards would be absolutely high and unquestionable. Over the years the governments have developed, through their public works, a formula for tendering.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know the nature of the tendering system in South Australia. I would be happy, if the honourable senator wished it, to ascertain the details. I do not know whether Red Ru was the lowest tenderer. That would be a significant, but not necessarily overwhelming condition in the determination of a successful tender. I am not sure that, following inquiry, a government would reveal to the public the reason why a committee or board arranging tenders had made a certain decision, but I would be perfectly assured in my own mind that the body making the decision was a highly ethical one. Perhaps the first approach I should make is to inquire of the South Australian Government the nature of its tendering arrangements and, if it desires to comment further, as to the substance of the telex.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for National Development and Energy been drawn to the report in Tuesday's Press of an attack in a considered speech by the Executive Director of the International Energy Agency on the energy policies of the Reagan Administration in the United States, particularly in opposing the notion that market forces are adequate to achieve social goals? What is the Minister's current personal status within the International Energy Agency? Was he consulted before the release of the speech by the Executive Director? Was Australia's approval sought for the point of view expressed? In any case, what is the Australian Government's point of view on the attack launched by the Executive Director of the Agency?

—My attention was drawn to an article in the Australian Financial Review and I have sought from our diplomatic post the full text of the speech so that I can assure myself of its nature. Of course, I know Dr Lantzke very well indeed. I would not want to comment upon the essential substance of the matter except as it has been presented by the honourable senator. In regard to my personal status, I was particularly honoured to be invited to be the Chairman of the International Energy Agency meeting in June, and as its Chairman to conduct certain business in conjunction with discussions with Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries leaders following that.
—Was that a reward for talking up Rundle shares?

—If, indeed, Senator Walsh thinks that it is clever to downgrade the fact that Australia-not myself-was paid a particular courtesy, let him do so because he only downgrades himself when he does such things. I believe that Senator Tate would acknowledge that. I imagine that the chairmanship is arranged for each meeting. There is a president and an executive director and I imagine that at the moment I am simply the Australian representative at the IEA. I have to say that the IEA has the very strong view that oil prices should be at world scarcity prices. To that extent, market forces would be valuable within the United States in raising the price of oil, both indigenous and imported, to the world scarcity price. Indeed, Senator Tate will know that in the past America lagged somewhat in that regard. To that extent, I would have thought that the movement of oil prices to market and world prices would be unobjectionable. I think that the criticism may be directed to what might be considered to be the decontrolling. Under the Carter Administration there was considerable government involvement in the energy office in America, involving very heavy-of the order of $40 billion-government expenditure. As I understand it, what has happened under Mr Edwards, the new Secretary, is that he seeks to do that through private industry. What would be necessary before Australia made its value judgment would be to determine the whole of the substance of the matter and to look at it. I will get a copy of Dr Lantzke's comments and I will put them under study.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does the Minister agree that there is some danger in an executive director of an international body of such importance and repute making such considered attacks on a major power such as the United States of America without the prior approval of member nations?

—I do not think it would be proper for me to make such a comment without full knowledge of, firstly, what was said by Dr Lantzke and secondly, under what authority he spoke. There is a governing board which meets and he may have had authority from it. Dr Lantzke is a highly regarded and very respected officer at the international level. I have had the privilege of working with him. On the surface, I would not necessarily share the views I have seen expressed in the paper. I would need to know a great deal more before I lent any comments of mine by way of criticism of the man or his actions.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CROATIANS: CLANDESTINE MILITARY TRAINING IN AUSTRALIA

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Yesterday Senator Sibraa asked me a question which related to the television program 60 Minutes. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has given me some information with regard to that question. It is a matter of record that a terrorist incursion into Yugoslavia, in which some citizens and residents of Australia participated, occurred in June 1972. The Minister for Foreign Affairs also refers the honourable senator to the recent trial in Sydney as a result of which an Australian citizen was convicted under the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act and sentenced to four years imprisonment. In the event that further activities of this kind are uncovered appropriate action will be taken. In common with other nations Australia has an interest in the continued existence of an independent, united and prosperous Yugoslavia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two days ago Senator Reid asked me a question concerning the National Library of Australia and some problems relating to it. I am advised by my colleague, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, that he has noted the main points of criticism which have been made in respect of the resources provided by the Government to the National Library. The Library receives a considerable amount of public funds to permit it to carry out its statutory functions. In this financial year more than $17m will be provided for that purpose. This amount represents a significant increase over last financial year, bearing in mind that the responsibility for the Canberra Public Library Service has been transferred from the National Library to the Department of the Capital Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: The ordering of priorities within the Library is a matter for the Council of the Library to determine, having regard to the total resources, both financial and staffing, which the Government is able to provide. The Government has made its position clear that the utmost financial restraint is to be exercised on public expenditure. This policy impacts on all departments and statutory authorities. My colleague advises me that it is unfortunate that the Press report tended to overlook many positive steps which the Library has taken over recent years to preserve collections entrusted to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 October Senator Jones asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister in the Senate representing the Minister for Primary Industry. The honourable senator's question is recorded in Hansard and relates to estimates of the cost to taxpayers et cetera of maintaining a dual State-Commonwealth meat inspection system, in which varying figures have been given. The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question: The best estimate of the direct additional cost to the meat industry of the present dual State-Commonwealth meat inspection system is $1.25m. This estimate was provided by the High Level Working Group on Meat Inspection in its report to the Standing Committee on Agriculture at the Darwin meeting on 29 July 1981. It represents the calculated savings that adoption of either of the two proposed options under discussion at that time may have produced had they been agreed to. Upper estimates of costs to the Australian community have been put at $5m but would include all the components of meat inspection, charges and related animal health administration in Commonwealth and State governments. Many of these costs are inextricable from government administrations in the Federal system but represent costs that could be attributed in some way to the dual system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, 27 October Senator Button asked me a question concerning the alleged use of delaying tactics by the Commonwealth in its handling of appeals before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act. Although that question was addressed to me as Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General, in fact the matters raised probably related to appeals brought by my department, the Department of Social Security. I have sought advice from my Department in relation to this matter. In the light of that advice I am satisfied that there has been no use of delaying tactics as such by the Commonwealth in such appeals. At the same time I acknowledge that complaints have been made on occasions about delays in the finalisation of certain compensation appeals. These delays may be attributed to a variety of causes, many of which are beyond the control of officers of my Department and some of which have been largely overcome by the transfer of appeals jurisdiction under the Act to the administrative Appeals Tribunals.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators may be assured that officers of my Department are fully aware of the need to obviate any unnecessary delay in the processing of such appeals. To this end, senior officers of my Department have met with the President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to discuss ways in which the hearing of compensation appeals might be expedited before the Tribunal. Following those discussions, a number of steps have been taken by both the Tribunal and my Department and I understand that these have had a desirable effect. I am informed by my department that it also hopes to be able to expedite matters further as time progresses.

In raising this matter with me in the Senate, Senator Button made reference to a case decided by the tribunal in August this year. I take that to have been a reference to the appeal of Mr John Bruce Wells. I received detailed advice in relation to that case which was given some mention in the Press at the time. It is unfortunate that those aspects of the appeal which were drawn to attention at the time represented only a portion of the true story and that certain of the asserted facts were incorrect. Whilst I deeply regret that Mr Wells had to pursue so long a course to effect a settlement of his workers compensation claim, I am satisfied that officers of my Department acted with propriety in their handling of his claim. If Senator Button would like any more detailed advice I would certainly be prepared to give that to him. If he would like to discuss the matter with a senior officer of my Department that also could be arranged.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time today in answer to a question about Sinai I mentioned, in a form of words, that a Syrian diplomat's reaction, which I had believed I had read in the Press, to our participation in Sinai was positive. I have been advised by officers that whilst the form of words in the newspaper might draw that impression, that is not strictly accurate. Therefore, I hasten to correct it. My understanding is that the general Arab reaction to participation has been low key. I felt that I should correct that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I want to quote a few passages from the report of the Australian Wine Board. On page 6, under the heading of brandy, I notice that we still have a great problem in Australia because of the savage increase in excise placed upon the brandy industry by this Government in a Budget several years ago. It increased the brandy excise to some 83 per cent. The Government reduced the excise by some 3 1/2 per cent to 4 per cent shortly afterwards and claimed, I suppose rightly, that this Government had reduced the brandy excise. Although when one looks at that claim on the surface it sounds very good, the fact is that the excise has had serious repercussions on the industry.
Under the heading 'Brandy', the Wine Board reports:

In 1980/81 brandy still operated well below capacity, a situation which has in recent years unfortunately become normal for brandy producers in Australia. Nevertheless, brandy production recovered from 1.65 million litres of alcohol (lals) in 1979/80 to 2.3 million lals in 1980/81. Grape intake for 1981 brandy production is estimated at 25,000 tonnes, or approximately half the intake that was common in the early seventies.

For those who live particularly in the Riverland area of South Australia, the State which produces the greatest proportion of grapes for the production of brandy and also the greatest amount of brandy, this has had a very serious financial effect. Many of the people there who depend on the production of grapes for the purpose of making brandy are in very severe financial straits. I think the Government made a very grave mistake when it introduced this savage increase in brandy excise. Whilst I do not want to rehash the whole problem, I recall that members of the Government said when the Senate discussed this legislation that they were very concerned at what effect the brandy excise would have on the industry. One member of the Government from South Australia, Senator Teague, said that he would not be a credible Liberal if he stood by and allowed that increase to take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that, Senator?
—Senator Teague. He sent off his speech to the Riverland of South Australia. It got on the front page of the Murray Pioneer and he was hailed as a hero. Then, of course, when the crunch came--
—We got the brandy tax down.

—I have just mentioned that. The honourable senator has just come in. The Government brought it down by some 3 1/2 per cent, from 83 per cent to 79 1/2 per cent after already having put it up. But it has made no effort to bring it down since. I am referring, if the honourable senator would be prepared to listen, to his forked tongue in regard to he way he has dealt with this particular matter. I think he rushed into the chamber when he heard me speaking. Senator Teague stood in this Parliament--
—He was here.

—Was he? He must have been asleep. He is not denying what I said. Senator Teague said in the Senate that he would not be a credible Liberal if he allowed this savage increase to take place. When I had charge of an amendment to the Bill relating to the excise on brandy, which would have prevented this increase taking place, what did Senator Teague do? He voted against it.
—He denies saying it.
—It is in Hansard and it is also on the front page of the Murray Pioneer.
—If you keep saying it long enough, people will start to believe it.

—I will raise this matter on the adjournment debate tonight. I will bring the copy of Hansard in and I will prove that he did say it. I do not have the Hansard copy now. But, getting back to what I am saying in regard to the terrible financial problem that this brandy excise has created for the brandy producers in the Riverland, Senator Teague in fact did say that but then he had the temerity, after having made a public statement, to vote for this savage increase. Not only did he vote for it but also, when a large meeting was called at the Renmark showgrounds, Senator Teague went along, grabbed the microphone and asked a Dorothy Dixer of Mr Sinclair, trying to square himself off with the people. But the people in the Riverland have not forgotten.
—That is not true.
—You did ask a question.
—That is not true. I did not ask a question. That is not true.
—The honourable senator got up and grabbed the microphone. My colleague Senator Elstob was there with me.
—It is not true.

—All right, the honourable senator says it is not true. The fact is that the brandy excise imposed by this Government has had a very detrimental effect financially on the people of the Riverland. Those people are still suffering from this imposition and they will continue to suffer for many years to come. Those remarks are borne out by what is said in the Wine Board report which we are now discussing. The report points out that the grape intake for the 1981 brandy production is estimated to be 25,000 tonnes or approximately half the intake that was common in the early 1970s.

SPEECH.PARA: The other disturbing aspect of the report concerns imports. This Government is allowing massive increases in imports of brandy at a time when our producers are facing very severe financial problems. I venture to say that the Australian produced brandy is equal to, if not better than, most of the imported brandy. Yet we find that this Government has allowed a great increase in the imports of brandy, which is having a detrimental effect on our own industry. According to page 9 of the report, France has been able to export to Australia 116,666 litres of brandy in bottles or 432,888 litres of brandy in bulk. France is the biggest exporter of brandy to Australia.

In Australia brandy has to be kept on wood for at least three years, I think, before it is allowed to be retailed. This Government does not require any proof of the length of time imported brandy is subject to this process. I criticised the Labor Government a few years ago when Senator Murphy was the Minister for Customs and Excise because we were unable to establish whether the brandy we were importing was in fact matured on wood for three years. The grapes for imported brandy could be picked today, processed next week and then marketed in this country. People buying this brandy could be fooled into believing that it had been matured on wood for a certain period.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no grapes in them.
—We know that they have used all sorts of things. They use turnips, potatoes, pumkins and so on.
—How does it taste?

—I do not think it tastes as good as our own brandy. But the Government should be taking some action to protect our own industry by preventing this brandy from coming into this country. I am a great advocate of upgrading tariffs so as to keep this brandy out. Of course, people on the other side of the chamber are always saying that tariffs should be lowered, particularly in respect of the motor industry. But that is another question. Some farmers are claiming all the time that we ought to lower tariffs on farm machinery so that they can benefit. Just recently I asked representatives of a farmers' organisation whether they would agree to lower tariffs on dairy produce from New Zealand. They said: 'Oh, no', and threw their hands up in horror. They do not want the consumers of this country to benefit from lower tariffs, only themselves. Yet some of their own members in the Riverland of South Australia are suffering because we have no restrictions on the imports of brandy, which is being imported in increasing quantities every year.

SPEECH.PARA: Another thing that disturbs me is the massive increase in the volume of wine imported from Germany. Earlier this year I had a discussion with a man from Western Australia who sells imported German wine. I was horrified when he told me that the greatest buyers per head of population of wine imported by his company are South Australians. Some people in the Barossa Valley are the biggest buyers of wine imported by this company. They are not using our own wine. This will be to their detriment in the long run.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have one minute to go.
—I will move that you be given an extension of time.

—With due respect to my colleagues, I think I can complete my remarks. We find on page 8 of the report, under the heading 'Brandy', that clearances of Australian brandy in 1981 totalled 2.4 million litres of alcohol or the equivalent of 8.64 million bottles, which is an increase of 11.6 per cent. But we then find that clearances of imported whisky increased by 8.5 per cent and of imported brandy by 47.7 per cent. That again bears out my argument using the figures from the Wine Board report.
