SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In doing so I welcome the tabling of the report as being yet another informative report demonstrating another quite productive year from what is a highly expert and capable body which has been achieving a great deal despite the part time status of its members and despite the very small and overworked nature of its full time staff. This is the kind of report which raises questions about the whole status of the much vaunted new system of administrative law which has been introduced by this Government and its predecessor over the last few years. It also raises questions about the extent to which the new administrative law reality matches the rhetoric which we have been hearing from the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and others in recent times. Because of the constraints of time I do not seek to traverse the kind of ground which I have in previous speeches on this subject, but simply to make three or four points which seem to me to emerge very clearly from this report.

The first point is that it is clear that the Administrative Review Council is just not getting the kind of co-operation it needs from this Government if it is to be able to perform effectively the functions which have been vested in it. Whether that lack of co-operation is a product of this Government's narrow conservative ideology, whether it is a product of the Government's and the Minister's notorious lethargy in reform matters or whether, as perhaps is most likely of all in this context, it is the product of a systematic bureaucratic snow job designed to ensure that not too much changes in the way the administrative system works and its susceptibility to review-for whatever the reason-it is apparent that the Administrative Review Council is labouring under conditions of much less support than might be expected for a body of its stature and importance.

The Council in its report at paragraph 15 draws attention to the very depressing situation which exists in relation to its staffing. It is limping along at the moment with five full time staff and one part time position which in fact represents not an increase but a reduction in the effective staff ceiling over the last 12 months notwithstanding heartfelt pleas from the Council to enable more full time staff to be made available.

The other aspect which is an even more alarming demonstration of the absence of serious co-operation from the Government in the work of the Council is the matter referred to in paragraph 86. That follows where the Council in discussing the implementation of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, one of the key linchpins of the new administrative law system, refers to its recommendation last year to the Attorney-General that it would be desirable in monitoring the operation of that Act for all departments to be required to maintain records as to the operation of the Act in their respective domains and in particular to keep records of cases of refusals to grant statements of reasons and notices as required under that Act in order to enable people to exercise their administrative rights. The Council draws attention to the fact that this obviously very reasonable recommendation to the Attorney-General which is an essential pre-condition for any effective monitoring of the effectiveness of this piece of legislation was in fact rejected by the Attorney-General and in fact no such instruction was issued to the departments involved in the actual or potential administration of this legislation. As a result, the Council's capacity to monitor this legislation will in fact be rendered quite nugatory. That is a clear cut demonstration of the kind of absence of co-operation that has been forthcoming from this Government for whatever of the reasons that I mentioned.

The second point that I wanted to make is that it is clear on a number of quite specific matters, not just procedural issues, that the advice of the Administrative Review Council has not been taken as seriously by the Government as the stature of the Council and the quality of its output would suggest that it should. Many examples of that are evident in recent reports from the Council. I drew attention to a number of them in the context of the jurisdiction of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the jurisdiction of the courts under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act in rather lengthy speeches which I made on this subject, and which I will not repeat now, on 20 August last year and 20 November 1979. But I do draw the Senate's attention to the rather eloquent, albeit politely eloquent, statement of the fate of a number of recommendations of the Council which appears on pages 20 to 22 of the report where the Council made it perfectly clear that despite lengthy and carefully reasoned arguments having been put to the Attorney and to the Government as to the nature of the jurisdiction which ought to be vested in the courts in this area, that advice has in fact been systematically ignored. I think that is a matter for considerable regret.

The final matter I want to mention briefly is the present status of the Freedom of Information Bill which is the subject of numerous references, as one might expect, throughout this report. The Bill had always been intended to be the capstone, as it were, of the legislative system of new administrative law that was to be established respectively by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act, the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act and the Ombudsman Act. The Freedom of Information Act, governing the way in which the dynamics of the administrative system would operate, was the Act which when implemented would give additional shape and content to the structure for review of Government decisions which had been thus created. But of course we do now confront a situation with the early rising of the House of Representatives in which it is evident that this Government no longer has any obvious commitment at all to the actual enactment of the Freedom of Information Bill. Despite all the hurry that was evident when the Government rammed the Bill through the Senate with indecent haste in the dying days of the last session in order to avoid being confronted with the kind of majority it has now against it on these questions the Freedom of Information Bill has languished unnoticed and untended on the House of Representatives Notice Paper ever since.

A small attempt at pretending there was a second reading debate on the Bill was held early in the Budget session but since then nothing whatsoever has happened and all the evidence is that this Bill like so many other grand promises of this Government, legislative and otherwise, has been consigned to the limbo of lost causes. It is a wholly insupportable state of affairs that that should be so. This is an extremely important piece of legislation. It is disgraceful that the House of Representatives is getting up as early as it is, running for cover as obviously it is without debating the Bill. I fear that the failure to debate the Bill and the failure to enact it this session does indicate all to clearly what the fate of freedom of information will be under this Government.

Might I make it clear by contrast that the Labor Party is firmly committed now, as it always has been, not only to effective administrative review machinery in all the other ways that are the subject of the Administrative Review Council Report-I refer in particular to the effective operation of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the effective operation of an Ombudsman with wide-ranging jurisdiction and the effective vesting of review jurisdiction in the courts-but also it is committed firmly, explicitly and unequivocally to effective freedom of information legislation of the kind that was recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. It is a matter, as I have said, for profound regret that the Administrative Review Council was not able in this report to report to the nation that a proper, decent, effective system of administrative law in all those respects is now in operation in Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I have in my hands a copy of the 1981 annual report of the Canberra Theatre Trust. I am attracted to a couple of comments which the report makes in the paragraph headed 'Hirings and Operational Subsidy' and which should be of some concern to the people of Canberra. It states that although there was a surplus in the accounts on the operational subsidy provided by the Department of the Capital Territory there seems to be a need for an increase in that subsidy because nationwide there has been a fall-off in the number of private promoters and as a result fewer forms of entertainment are coming to Canberra. Apparently the increased cost of touring and the restricted seating capacity of the Canberra Theatre make profitability doubtful in the view of these people. The problem is understated in this report. Most annual reports understate the problems for some reason or other. No organisation which is faced with restrictions on funding is inclined to be highly critical of government because it may find there will be further restrictions in the funds which are made available. From this understatement there emerges a problem that Canberra is facing as the national centre. Not only is it the national centre of government but also it is the national centre, and we have accepted it as such for many years, of education and research. To a certain extent we believed that a cultural level would be developed in Canberra which would attract similar efforts elsewhere. It seems now that there will be not only a restriction in the growth of Canberra economically and structurally but also a chance of a lack of growth culturally. I believe that note ought to be taken of the comments made in this report, which states:

The Trust believes it should take the initiative in seeking out more attractions to bring to Canberra. To do so will, however, require greater resources than it has at present. Given a further injection of funds, the Trust believes that in the longer term more of the subsidy could be recovered by a greater usage of the facilities by hirers.

It is doubtful if the situation can ever be reached where no subsidy will be required as has been found not only in Australia but throughout the world in publicly owned performing arts centres. To reach this situation would require an increase in ticket prices of considerable proportion, which would in turn be counter productive in discouraging the public from attending the theatre.

I go back to the fact that the facilities in Canberra at present are limited. The attractions that are available now are limited by the cost of bringing performing arts companies here. Therefore there is in effect a downturn which should concern not only citizens of Canberra but also this Parliament which is responsible for the development of Canberra as a national capital.

It may be said that the problem is Australia-wide, but it goes back to the policy attitudes of the Government in reducing funding for the performing arts. If this trend is allowed to continue, it could reach a stage where to reverse it would need considerable funds and effort. The stage could be reached where the trend could be irreversible; the traditions, the expectations which are developed within Canberra, could be so diminished that when funds become available there may not be the initiative nor the enthusiasm to lift the national capital back to the cultural level that we have been led to expect. This report ought to be carefully considered; the implications which are spelt out in mild terms should be realised fully and taken up by those who are concerned about the cultural advancement of Canberra.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The report of the Department of Administrative Services deals with multi-varied aspects of Government administration. Therefore, in 10 minutes it is rather difficult to give adequate attention to all of the various sections and statutory authorities that come within the purview of the Department of Administrative Services. Nevertheless, I shall do what I can with the report and the variety of issues it deals with in the brief time that is available.

Firstly, of course, it deals with a vexed question that has been worrying the citizens of New South Wales for a considerable number of years. The machinery of government grinds very slowly particularly as it relates to the attempts that have been made by the community of Sydney to get its hands on Commonwealth properties that would otherwise be regarded as part of a military requirement. Of course, I refer specifically to the attempts made by many organisations and by the State Government to establish the Sydney Harbour foreshore or national park.

The report also deals with the infamous decision made by this Government, as a result of the razor gang decision, to sell the Glebe Estate. That is a very important land acquisition. This was a property and accommodation decision made by the Whitlam Government to acquire from the Church of England in Sydney the very large area, containing some 700 dwellings and 60 commercial properties, commonly known as the Glebe Estate. Of course, so far as the Commonwealth was concerned, that was a very good buy. Of course, the Government now having got ownership of it and looking from the point of view of revenue is endeavouring to sell the Estate. Under force of public opinion that the Government should at least have regard to the fact that the Estate should remain in public ownership and not be sold off as a piece of real estate, negotiations are still proceeding between the Commonwealth and the State Government.

We hope the State government will be adamant in its attemps to get ownership of this important piece of real estate, being as it is close to the city proper and one which affords an opportunity for a public authority to provide cheap and effective accommodation within the city proper. Therefore, given the Commonwealth Government's desire to have transferred to it other areas of land within New South Wales, one would hope that there will be an amicable settlement of that project.

I draw to the attention of the Senate another one of the policies being adopted by this Government which shows that it does not have regard to building up its assets. My remarks apply to overseas residences and public offices. Page 12 of the report shows in relation to rental outlays and outlays on capital works and purchases the difference between the last Labor government Budget for 1975-76 and the current Budget of the Government. It is worth referring to the policy considerations that this conservative Government has pursued in this area in the brief period it has been back in office.

In 1975-76, the Australian Labor Government was prepared to put $15.9m into the areas of capital works on and purchases of overseas properties, but it paid only $11.3m out in rent. It is interesting to compare those figures with the drastic change that has occurred in this area since the Fraser Government came to office. In the current year, we are spending only $3.6m, less than a quarter of the amount I previously mentioned from the Labor 1975-76 Budget, on capital works and purchases. Of course, expenditure on rent has almost doubled from $11.3m in 1975-76 to $21.3m in the current Budget. This Government claims to be concerned with good business principles. We are now paying out more than twice the amount of money in rent that we did in 1975-76, but are doing so in a period when property values overseas are increasing tremendously. As far as the Government's foreign affairs and trade responsibilities are concerned, it has not taken advantage of acquiring property and therefore of having assets in foreign countries.

Very briefly, I refer also to the matter dealing with the Government's information services and their sales and distribution of publications. We see here quite a remarkable increase in public interest in our sales and distribution of publications. Sales increased in 1980-81 by 32 per cent over those for the previous year. Of course, as we all know this is an enterprise profitable for the Commonwealth. What is the Commonwealth seeking to do? It seeks to lease or sell the Australian Government Publishing Service, an area in which there has been a tremendous increase in profitability.

I turn in a fairly hurried way to advertising expenditure. This is a matter coming under the Department of Administrative Services, to which I think the Senate's attention ought to be drawn. In 1975-76, total Commonwealth Government outlay was $9m. It has now risen to $23.2m. This is an increase of about 270 per cent. It is worthwhile looking at how the Government is now spending that increased budget. For example, in 1975-76, the last Budget of the Whitlam Government, we spent $68m in display and classified advertisements in metropolitan newspapers. That figure is now down to $42m which is rather a dramatic drop at a time when we ought to be publicising and communicating the decisions of Parliament and other activities of the national Government. It is similarly shown that in the provincial Press there has been a dramatic drop in advertising expenditure from $7m to $3m.

Of course, this must have some effect upon the Government's attempts to communicate and to advertise activities in respect of the printed media. One must say that, having regard to the influence that the television moguls have upon this Government, we see a corresponding increase over the previous six Budgets, in the amount of money spent on television advertising, from $11m to $40m. Maybe it can be argued that this is the most effective way of presenting a point of view. The Opposition has seriously criticised the Government's wastage of expenditure on so many advertising campaigns, for example, in relation to the 35-hour week and other matters.

The reference dealing with public order and police affairs is contained on one and one-third pages. The Department of Administrative Services deals with public order and police affairs so this is a most inadequate report on that aspect. It does not mention the tremendous drop in morale that has taken place as a result of the merger of the Australian Capital Territory Police with the former Commonwealth Police Force, to form the Australian Federal Police organisation. It does not mention the great dissatisfaction that is evident in the Australian Federal Police journals. It does not mention the dissatisfaction which exists in Tasmania, Victoria, New South Wales and South Australia because the Government's assurances in respect of the merger have not been carried into effect. Nor is any mention made of the fact that the projected retirement of Sir Colin Woods, the head of the Australian Federal Police, probably results from his failure effectively to bring about the merger in such a way as to protect the economic interests and efficiency of our new national organisation.

—I am told by Senator Coates that Senator Harradine is provided with not just one telephone but many telephones to enable him to service Tasmania. I think that matter was raised during an Estimates committee hearing when Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked a question about the emoluments paid to the extra staff of Senator Harradine. Whilst the Government can provide those facilities for one senator from whom it might expect support on contentious issues, members of the Parliament such as myself and Mr Wallis are not provided with adequate parking facilities and, because I want to have a second office, I have to bear the whole cost of that office.

SPEECH.PARA: It might be argued that honourable senators are given an electorate allowance and we should meet the costs of office facilities from that allowance. But, that argument falls to the ground when we look at the situation of the honourable member for the Northern Territory and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, who are provided with second offices. Senators have to represent a whole State and not just a small electorate. In my State of South Australia at least the Australian Labor Party members service the whole State. We split the States up into areas so that we can service country areas. I represent, in particular, areas within an electorate in which the sitting Government Liberal member does not want to live; he wants to be within view of the General Post Office clock and to have his office in King William Street where country people do not have access to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which member is that?

—There are two members. One is the honourable member for Barker, Mr Porter. I have two offices in his electorate, one at the extreme north and the other at the extreme south. The extreme north of that electorate borders on the extreme south of the electorate of Wakefield, so my main office is more or less in the centre of the two electorates. My other office is at Mount Gambier. What I am asking for is that the Government give due consideration to not only my desire but also the desire of other honourable senators to be provided with a regional office and facilities so that we can give our electors the service to which they are entitled. The electors pay us. We are their servants. At least we in the Labor party deem ourselves to be their servants; probably some Government members do not. Anyone who cares to read the record of what I have said might see that a couple of members do not believe that they are servants of the electors they represent because they neither live nor have an office in their electorates. Whilst Liberal members of the Liberal Government often claim that they have the interests of the country people at heart, I think the proof of the pudding is in the eating, particularly in South Australia, where they do not have the interests of the country people at heart. We have only two Federal members in South Australia who are so concerned about meeting the needs of their electors that they live in the country and have their electorate offices there. What I am asking for is to be provided with the wherewithal to enable me to conduct my regional office in a proper manner, rather than having to conduct it on a shoestring, having to scrounge around for furniture and having to pay the rent for the office. We have a good office. A I said, it is serving its purpose down there. But it would serve the purpose a lot better if we had support from the Government in that regard. I hope that the Government will take notice of what I have said.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I hope also that the Government takes congnisance of the fact that neither Mr Wallis nor myself, who are country members, has any parking facilities in Adelaide. I understand also that even the metropolitan members who have electorate offices in the suburbs they represent, if they have to go to Adelaide on parliamentary business, cannot find a place to park. Some of them are Liberal members, but mostly they are Labor members who deign to live in the electorate and to have an ofice there. If they come into the city no parking facilities are available to them. I hope that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner, being a South Australian-I hope that also, as a senator, he has the interests of his constituents at heart-will do something to help us to overcome the problem I have outlined. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH ACCOMMODATION AND CATERING SERVICES LIMITED

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report of Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services Limited is one which has to be looked at with a great deal of misgiving and sadness. That organisation has been carrying on a very worthwhile activity in a variety of places throughout Australia, at the waterfront, with the Australian Federal Police, the Clyde Cameron college and so on. The Government is hocking off those enterprises. They are profitable enterprises. The income and expenditure accounts show that, apart from the taxation loss, they are able to provide a service at very little cost to revenue.

I refer to matters on which I do not believe we have had satisfaction. I do not think that Senator Evans received a satisfactory reply to a question he asked the other evening when we were considering the Estimates in Committee of the Whole. His question related to the effects of the decision of the razor gang, or should I say the Fraser Gang, to sell off all those public enterprises. The fact is that, despite the assurances given by the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, what is happening is that in the transfer of the enterprises the Government is not being sufficiently forceful and the new owners of the enterprises, be they responsible for catering or cleaning, are being discriminatory. Without equivocation they are preferring to accept the younger members of the labour force for employment and are not having a second look at anybody over the age of 40 years. Certainly they are not applying any criteria which would permit the employment of migrants. I do not think it is good enough that the Government allows those new contractors to make such decisions.

In the negotiations the Commonwealth Government should have made it mandatory that no labour would be displaced as a result of the sales. The undertaking given to this Parliament should be carried into effect in those enterprises. All labour employed by the Commonwealth Government in an enterprise should, on the sale of transfer of that enterprise to the private sector, be transferred to the private sector. We have made it quite clear that we are opposed to the sale of public enterprises. We do not believe that public property should be transferred to the private sector, irrespective of whether it is the catering service, or the organisation that handles cleaning or the supervision of public buildings. We feel that way also about the sale of Commonwealth properties such as Havelock House. The four Commonwealth Government guest houses that have been operating for many years in Canberra have been placed on the market.

We make it clear again that we expect the Government, in all humility, to pay some regard to humanity. A discriminatory policy is being exercised. The new companies, the private sector managers and supervisors, are picking and choosing in respect of labour content. That means, of course, that we are placing in jeopardy the future of quite a number of the persons who have been employed and who have given faithful service to the Commonwealth. I hope that the Government will be a little more determined, having regard to the statements made by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle to Senator Evans the other evening, to make sure that the livelihoods and the jobs of those affected by the razor gang decisions will be protected in the transfer of these public enterprises to the private sector.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Despite the obvious enthusiasm and energy of the lengthening cast of characters who seem to have been involved in the preparation of this report, I believe it is in several ways quite a disappointing document. It is disappointing in the first place because of its continuing evident pre-occupation with the fireworks and dress-ups aspect of the bicentenary rather than its potential for being the occasion for some rather more long lasting and significant national achievements. For example, the achievement of a renewed Australian Constitution along the lines I have suggested in various forums and on occasions elsewhere really would be the kind of significant goal for which an occasion of this kind might provide a momentum otherwise lacking.

In the second place, I think the report is disappointing because it reveals the continuing failure to date of governments at any level in Australia to give a clear indication of the likely financial commitment that they are prepared to make over the whole period leading up to the centenary. That state of affairs was adverted to by Mr Cohen in the other place when this report was debated there a few days ago. The failure of the governments to be prepared to make the kinds of contingent commitments that are necessary in this matter clearly has been quite destructive of the planning capacity of the Authority and other various offshoots around the country. They cannot be criticised for the Government's failure but it certainly ought to be acknowledged that there has been such a failure. The remaining matter that seems to me to be of real disappointment is the evidence revealed by the report of the evident failure so far of the bicentenary concept in any way to impinge on the national consciousness. On page 6 of the report it is stated:
A national survey early in 1981 showed that only one in four people could identify 1988 as the Bicentennial Year.
The report goes on to state:
This situation needs to be remedied quickly, but it must be done without raising expectations prematurely.
It also states:
The Authority has embarked on a programme aimed at increasing awareness among the Australian people of the significance of the Bicentenary.

I take this occasion to suggest in this respect that perhaps the best way of embarking upon a consciousness raising exercise about the bicentenary and what is involved in it and, at the same time, contributing to that sense of national pride, independence and unity which it is part of the bicentenary objectives to encourage, would be for the Bicentennial Authority to sponsor a competition to produce a design for a new Australian flag. I readily acknowledge that patriotic instincts have all too often been appealed to in the past in support of various ignominious tory crusages in national chauvinism of one kind or another. However, I believe that we ought to be proud of our country and that we should not be ashamed to demonstrate that pride from time to time. One of the best and time-honoured ways of expressing that pride is to embody it in national symbols including, of course, a national flag for which people do have some real, genuine affection.

Whilst I hope that our culture never becomes as sentimentally obsessed with flag waving as the culture of the United States of America appears to be-in this respect the United States, as in so many other contexts, does rather seem to do things to excess-I think we can do rather better than the present undistinguished and undistinctive bith of cloth which we have inherited from our colonial past and which manifestly does not set anybody's pulse racing in the community at large except, perhaps, the occasional Returned Services League blimp or a proportion of the tory back bench opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about, as an innovation, the coat of arms above the chair; shouldn't that be on the flag?

—I take a view about coats of arms-that they represent a rather medieval hangover. I will mention in a moment that I think there is something to be said for embodying some of our native fauna on the --
—But they are not imperialistic symbols.

—They are not imperialistic except that the whole concept of a coat of arms implies a rather aristocratic preoccupation with the symbols of elitism which I thought would be foreign to Senator Mulvihill's democratic nature.
—You are looking to the Eureka stockade.

—Ah, there we come on to it. I want to make reference to this and say simply in general terms that I endorse the kinds of remarks made by Mr Hurford in the other place when he spoke on this subject on 10 September, while not necessarily endorsing his preoccupation, which he apparently shares with my learned colleague, Senator Mulvihill, for medieval armoury. At the same time, I take the point he made about the desirability of there being some distinctive imagery of this kind to replace the rather indistinctive imagery that is there at the moment. One of the most important incentives to produce a flag which can generate a bit more enthusiasm than the present one must be said to be the flag pole which will occupy such a pre-eminent position in the new Parliament House. It is perhaps getting things rather tail about to let the architecture design the flag. I think one of the reasons people have been critical of the pre-eminence of the flag pole in that design is that nobody is especially happy about our present flag assuming for the future such an obviously central role in our imagery about ourselves.

SPEECH.PARA: I am well aware of the endless argument that is possible on this subject. I certainly hope that we do not find ourselves in the Canadian situation. The Canadian Parliament was bogged down in 1965 for almost six months, almost to the exclusion of all other business, while it debated committee reports and kicked the arguments backwards and forwards both as to the colour of the flag and on what its content should be. I think it would be helpful to generate officially, perhaps through the auspices of the Bicentennial Authority, some sort of competition designed to elicit a systematic response on these questions, such as what our national colours should be. We should consider whether they should be the blue and the gold which seem to be the official status colours but which do not really appeal to anybody as having any relevance to what we think of as being the Australian colours-obviously the green and gold. What sort of design would best and most effectively assure recognition of the flag as being a genuinely Australian symbol?

I do not express any personal preference at this stage except perhaps to make a couple of points. One is that I am rather fond of the Eureka design-I am sure that will appeal to Senator Mulvihill-this being our one really significant indigenous attempt at flag making. I regret that that design seems to have been captured by the looney Left of this country in recent years and that its real potential for being a unifying symbol of the nation for the future has, to that extent, been somewhat diminished. I hope that as a result of this kind of exercise it might be possible to recapture some of the original democratic and national pride associated with that imagery.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have ignited the flame.

—I am endeavouring to do that. If I ignite the honourable senator's flame at least that is a start. Failing that, I say that I have a sneaking preference-and I think this might appeal to Senator Mulvihill even more-for a design which embodies in some simple and elegant fashion Australia's most spectacularly well known symbol, and that is the kangaroo, perhaps in the form of a yellow and gold design. I acknowledge that this might be thought to be bordering a little on the kitsch to contemplate our fauna being elevated to this kind of status. But there are ample precedents elsewhere for various exotic bits of a country's fauna or flora appearing on the national flag. If we are talking about a flag as being a symbol of a country's recognition around the world, it is very difficult to argue otherwise than that that would have the greatest effect.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall not burden the Senate with possible scenarios as to how such a competition might actually be conducted and organised, whether it should be accompanied by the supervision of a parliamentary committee or questions of who should have the final say in any such outcome. I simply ask that the issue be seriously considered now, if it has not been already, by the Bicentennial Authority because it may be, as corny as it sounds, the best way of capturing the public national imagination about the bicentenary concept.
Sitting suspended from 1 to 2.15 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE GOVERNMENT CLOTHING AND ORDNANCE FACTORIES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion and to make a brief statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the time for the presentation of the Report on the future of the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo by the Select Committee on the Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories be extended by providing that the Committee report as soon as possible.
(2) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its Report-
(a) the Committee may send the Report to the President of the Senate or, if the President is unable to act due to illness or other cause, to the Deputy-President of the Senate;
(b) the Report shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate and the President or the Deputy-President is authorised to give directions for its printing and circulation; and
(c) in such event, the President or the Deputy-President shall lay the Report upon the Table at the next satting of the Senate.
(3) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

On 22 September, the Senate agreed to the establishment of the Select Committee on the Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories to inquire into the future of the Australian Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo. The Committee has to report by the first sitting day in November on the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo. It has become necessary for the Committee to have further time to consider properly this aspect of the reference. In a little over a month, since the matter was referred to the Committee, it has met seven times, twice travelling to Bendigo-once for a public hearing-as well as holding public hearings in Canberra with representatives of the Department of Industry and Commerce and the Department of Defence.

A wide interest has been shown in relation to the future of the factory. To date, with the inclusion of a submission that arrived from the Australian Council of Trade Unions just a few minutes ago, the Committee has received 18 submissions, most of which are of considerable substance. To consider properly the issues raised in the submissions and the public hearings, the Committee requires additional time in which to report. Indeed, the view was expressed in public hearings in Bendigo that the Committee should not be limited in its investigations by a short reporting time. The Committee is mindful of the reasons for the short reporting time imposed by the Senate in relation to the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo and I can assure the Senate that the Committee is applying itself to the task of reporting as quickly as possible. I would hope that, if the Senate sits for two weeks when it resumes the week after next it might just be possible to have the report ready for presentation by then but, failing that, it will be available as soon as possible thereafter. I think the end of November would be about the best the Committee could do. A bit more time is needed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I express my concern that further time has been sought by the Select Committee on the Government Clothing and Ordinance Factories. I understand its reasons for seeking further time. It was my prediction at the time when the Committee was established that it would not be able to perform the task that the sponsors of the motion to establish the committee seemed so readly to give to it. My colleague, Mr Bourchier, in the other place and my colleagues in this place, Senators Missen and Hamer, and I have put an enormous amount of time into consideration of this problem in the city of Bendigo. We have considered representations from many people in Bendigo and we have also made a number of representations to Ministers. We were aware that it was more than likely that at least some 18 submissions would be received as Senator Martyr has confirmed has occurred, and that there was a wide interest in this matter in Bendigo. It was clear that a proper investigation of this subject would take considerable time.

SPEECH.PARA: What concerns me is the effect that this inquiry is having on the people of Bendigo who have had their anticipations aroused by the sitting of the Committee. I recall speaking to Senator Siddons when he indicated that he intended to go ahead with this motion. I put to him outside the chamber that there was no chance of the Committee having an adequate consideration of this subject matter and coming up with its conclusion by 1 November. He assured me that he could see no reason why it could not comply with this timetable. Then, Senator Button, seeing the opportunity for some political gain from this matter, leapt in and supported the proposal that the Committee be established and that it report by the first week in November.

What absolutely staggered me was to discover that the Opposition had appointed Senator Button to the Committee. Senator Button must be, apart from Ministers of the Crown, the busiest senator in this place. For Senator Button to get himself on the Committee and to expect it to be able to bring down a report within a few short weeks was an absolute nonsense and a clear indication to me and to the members on this side of the Senate that he is involved in this matter only for the political gain that he can get out of it.

I am very disturbed about the people of Bendigo who are waiting on this report, apparently believing that it will in some way or other achieve the objects of the people who are concerned about this matter. Really, Senator Button is playing on their emotions by involving himself with this Committee. Knowing the amount of work that he has to perform, there is no possible chance of him being able to assist the Committee to reach a speedy decision., which is what he has been talking about.

Mr Bourchier and I have made representations to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) that the Bendigo Ordnance Factory ought not to be sold unless it be sold to a company which does not intend to asset strip it, unless it be sold to a company which has sufficient asset backing and free-flowing capital available in order to put into this Bendigo Ordnance Factory the additional capital that it needs. Frankly, if the Government cannot find a purchaser with those sorts of qualifications, it ought not to sell the factory. I firmly believe that the Government has accepted the recommendations from Mr Bourchier and me and, frankly, I have never been able to see the need for this Committee or for a report other than for the political purposes of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make the point that it is important for the Select Committee on the Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories to proceed. It has become very obvious that the problems of selling the Bendigo Ordnance Factory to private enterprise are very great indeed. There seems to be no way that such a move could be guaranteed. The preservation of the important ordnance work at Bendigo-indeed, the preservation of important ordnance work for our defence production capability in the whole of Australia-is the issue that is at stake.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has moved with all possible speed. I can only criticise in the strongest terms the comment that Senator Button joined the Committee for political considerations. He has demonstrated by his attendance and the time that he has devoted to the Committee that he is very concerned about the issue, as are the people of Bendigo. We are facing the problem of losing expertise and capability in defence production that has taken nearly two generations to build up. I believe that this Parliament would be acting with complete irresponsibility if it rushed into a decision on such an important issue without have exhausted all possibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the Parliament's decision; it is the Government's decision. It is not the Parliament's decision.

—I am sorry, it is Parliament's decision. It is of great concern to all the people of this country. We are sending troops to Sinai. The Indian Prime Minister, Mrs Gandhi, said just a few weeks ago in this country that there is a disturbing build-up of naval forces in the Indian Ocean. We are about to sell the one factory than can manufacture naval ordnance and that can repair the ordnance of our ships which may operate in the Indian Ocean. It has become very obvious to the Committee that there is no way that we can guarantee the preservation of this factory in the hands of private industry. There are very real problems. I can only say that we as senators would be irresponsible if we did not give the information we have received the utmost care and attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks of Senator Siddons. I viewed the operations of the Senate Select Committee on the Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories from afar and near. I visited Bendigo with the Committee. Members of the Committee are approaching their task with great diligence-with much more diligence than the Government approached the actual decision to get rid of the Government Ordnance Factory. Criticism was made that Senator Button joined the Committee so as to make political points. Maybe some political points have to be made because the representations of Senator Lewis and Mr Bourchier appear to have got nowhere. I will at least give Senator Lewis credit for staying in the country, not going away for three months and representing the electorate from some 12,000 miles away.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee needs more time. The submissions are very extensive and detailed. I was very impressed by all the submissions. I hope that the report is put down some time in November. I revisited Bendigo just two days after the Committee had made its visit. Senator Lewis is correct-the visit by the committee has raised the hopes of people in Bendigo. They have some hope in the Committee; they do not have any hope in the representations of Senator Lewis or Mr Bourchier.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE ELECTORAL SYSTEM

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The next matter for consideration is General Business, Notice of Motion No. 56, standing in the name of Senator Gietzelt. Is this formal or not formal?

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Gietzelt-I seek leave to move a motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Gietzelt moving a motion relating to Notice of Motion No. 56.

I want to draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that since 1977 the Government has been conducting a review of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. A number of senators, both Government side and, particularly, Opposition, have raised a number of questions with respective Ministers for Administrative Services. In this place we have directed our questions to Senator Withers, Senator Chaney and Senator Peter Baume, who represents the current Minister, Mr Newman, who succeeded Mr John McLeay.

The Opposition's patience on the question of reviewing the Electoral Act is just about exhausted. The Opposition has sought the goodwill of the Government. Mr Hayden discussed this matter with the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) with a view to establishing a joint select committee to look at the Commonwealth Electoral Act only to be informed over the last couple of days, due to the Government's haste to get the House up because of embarrassment caused by a whole series of incidents during 1981, that the Government had finally decided not to agree to the establishment of such a committee. As I indicated in June, the last occasion on which I raised this matter, it was the intention of the Opposition, having discussed this matter with the Australian Democrats, to establish a select committee in the spring session of Parliament. If we are denied the opportunity to do that, the task of reviewing the Commonwealth Electoral Act will not be able to be undertaken in the life of this Parliament.

I want to put it to Government senators that all we are asking for at this stage is that a select committee be established. It would be able to conduct one very short meeting before the Parliament rises for this year. Following that meeting we would be able to invite submissions from interested bodies throughout Australia. The Commonwealth Electoral Office would have the opportunity to make a submission. We would then be in a position to carry out that essential review of the Commonwealth Electoral Act during the following year and, depending on the evidence that is available, make recommendations to the Parliament in respect of this matter. Just to emphasise the point, Senator Chaney in reply to a question by Senator Button, said:
A review is currently being undertaken of all aspects of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Senator Gietzelt is debating the issue. He is supposed to be giving us the reason why we should suspend Standing Orders.
—I am just giving the reasons.
—There is no point of order.
—Senator Chaney said:

SPEECH.PARA: I can give no indication as yet as to when the results of that review are likely to come forward for Government consideration.

That was on 12 September 1978-more than three years ago. Senator Mulvihill then directed a question to Senator Chaney, who said that it was the intention of the Government to bring forward a general review of electoral laws. He said:
It is my intention to discuss that general review with the officers of the Australian Electoral Office within the next few weeks and to get some idea of the parameters of that proposal.

On 17 October 1978 Senator Chaney, acting in his new capacity as Minister for Administrative Services, made that statement. Senator Sibraa asked a question of Senator Chaney on 20 March 1979. Senator Chaney said:
I will refer the matter . . . to the Minister for Administrative Services--
At that time Mr McLeay was the Minister. Senator Chaney continued:
who is responsible for the conduct of the review of the Commonwealth Electoral Act which is at present still with the Commonwealth Electoral Office and has not yet come before the Government.
I then asked questions. Mr Braithwaite asked a question of Mr Newman on 2 December 1980, almost a year ago. Mr Newman said:
At present the Chief Electoral Officer and I are examining the Commonwealth Electoral Act and the conduct and the administration of elections.

I asked a question a couple of days later to which Senator Baume said that the matter was still under consideration. Senator Missen has asked several questions this year on matters relating to the Electoral Office. I have asked another two questions in recent times about tolerance, redistribution and the report.

Therefore, I think we are entitled to say, without in any way discussing the substantive motion, that the patience of the Opposition has expired. I would believe that if the Senate were to look at this matter in an objective fashion it would agree with our attitude. We are not asking for approval of legislation. We are not asking for the Government to be put on trial. We are taking a position in respect of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. We are asking for the establishment of a select committee. I understand that senators from both sides of this House-that includes senators from the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats and the Government parties-are prepared to serve on such a committee. All we are asking is for the right to establish such a committee. I have a copy of the report which has been referred to by previous Ministers and which this Government has had since 22 August 1979. That report states that there has been no substantial overall legislative review of the Commonwealth electoral law over the last three-quarters of a century and no major consolidation since 1918.

Are we going to leave it in the hands of the Executive, of the government of the day, which is clearly procrastinating and delaying for its own reasons? One cannot understand why it is doing that. That report has been in the hands of the Government for more than two years and I am led to believe that a second report has been called for. That has still not been made public. I have asked for this report to be made public. Fortunately, when I was walking around the streets of Canberra a document fell off the back of a truck and therefore I have that document. It indicates that from the Commonwealth Electoral Office there is a great, pressing need for a review of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. The document draws attention to the fact that Australia has undergone many changes. Perhaps that of greatest significance in relation to electoral law has been the increased mobility of the Australian electorate. One could go on and talk at great length about what the report says. For example that since the Commonwealth Electoral Act was first enacted there has been a great change in the whole way in which elections are conducted.

The report draws attention to the fact that the major political views in Australia have hardened largely behind a small number of political parties-the National Country Party of Australia, the Liberal Party and the Australian Labor Party. It draws attention to the fact that communications have changed dramatically, that radio and television are now the main forms upon which advertising and election campaigns are conducted as distinct from the method used when the Commonwealth Electoral Act was first enacted during World War I. Of course then one stood on the street corner and explained one's point of view to those who assembled to hear it. There has been a very dramatic change in the way in which elections have been carried out in the last 60 or 70 years. The report refers to the importance now of talk-back programs on radio. It also refers to the electronic media blackout. I have some disagreement with the Australian Democrats about this, based on my early political experience of what happened in 1942, when we had this dramatisation of politics during the last 24 hours of an election, which brought about changes to the Australian Broadcasting Act of that time. Of course, the report also refers in great length to the need to have limitations placed on expenditure in respect of elections. Surely these are matters which the public at large, and the Senate in particular, would have some interest in.

The report also draws attention to the differences in the way in which election campaigns are conducted in Western countries. It mentions the changes that have occurred in countries of Europe, the United Kingdom and Canada and the need, therefore, to have some limitation on the amount that can be expended on election campaigns. Similarly, it talks about the differences that exist in the four main countries of the Western world-the United Kingdom, Western Europe, Canada and Australia. For example, it is interesting to note that in the United Kingdom if 50 candidates present themselves for 50 different electorates then those various political parties have equal access to the British Broadcasting Corporation for the presentation of their policies and their candidates. In Western Europe the general tendency is to have free time based on the degree of electoral support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the fact that Senator Gietzelt is certainly straying very far and wide and seems to be discussing the substantive issue rather than the point which is before the Chair, and that is the suspension of Standing Orders.

—I respect the point of order that has been taken. I drew attention to those matters to show the need for a public examination of the issues and the need to look at voting systems. I also drew attention to the report which deals with optional preferential voting and with the degree of informality. These are matters which have been debated in the Parliament and consequently--
—You have got friends over there. You didn't know that, did you?

—I am sure that I have friends over there. I would hope that very shortly those friends on the other side would join me and agree that Standing Orders should be suspended at least for the purpose of establishing such a select committee. I know that there are members on the Government side who share the concern of the Commonwealth Electoral Office, the Austradia Labor Party and the Australian Democrats and I am sure they also share the concern of the Australian people who believe that our electoral system and laws should be equitable and be on such a basis and standard so that everybody can have equal rights.
—Order! I suggest that the honourable senator has made his arguments. Having made his arguments as to the reason for the suspension of Standing Orders, he is now starting to range a bit wide.
—Thank you, Mr President. I invite the Senate to respond accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MASON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders for a number of reasons, which Senator Gietzelt has stated admirably and at length. I will not repeat them at this moment. We are debating whether there is any urgent necessity for this matter and whether we should go ahead with the motion and arrange for the appointment of a select committee. It is the view of the Australian Democrats that there is considerable urgency over the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: After all, in the last week or so the Government has been showing all the signs of refusing to accept the majority opinion of the Senate. It shows signs also of reacting with the desperation of a cornered rat in these circumstances in that it appears to be of the inclination-some of its members have said as much-that it may even force this country into an expensive and unnecessary double dissolution election simply because it has not got its way. It will not accept the reasonable requests of the Senate, which are the majority opinions of the Senate and also the opinions of the Australian people. The possibility is that the Government may well plunge this country into an election next year. If it is going to do that, then it is essential that we should--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator, you are ranging very broadly on the subject.
—I am speaking to the matter of urgency.
—I suggest that you bring your remarks back to the same issue that was raised by Senator Gietzelt.
—I will do that, with great respect to you, Mr President. The motion is one of urgency to suspend Standing Orders. Should we suspend Standing Orders now? Of course we should.
—For a reason, Senator, as specified by Senator Gietzelt. I ask you to confine your remarks to the same reason.
—I am coming to my point, Mr President.
—Thank you. I suggest you do.

—It is: Why should we do this now? Surely that is the point we are trying to achieve. We will do it now because we are facing a situation where we may have an election next year and it is essential that these matters be considered before that is done. Can we trust the Government over this matter and trust it to do this? I think that has a bearing on Senator Gietzelt's motion. I do not think we can. The Government very cynically, during a journalists' strike, when it knew that it would not get publicity, abolished and repealed those sections of the Commonwealth Electoral Act which concerned disclosure of expenses. Half of the Australian community still does not even know that that happened, that that matter had been put forward by the founding fathers in the Commonwealth Electoral Act as far back as 1902. I was looking through the Hansards. That provision was cynically destroyed by the Government so that it had the Electoral Act in such a state that it could spend as much money as it liked from any source it liked, without disclosing it. When we raised that question and I objected to it in this place, the Government said that it would hold an inquiry. But the Government was very careful not to have the inquiry until after the 1980 Federal election. The Government cannot be trusted in this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: This makes it urgently necessary for those of us on this side of the House who want this matter to proceed to do so by the suspension of Standing Orders now. It should not have been necessary for Senator Gietzelt to get up and suggest that we suspend Standing Orders. There is no reason why we should all have to use this device of the House as much as we do. The Government should recognise that it does not control this Senate, that it is not the majority here, it is the minority. I am not saying that in any threatening sense, but in the sense that it should reasonably accept the things that the Senate says and wants.

The idea that we should have a select committee has been a matter of discussion between the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party for some months now. We believe it will be a select committee of enormous importance and we believe it is a matter that the Australian people want discussed. One of its terms of reference will indeed refer to that cynical and cowardly Government action of deciding that it would remove from the Commonwealth Electoral Act any kind of disclosure of expenses so that it can go to its friends and get as much money as it likes. The Government does not say who that friend is, if indeed he is a friend. Believe me, that friend is no friend of this country. Such friends are the people who want to exert undue influence on the Government, and the Government has cleared the way so that they can do that. We promised the Government at the time it amended the Electoral Act that is was something the Australians Democrats would never forget and something we would continue to remind it of; here is another opportunity to do that.

This is a matter of urgency. I give an undertaking as the Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats that we will certainly contribute to this proposed committee. We will place one of our members on it and we urge honourable senators opposite accept this motion to allow this matter to proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason the Government opposes this motion at this time is that simply it has been forced upon us. We have had no opportunity in our party room to consider the whole proposition properly. Members on this side of the chamber have a particular interest in the matter and would want to put their views in their party room to make sure that we have a common view on it. For that reason, we oppose the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Gietzelt's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Senator Button, could you give the reason? I have been asking for some indication of the reasons for making personal explanations.
—I understand I have been misrepresented, Mr President.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I was out of the Senate chamber I understand that Senator Lewis laid a very grave charge against me. He said that I had become a member of the Select Committee on the Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories, which is inquiring into the future of the Bendigo factories, for political reasons. Mr President, that is perfectly true. I am a member of that Select Committee for political reasons but I am one of those people who are old fashioned enough to understand that political reasons can sometimes be honourable. Nothing I have seen in Senator Lewis's conduct here would suggest to me that he is here for political reasons. He may be here for social reasons or something of that kind; but nothing in his life has led me to believe that he is here for political reasons of any serious purpose. I have been misrepresented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That at 8 p.m., after the further consideration of papers pursuant to sessional order, intervening General Business be postponed until after the consideration of General Business Order of the Day No. 62, Senate Elections (Queensland) Bill 1981; No. 89, Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill 1981; and No. 138, Industrial Democracy Bill 1981.

I move this motion because of the agreement that on Thursday nights we debate Opposition business. Certain agreements have been reached to discuss three items of business tonight. Unfortunately, for some reason best known to itself, the Government has decided to change this arrangement and deny Senator Colston the opportunity to speak to his private member's Bill. We on this side of the chamber feel that it is inappropriate that Senator Colston should not be allowed to do so. He should be entitled to have his motions debated. No doubt he will have something to say on this matter.

It is disturbing to recall that Senator Colston has been trying to get his Bill before this chamber for some time. He has been very co-operative. He has been prepared to stand down from the list of speakers and deny himself an opportunity of making a contribution in an area that he was particularly keen to speak on in order to have his Bill debated. This opportunity is being denied. I do not intend to speak at any length, but co-operation to the Government seems to mean-we listen to the Government speak about a little goodwill and a little co-operation-that we do what it happens to want to do and not what we might want to do. The one night of the week when we have the opportunity to debate business that we think ought to be brought on, the Government has decided, capriciously I suggest, that it wants something different, despite the fact that this is contrary to an arrangement which we have made with it. That is why I have moved the motion that this evening Senator Colston, Senator Evans and Senator Siddons present their private members' Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after 'General Business, Order of the Day' insert 'No. 89 Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill 1981; No. 138, Industrial Democracy Bill 1981; and No. 62, Senate Elections (Queensland) Bill 1981'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to speak at great length on this matter. It is very difficult, when one is the person involved, to see some things objectively. We have just been given an amendment, which certainly I will oppose, which drops to the bottom of the list tonight, the private member's Bill which I presented to this Parliament. This probably suggests it will not get on. If we had been given some reason for that amendment by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) things might have been different. It is very hard to argue against what he has moved when he does not put any arguments forward himself. It is very hard to put counter-arguments to nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that what is going on at the moment is a deliberate ploy by the Government to shelve this Bill because it thinks it might go through this place tonight. It reminds me very much of the behaviour of the Government earlier this year. We all remember what a hard first session we had because of the amount of legislation that was going through the Senate simply because the numbers were here for the Government at that time but those numbers were not going to be here from 1 July onwards. In fact the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on the program AM recently admitted that this was so and used this as justification for getting Parliament up early. But that is not the real reason for getting Parliament up early; he simply wants to get the Parliament up so that he will not have people peering over his shoulder all the time. What is happening this afternoon reminds me very much of what happened earlier this year when the Government was using the temporary numbers it had to get some legislation through. Because it does not have the numbers today, because one of its supporters is away, it is fearful that this legislation might go through. I cannot see why it is fearful. There is nothing terrible about the legislation that I have presented.

What is happening here this afternoon also reminds me of something that happened in mid-1975 when I was not a member of the Senate. The Government then used contrived numbers in this place to make sure that an elected government was sent to the polls early. Some of those contrived numbers were put there because I was not here. I should have been here under normal circumstances, but because of a maverick government somewhere else, somebody else was put in this place to replace a Labor Party member who had died. I am reminded of these things this afternoon because of the way the Government is behaving.

I presented the Senate Elections (Queensland) Bill earlier this session. I had it ready well before the session started but I took my time and waited until it was satisfactory to people on both sides of the chamber for me to introduce it. I accepted that I might have to wait. I introduced the Bill in the session prior to the end of June and gave my second reading speech. There is nothing in the Bill that is really controversial. I have waited patiently to have this Bill debated. I thought perhaps I would come back with some comments at the end of the debate so that the Bill could pass this place and go to the House of Representatives.

Last week it was indicated to me that by 5 o'clock some time would be set aside for the debate of that Bill. I realised at that stage that we might have a tight debate if we commenced at 5 o'clock. But I was willing to accept that we would start the debate then. A number of honourable senators were speaking on the appropriation legislation. I deliberately took my name off the list of speakers, even though I wanted to make a contribution to that debate, so that there would be more time available for the debate of this Bill.

A major statement was then brought down and at 5 o'clock a debate commenced on the Sinai peacekeeping force. At that stage I rose and mentioned that I had deliberately taken my name from the list of speakers on the earlier legislation and that I would be unable to make a contribution to that debate and to the Senate Elections (Queensland) Bill. I said words to the effect that it looked as if we would have to arrange a different time for the debate. I can recall Senator Carrick sitting and nodding very wisely and very gravely, giving me the indication, certainly not by words but by action, that we would debate this Bill at a subsequent time. It seemed, from some of the comments that were made, that it would be debated this week. This week when I came back to the Parliament and spoke to my Whip I found that the Government had decided that this Bill would be the last item of business for the next Thursday night. That certainly was not acceptable, and all this week my Whip and my leader have been trying to make arrangements to have this Bill brought on.

I believe that this is almost a deliberate breaking of an agreement that we made last Thursday. All of the indications were that the Bill would be brought on and would be debated. Of course, if it is debated today it might pass through this chamber and be transmitted to the House of Representatives. Last week an indication was given to me that, if the Bill were debated, a motion would be put forward to the effect that the Bill be held back until February next year. The indication was that it would be held back until February so there could be consultations with the Queensland Government. Honestly, I do not know what the Queensland Government has to do with this Bill. Those people who read the way the Bill is written and who look at the Constitution will know that this matter is one purely for the Commonwealth Parliament alone. If the Queensland Government were to be consulted to make sure that it agreed to the provisions of the Bill, we would be here in 100 years time still waiting for the Queensland Government to agree.

Although the Queensland Government has not used the particular provision that I am talking about, the provision is still there for any government, which loses some speck of decency, to gerrymander the electorates in Queensland for the purpose of electing senators. What is wrong with this Government, if it has to consult with the Queensland Government before a Bill such as this comes on for debate? Is it afraid of the Queensland Government? That situation reminds me of one of the other powers contained in the Constitution that this Government can use which is in relation to making laws for Aboriginals. That power was given to the Government in the 1960s by an overwhelming vote from the people in a referendum. Yet this Government seems very timid to use those powers when it comes to doing anything for Aboriginals within Queensland. Unfortunately, this Government seems to be afraid of the Queensland Government and seems to be afraid to do anything that might peeve it or that the Queensland Government might think should not be carried out. This Parliament has the power to take the action neccesary in this matter.

In conclusion, it seems to me that any agreement made by the other side has to be taken with a grain of salt. I made the point last week that I was beginning to understand what my Party Whip had to put up with in this place. I believe that, if an agreement is made by the Government, it should be kept. The Government should have known that the Bill was expected to be brought on for discussion this Thursday. Therefore, I will oppose the amendment moved by Senator Messner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats for reasons similar to those expressed by Senator Colston will oppose the amendment moved by Senator Messner. It seems to me totally inappropriate and rather petty that, in a Senate so evenly divided, on matters of Senate Business the Government should seek to bludgeon its way through on every occasion that it can. That is totally inappropriate. It would be far more appropriate if in fact it were possible for the progress of this type of business to be arranged by agreement. Traditionally, Thursday night is for dealing with Opposition business; therefore, it seems to me that, in dealing with Opposition business, surely the Opposition parties ought to be consulted. We have expressed a wish that the Senate Elections (Queensland) Bill 1981 should be brought on first.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government wishes to operate in that fashion, we may go back to the time, mentioned by Senator Colston, when his Bill did not come on for debate for the reason that the Government wished to spend time in the Senate talking about the Sinai peacekeeping force. The Government by leave sought to talk about that. In fact that leave could have been refused as the Government did not have the numbers to force a discussion of that item here in the Senate. The Opposition parties allowed leave because obviously it was an important statement. To accommodate the Government and to allow it to have a statement made here in parallel with a statement in the House of Representatives, it was thought reasonable that we should accede to the Government's request in relationship to that matter. What do we find? Our reasonableness in acceding to that request was subsequently used against the Opposition parties in this chamber to their detriment.

I think that, if this chamber is to operate in any reasonable way from now on, the Government should look again at the Bill and allow the arrangement of business, as proposed by the Opposition parties, to be followed, firstly with consideration of the Senate Elections (Queensland) Bill, followed by the private member's Bill that Senator Evans intends to move and then the private member's Bill proposed by Senator Siddons. That does not seem to me to be unacceptable. It is a perfectly reasonable proposition. I appeal to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) that he see this as a reasonable proposition in terms of the arrangement of Senate business and allow it to go ahead so that in future weeks, before the end of this session, we may not have a Senate where leave is not always given and a variety of other devices of this chamber used to disrupt business. The motion moved by the Minister seeks to disrupt the business of the chamber. It is a direct disruption of the business that traditionally is allowed to the Opposition Parties on Thursday night.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to answer one or two points raised by Senator Colston. Firstly, I think it must be observed that an opportunity was given to Senator Colston to discuss this Bill last week--
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Robertson has moved a motion to which the Minister moved an amendment on which he spoke.
—The Minister will need to seek leave to speak.

—by leave-I rise briefly to make the point that we understand that Senator Colston did in fact withdraw his name in respect of the appropriation Bills last week. In fact discussion was set down in respect of his Bill for last Thursday night but we did not discuss that Bill for the reason that there was an urgent matter in connection with Sinai and many other issues were raised in respect of the transport and communications area. As honourable senators might recall, a number of papers were dealt with in this chamber at that time and that delayed discussions. I say that perhaps Senator Colston should be in a better position to influence his colleagues in future. I think there is another reason which is more important and which supersedes all of those other factors. This relates to the fact that the Government is in a position where it needs to have legislation for social security pensions and repatriation pensions passed before 1 November; otherwise no pension rises will be paid after that date. Consequently, it is necessary for the Senate to consider this legislation as promptly as possible. Therefore, I invite honourable senators to carry on with the job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I understand that I have a right of reply. I do not want to hold up the debate this afternoon but nothing of what the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) said when he originally put down his amendment or now justifies the amendment. Not one argument that he put had any relevance to what we were talking about. The first point I make is that Senator Colston's Bill has nothing whatsoever to do with the passage of social security legislation this afternoon or any other time. The time that has been given to the Opposition on Thursday nights is intended to enable us to deal with certain matters. It has been agreed that we will handle those matters on that night. All that we are talking about here is the order, nothing more. The three items that are to be debated tonight are in a certain order according to our wishes and in another according to the wishes of the Government.
