Not one statement has been made to suggest why we have to change our order.
—They are born to rule.

—Perhaps that is it. Perhaps Government supporters have the delusion that it is they who will make the decisions. As a matter of fact, if one might so comment, all this week we have seen examples of that. On one night we had the ridiculous situation of the debate being delayed from 10.30 to 11 p.m. simply because a Government Minister wanted that to happen. We sat until 20 minutes to 12 and achieved absolutely nothing except bad will-simply because that Minister said: 'I will say what is going to happen in this place'.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon we are dealing with another Minister. I will not nominate him but he made the statement this morning that it is he who decides that the Opposition business will be in order such and such rather than in the order that the Opposition wants. Clearly, the Government had no objection to Senator Colston bringing on his Bill tonight because, very generously, it has said: 'You may have it as No. 3'. The Government has produced no arguments as to why it should be No. 3-simply that it wants it in that order. This is the one night of the week when, traditionally, we have been allowed to organise our own business.

That brings me back to the point that the people on the other side of the chamber have no idea of tradition. We saw that in 1975 and we have seen it since. It is all very well for them to scoff. They like to get their own way all the time. Senator Withers, who is smirking in the background, is the person who said: 'We will never act as an Opposition. We will bring down the Government. That is the only job of an Opposition'. Yet we have Government supporters coming in here every day and saying: 'A little goodwill, gentlemen; a little co-operation, senators'. Goodwill means doing what Senator Carrick wants in this place. Co-operation means doing what the Government wants. I suggest that we throw out this amendment and, on our business night, employ the order that we want, not the order that the Government wants.
Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill provides for amendment of the Repatriation Act and associated Acts to give effect to the Government's Budget decisions and for certain operational and machinery amendments intended to facilitate administration. In the Budget context, service pension is to be extended to Australian mariners; repatriation benefits are to be extended to all representatives of Australia who suffer death or incapacity while serving with peacekeeping, observation and monitoring forces of the United Nations, or any other recognised international body; disability pensions are to be paid to former members of the Royal Papuan Constabulary and the New Guinea Police Force; and the proportion of disability pension to be disregarded in determining eligibility for service pension and fringe benefits is to be increased. In addition, the pensions payable for amputations or loss of vision, and the amounts payable for many other repatriation benefits are to be increased. Supplementary assistance, known as rent allowance, is to be increased. The operational and machinery amendments are simply to correct certain operational shortcomings, to clarify certain provisions, and to align the legislation with modern drafting practice. I will deal with these briefly after I give details of the Budget initiatives.

SPEECH.PARA: As announced in the Budget, eligibility to receive service pension is to be extended to Australian mariners who served in a theatre of war during the 1939-45 War. An Australian mariner is broadly defined as any mariner employed under agreement in sea-going service during the 1939-45 War on a ship registered in Australia. It includes Australian mariners employed in seagoing service in a ship registered outside Australia. Persons who served in a lighthouse tender, pilot ship, hospital ship, troop transport, tug, cable ship, salvage ship, dredge, supply ship, fishing vessel or fisheries investigation vessel are included in the definition. These men were not members of the Forces but civilians who, in undertaking their normal occupation, were subject to dangers from enemy hostility. This extension of service pension will be effective from 4 February 1982.

Repatriation benefits are also to be extended to all representatives of Australia who serve overseas with peacekeeping, observation and monitoring forces raised or organised by the United Nations or any other international body. At present, for a member of the Armed Forces to be eligible to receive repatriation benefits he must have had three years effective full time service, or have been discharged medically unfit. Civilian personnel, such as members of police contingents, have no repatriation cover. This proposed amendment of the Act establishes a mechanism whereby Australian representatives performing peacekeeping or similar duties in areas outside Australia where a state of tension exists will be eligible for repatriation benefits. The extension will apply only to those members with service after 1 November 1981 in any force which on the authority of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs is designated in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette as being a peacekeeping force for the purposes of the Repatriation Act. Currently Australian peacekeeping forces are serving in the Kashmir region, the Middle East and Cyprus. Following the announcement of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on a possible commitment of Australian forces to the Sinai peacekeeping force, the provisions in this Bill have been examined. The provisions of the Bill in relation to peacekeeping forces would not extend to such a force. The Government has agreed that it will bring forward legislation in the autumn sittings to cover such a force if it is sent to Sinai.

Honourable senators will be pleased that the Bill gives formal recognition by Australia of the outstanding service of former members of the Royal Papuan Constabulary and the New Guinea Police Force who, although not strictly members of the Forces, served under Australian Army control from 7 December 1941 to 31 December 1945. Disability pensions will be paid to these veterans from the date the Royal Assent is given and under the same conditions as apply to other Papuans and New Guineans who served as members of the Australian forces during World War II.

Last year, the Government introduced a measure that was widely welcomed by the ex-service community. It provided that only half of a disability pension be taken into account in determining eligibility for fringe benefits. The Government has decided that the proportion of any disability pension disregarded when assessing eligibility for fringe benefits and service pension is to be increased to 60 per cent from 1 January 1982, thus enabling more persons to become eligible for the service pension and still retain fringe benefits. In addition, this measure will increase the amount of service pension paid to many veterans receiving disability pensions for incapacities suffered because of their service.

Provision has been made in the Bill for increases in many other repatriation benefits to severely disabled veterans and pensions paid to orphans with effect from 12 November 1981. Over each of the past three years these benefits have been increased and thus protected recipients against the effects of inflation.

The pension paid for amputations or loss of vision, which is payable in addition to the repatriation disability pension or service pension, is to be increased by approximately 9 per cent in respect of the various categories of disablement. Also, the rate of attendant's allowance is to be increased from $19.32 to $21.02 a week in the case of a veteran who is blind or is suffering a cerebro-spinal injury. In the case of a veteran who has had both arms amputated or is blind and has lost hearing or speech, the allowance is to be increased from $38.65 to $42.05 a week.

The Bill also provides for the maximum amount of supplementary assistance, known as rent allowance, payable to a service pensioner to be increased from $5 to $8 a week from the first pension pay-day in February 1982. (Quorum formed). From that date supplementary assistance will be made available only if the amount of rent paid by a veteran exceeds $10 a week, at a rate of 50 cents for each $1 of rent above that amount. These changes are similar to those which will apply to pensioners of the Department of Social Security. The Government recognised that some pensioners currently receiving supplementary assistance could be financially disadvantaged because of the changes to the eligibility criteria and decided that payments would continue to be made to them at the existing rate. Overall the increased benefit will assist many who face increased rent charges. Other increases affecting veterans announced in the Budget, including increases in funeral benefits, clothing allowance, and recreation transport allowance, are to be provided for by the regulations.

I now will refer briefly to the operational and machinery amendments contained in this Bill. Provision is made to bring the terms and conditions of service of persons appointed to the Repatriation Commission and Repatriation Boards into line with those currently applying to other statutory appointees. Provision is also made to simplify and facilitate the processing and hearing of applications for the review of decisions of the Repatriation Commission and Repatriation Boards by the Repatriation Review Tribunal. Certain provisions relating to the review of decisions by the Repatriation Review Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will be clarified. In addition, the Bill corrects certain operational shortcomings and aligns the legislation with modern drafting practice.

In conclusion, this Bill reflects the Government's continuing concern to see that those who have served their country in times of war or war-like operations are appropriately compensated for any losses they have suffered or sacrifices they have made. It reflects this Government's belief that the main pensions and allowances directed toward the more seriously incapacitated and needy veterans should be kept under continuous review to ensure that these are not permitted to be eroded as a result of inflation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 October, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Services Amendment Bill 1981 is an omnibus piece of legislation--

—Mr Deputy President, I am sorry to intervene just as the honourable senator is starting his speech, but I think it was proposed that this be a cognate debate. I thought we might try to clarify that point before the honourable senator gets well into his speech.
—Mr Deputy President, it was not proposed to me that there should be a cognate debate and I certainly do not agree to any such debate.
—Order! I think only one matter was called and that was the Social Services Amendment Bill 1981.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. As I said, this legislation, the Social Services Amendment Bill 1981, is an omnibus piece of legislation, as are all such Bills presented at this time of the year. From our point of view, it contains sections which we support, sections of a technical nature which we do not oppose and two clauses in particular which we oppose absolutely. The Bill provides for many changes to the Social Services Act. Firstly, it seeks to alter the Supplementary Assistance Scheme to increase payments and it seeks to alter conditions of payment of the rent allowance to pensioners and some sickness beneficiaries. It seeks to exclude from the new supplementary allowance future tenants of government housing. It seeks to increase by $3 a week the rate of the incentive allowance payable to the sheltered workshop employees by increasing that allowance from $5 to $8 a week.

SPEECH.PARA: It provides for the granting of a wife's pension under conditions which will be the same as those applying to the granting of an age or invalid pension. It seeks to increase the amount of child endowment payable for the third and subsequent children. It seeks to extend the circumstances under which double orphans pensions are payable in respect of refugee children. It seeks to prevent the payment of the unemployment benefit to the spouse of a person who is involved in industrial action or the payment of a special benefit to those people. It also seeks to prevent the payment of the unemployment or special benefit to persons who are spouses of people who have had their unemployment benefit cancelled or postponed due largely to failure of the work test or their being deemed to be voluntarily unemployed, except in very special circumstances. Finally, it seeks to increase from $53.45 to $58.10 the rate of unemployment benefit payable to persons aged 18 years or more without dependants.

Two aspects of the procedure by which this Bill has come to the Senate must first be referred to by the Opposition. The proposals contained in this Bill were announced in the Budget on 18 August this year, some two months ago. One further provision, the intention to correct the income avoidance practices of some pensioners in this country, was also announced in the Budget but it is not included in this legislation. It has been delayed until at least next February. One assumes that is because the Government cannot work out how to do it. One assumes that, once again, the Government has made an anouncement without thinking the matter through. It is typical of the Government that legislation like this, containing so many varied proposals, should be presented to this Parliament for debate at the absolute death knell of the session and should be brought into this House three days before some of the proposed increased payments-namely, those made to the unemployed without dependants-are due to be made.

It is also typical of the Government that pressure should be applied to the Opposition to consider the Bill and its provisions in haste, using those very increased payments as a weapon to attempt to bulldoze the associated unsatisfactory aspects of the Bill through the House. That, in fact, is nothing less than blackmail. We heard the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), in the debate immediately preceding this, using that sort of argument to encourage this House to ignore its normal procedures and, in fact, to rush through this legislation. It is also typical that the Bill after its long gestation period is, on the admission of the Government, a defective Bill. It is defective in drafting and will need amending at a later date to correct a mistake in the section dealing with refugee children.

The intent of the legislation was announced in the Budget. The introduction of the legislation has been delayed deliberately to truncate the debate. The legislation is not satisfactory, even in the Government's eyes, after that time has elapsed. The unsatisfactory and controversial sections of the legislation are tacked on to the inoffensive sections in an attempt to stifle opposition. The Opposition is expected to fold against this pressure to satisfy the desire of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to have the House of Representatives rise early to avoid the discomfort he is suffering from the exposure of his and his Government's inadequacies in that place. We have no intention of yielding to this pressure. We have no intention of assisting the Prime Minister who, in typically cowardly fashion, is running away from his responsibilities to this Parliament. Legislation of this type involving the well-being and the civil rights of the less fortunate members of our community should be introduced in time for proper consideration and proper debate by all members of this Parliament, and not rushed through in three days. The device of tacking on offensive legislation to essential changes to overcome opposition is cowardly. The Government should put its controversial items separately and debate and defend them on their merits. It is for this reason that I have given contingent notice of motion to seek to separate the segments of the Bill which we find offensive out of the legislation.

Let me first deal with the aspects of the legislation which change the supplementary rent assistance system. At present the maximum assistance is $5 a week for pensioners in rented accommodation who have an extra income of less than $6 a week. After a free area of $1 a week the amount made available is reduced dollar for dollar so that after $6 a week no supplementary allowance is paid, with the exception of married couples who have their income calculated as half their combined income. Under the new system only pensioners who pay more than $10 a week will qualify. The rate of payment will be half the rent in excess of $520 a year up to a maximum of $8 a week and the amount will be reduced by one half the annual income of the pensioner.

Pensioners who are in government housing, particularly State government housing and Commonwealth government housing such as that subsidised at Glebe, at Jervis Bay and in some Aboriginal areas, in future will be excluded from receiving the supplementary rent allowance. It is worth while noting that those in local government housing, which is also subsidised, will still receive the supplementary rent allowance. In fact, there is also a saving clause which means that those who are already receiving the supplementary allowance and are in those circumstances of government housing will continue to receive it.

In June 1980 there were 400,000 people in this country receiving supplementary assistance. There were 188,000-odd aged pensioners, 102,000 invalid pensioners, 55,000-odd widow pensioners and 45,000 supporting parents. Under this scheme the Government claims that about 300,000 private renters will improve their situation and we certainly agree that that should happen. About 130,000 others currently receiving supplementary assistance will continue to receive it at their current rate, due to the savings provisions in the legislation. So only about 30,000 new people will come into the supplementary assistance scheme as a result of this liberalisation of the system. But this is only a guess, as is the estimate that this will cost $20m this year and $50m in a full year. This estimate was characterised by the departmental witnesses at the Estimates committee hearing who described it as being of broad orders of magnitude only. I suggest that that is roughly the departmental equivalent of: We really do not have a clue how many people will be involved and how much it will cost.

Supplementary assistance has been around since 1958. It has not been increased by this Governmeft since 1975. The strict means test of a dollar for every dollar over the $1 free area has not been increased at the same rate. Those pensioners who have been paying rent since 1975 have, in fact, received no extra assistance from the present Government. In that time there has been no real attempt to evaluate the effectiveness of this method of assisting people in housing. One can remember the housing allowance voucher experiment which cost the Government in excess of $1m. It was to be evaluated but it was killed before it got under way. It was an ill-conceived program but it was an expensive program which was destroyed halfway through its initial stages because, I presume, the Government came to realise that this was an ineffective way of providing housing.

At the same time, since 1975 the amount of money available for public housing has been effectively halved and the amount of assistance available to the States for public housing has similarly been reduced. In this legislation and in this change certainly the Government recognises what the report of the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty recognised, that is, that there are far too many people, particularly pensioners on low incomes, who are in the private rental market. As such we welcome the liberalisation introduced in this legislation. But it is a complicated means test and one hopes that every assistance will be given to pensioners when they seek assistance in this area.

We do not agree with and we are quite unhappy about the introduction of the clause which in fact prevents those who are in State rental housing from receiving assistance. Those who are in State rental housing at the moment will certainly retain their $5, $4 or $3 assistance but new tenants of State government housing will receive no assisstance at all. The States do not subsidise housing in a uniform way. The States have different methods of calculating the subsidy they will give to housing. Some local governments provide subsidised housing. Their tenants will still receive the supplementary assistance but those in State government housing will not. This, we believe, is an unnecessary discrimination. In housing estates in this country we will have two groups of pensioners-one group under the saving clause receiving supplementary assistance and their neighbours, who have come in after the commencement date of this legislation, receiving no assistance at all. We believe this is a form of discrimination. It is unfair to State housing tenants. To a certain extent it will assist private landlords who will bid up the price of rent as they inevitably do when more money becomes available. It cuts down effectively the amount of housing assistance available to the States because the States, in calculating their subsidies, take into account the supplementary assistance which has been available previously through the legislation.

The whole exclusion of State housing tenants, we believe, is unfortunate. We believe we are in a situation where, with increased interest rates, increased costs of housing and increased costs of land, more and more people are being forced into public housing. At the same time public housing is not being made available to make up for this increase and we believe moneys would be better spent and, in fact, more money should be spent on the provision of public housing stock. In the amendment which I will move to the motion that the Bill be given a second reading we ask the Government to reconsider this. We ask the Senate to express the opinion that, in fact, people renting public housing should not be excluded from payment of this supplementary benefit.

We have the situation where supplementary rent assistance will continue to be paid for those who have been on sickness benefit for more than six weeks. But once again, one of the poorest groups in the community, one of the most disadvantaged groups in the community, the unemployed, will receive no rent assistance at all. The Government, through this legislation, although it liberalises the provisions for some people, in the long run is saving money at the expense of pensioners in housing commission homes and pensioners in other forms of State accommodation. In fact, it does nothing at all to ease the very difficult housing problem which we face in this community, and which everyone realises we face in this community.

The next section of the legislation I will deal with concerns those who are on the unemployment benefit, who are adults-over the age of 18 years-and who have no dependants. This year this group will have its first increase in the unemployment benefit since 1978. The increase to $58.10 a week still leaves those people $11.60 a week and $603.20 a year poorer than single pensioners of the same age and in the same circumstances, and in fact who have the same needs. These people will receive $69.70 a week from next week.

It is important that we realise the discriminatory nature of the Government's action in removing this group of unemployment beneficiaries from the provisions of the indexation clauses in the legislation. They are being paid less. They are not receiving the automatic increases received by others who are dependent on social security benefits. They have a more restrictive means test than other pensioners and although their level of permissible earnings has been improved, their current earnings limit discourages them from seeking part time employment or from seeking to assist themselves. Inevitably this encourages deceit; it encourages people to seek to get around the provisions. A single unemployed person over 18 years of age working part time can keep only $28 of his or her earnings before losing the rest on a dollar for dollar basis. However, a single adult pensioner can earn $20 without losing anything and then loses only $1 for every $2 earned.

If we really want to encourage the unemployed to take casual or part time employment to get experience in the work force and to help raise themselves above their difficult circumstances, the present financial difficulties are too severe; the disincentive is too severe and is not in keeping with the Government's asserted aim that it wishes to help those who help themselves. There are over 19,000 single people over the age of 45 years on the unemployment benefit. No one can accuse them of being dole bludgers, as so many members of the Government like to do; no one can say that they are sponging off their parents. Many of them are out of work because their skills are no longer appropriate. Many are out of work because of technological change in industry which has made great differences to and great inroads into the occupation levels of many industries. They should not be treated with any less dignity and they should not be given less support than their contemporaries who are on other benefits.

The second reading speech says that the level of unemployment benefit has been struck with regard being given to the needs of such beneficiaries as well as to the continuing needs for restraint in Government expenditure. It is quite apparent that restraint in Government expenditure has won in this situation over any regard for the needs of this unfortunate group. Those aged 45 years and over make up one of the most rapidly increasing areas of unemployment in our community. It is for this reason that we include a section in the second reading amendment expressing our distress and concern that these people have once again been neglected.

Another group that is completely neglected in this legislation, and which has been completely neglected since 1975, is that of those on unemployment benefits who are under 18 years of age. Since April 1975 they have been paid $36 a week, which is now almost $40 a week below the poverty line for a young person living alone. Certainly most do live at home with their families but, as has been said in evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare over and over again, the situation of the young unemployed trapped at home because of the inability to move with this $36 payment, in what is sometimes a hostile environment particularly in those areas where unemployment for two generations is common, is potentially difficult and destructive not only to the person who is unemployed but also for the structure of the family itself. It contributes considerably to the problem of homeless youth.

For those people who are away from home, either because they live in rural areas where there is insufficient employment or in other areas of low employment and move to seek employment, the $36 a week is an absolute pittance. It is absolutely impossible to live on that, as has been repeatedly pointed out to the Senate Committee on which I serve. According to a survey of the Department of Social Security last May, there were 40,000 under 18 years of age unemployment beneficiaries. A total of 8,500 of them-more than one in five-had been on unemployment benefits for more than six months. Thirty-six dollars is an absolutely inadequate payment. It is impossible for anyone in this community, particularly living away from home, to live on $36. It creates the problems which we know are common amongst our youth. It particularly contributes to the problems of the homeless youth in our community. It is for this reason that we again include in the second reading amendment, as we have in past years, an expression of opinion by the Senate that something should be done about this unfortunate group.

I will now deal with the provisions in the legislation which the Opposition find offensive and discriminatory and which we utterly oppose. I refer to those sections of the legislation which deal with the spouses of unionists affected by industrial disputes and the spouses of unemployed persons who have failed the work test or are deemed to be voluntarily unemployed. Against vigorous opposition not only from the Australian Labor Party in this Parliament but also from the trade union movement itself, from welfare agencies in the community, from councils of social service, from churches and from most newspapers in this country, the Government introduced a provision whereby not only unionists directly involved in industrial action could seek no assistance from the department of Social Security-no one is advocating that that should be the case-but also unionists indirectly involved in the dispute could not do so. This included unionists stood down because of a dispute in the same union which may have occurred in another State or which may have occurred hundreds or thousands of kilometres away and of which they may have no knowledge, and certainly no opportunity to influence.

We pointed out at the time that the ridiculous situation could arise where there could be a dispute by one union in, say, Newcastle which means that people in car manufacturing plants in South Australia will be laid off work. The people laid off who are members of the union taking part in the dispute in Newcastle would not receive unemployment or special benefits. Their neighbours, in another union, could receive those benefits. This was discriminatory; it was using the social services legislation as a weapon in industrial relations and in industrial disputes. It demonstrated to everyone the absence of a sensible Government industrial relations policy. It was an abuse of the Social Services Act, which is an Act designed to assist people.

The Social Services Amendment Bill proposes to extend to the families of unionists the penalties involved in the existing legislation. The wives, and indirectly the children, of those involved in or affected by industrial disputes in which the members' unions are involved will now no longer be able to claim the unemployment benefit; they will be able to claim the special benefit only in cases of what the Bill describes as extreme hardship.

The Minister has told us in his second reading speech that, because of the operation of the social security system as it now stands, union members are largely insulated from the effects of their actions when they strike. This is simply not true. Families are very seriously affected when members choose to begin and prolong an industrial dispute. Their living standards inevitably drop because of the pay lost and as each day goes by that loss becomes greater.

Strikers in this country do not choose industrial action lightly. They are aware of the problems that they will face when they go on strike. The social services that their spouses have been able to qualify for have been minimal. They are certainly not an insulation against the loss of regular wages and salary. The wives who were able to claim unemployment benefit had to pass the work test. They had to go through the week's delay involved. They had to demonstrate that they were able and capable of taking part in paid work. They had to qualify in the same way as any other unemployed person to get assistance. They are now to be penalised because they happen to be married to someone who is involved in an industrial dispute.

The 1979 legislation which extended the ambit of restricting the unemployment benefit for unionists was bad enough. This, however, is even worse. It is just another step in the Government's battle against the trade unionists of this country, in the Government's battle to restrict trade unionists from using the right to strike, a right which is only absent in totalitarian governments of the Right and the Left throughout the world. I believe that it is hard to understand how a government whose members are paid at the level they are and whose Ministers are paid at the level they are can say to the family of a unionist who is indirectly involved in a dispute that it cannot receive the minimal payment of the single unemployment benefit plus any assistance it may get on top of that because of children. As I said, it is part of the war against the trade union movement. However, to extend that war to the wives and children of trade unionists is ludicrous and discriminatory. We utterly oppose that provision in the legislation.

That provision is also being extended to the families of people who failed the work test or had their unemployment benefit withdrawn for the mandatory six to 12 weeks, a penalty which was also initiated by this Government. The latest figures show that work test failures accounted for only 1.6 per cent of the terminations of unemployment benefit. This is not a major social problem in this country; it is not a major problem for the Department of Social Security. The unemployed are already penalised by having their benefits postponed. Each month there are just over 1,000 postponements of benefits. Three-quarters of the persons affected have no dependants. So we are probably talking about a maximum of about 300 families who have had their unemployment benefit stopped or refused because they were allegedly dismissed for misconduct, were voluntarily unemployed or had failed the work test.

I believe we can make two initial comments about this. The first is that those families could be victims of some of the suspect primary decision-making processes which we know exist in the Department of Social Security and in any other large departments. In 1979-80 half of the appeals against the decisions of the Department which were finalised finished up in favour of the persons appealing, the majority of whom were unemployment beneficiaries or applicants for unemployment benefit. Almost one-third of the appeals were conceded by the Department as departmental error even before going to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. Furthermore, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has given decisions in some cases to appellants rejected by both the Department and the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. A wrong decision-one not taking in or accepting all the facts-can be made in an office of the Department of Social Security. Under this provision a whole family can be financially crippled because neither spouse will be allowed to receive unemployment benefit or special benefit. This kind of legislation is heavy-handed, it is unwarranted and it inevitably hits the innocent. It does not hit those who can work the system. It does not hit the smarties who know how to use the system. It will also affect voluntary agencies inevitably because these people seek help from voluntary agencies, such as the Salvation Army and St Vincent de Paul. They are run by people who know what will happen; they are run by people who protest as much as anyone about this sort of provision.

The second point I wish to make is that the penalties for being voluntarily unemployed, failing the work test or being dismissed are already very harsh. Single unemployed persons can lose up to $600 when their unemployment benefit is postponed and married unemployed can lose over $1,000. We are penalising people from $600 to $1,000 in this situation where they fail to comply with the regulations of the Department of Social Security. Recently a 24-year-old man was fined $500 for having knocked down and killed a child while under the influence of alcohol. This was his third conviction. In 1978 when the maximum fine for drink-driving was $400, nearly two-thirds of the drink-driving convictions were between $100 and $200. In 1979, when the penalties were raised, four-fifths of drivers convicted for drunkenness were given fines below $500. Surely these are crimes against society. Surely these are crimes that deserve penalties. But these penalties are completely out of proportion to the penalties which are applied to people who fail to comply with the regulations of the Department of Social Security and therefore have their benefits removed for six weeks to 12 weeks.

It is totally out of proportion to treat people who it is alleged voluntarily leave a job or leave because of misconduct as more serious and deserving heavier penalties than drunken drivers with recorded offences. It is absolutely ludicrous to penalise on top of that their wives and children who have, and certainly usually have, no effect on their feckless or irresponsible behaviour, if that is what the Government wants to call it. It is getting at the people the Government is aiming to get at through their wives and children. This is ridiculous and harsh. No Parliament should tolerate the passage of this sort of legislation.

We feel so strongly about this that we believe we should wipe clauses 18 and 21 out of this legislation. We think it is outrageous in the extreme for the Government to say 'If you do this we then will not pay the unemployment benefit increases to the single unemployed' and to try to blackmail people in this Parliament who are taking a responsible attitude to this legislation by suggesting that we may deprive someone else. This part of the legislation should be excised. The Government should accept the legislation with this excision. It should accept that it was wrong and that it should not act in a discriminatory way.

The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) said in another place that people would be able to get special benefit in cases of extreme hardship. There is no departmental definition of 'extreme hardship', but it is probably related to the provisions for immediate hardship, which are roughly defined in the Department's manual of instructions on unemployment, sickness and special benefit. The manual states that persons may claim special benefit if a person has no work and no money. One cannot get much greater hardship than that. The manual points out that provided the applicant has a reasonable explanation for the lack of funds, it may be expected that hardship exists. The test of 'reasonable' is the same as the test of reasonable in the steps taken to obtain work and so on. It is never spelled out so that people can understand the position. It is always the Director-General of Social Security or one of his delegates who makes the decision about what is reasonable.

We are informed by the Deparment that if there is less than the equivalent of a week's special benefit in the house-that is now $58.10 plus allowances if there are children-an applicant probably would be eligible for special benefit. It is far from clear that the possession of $50 or $60 which may be owned in rent or food bills will not exclude the spouse of a person work-tested off unemployment benefit or in an industrial dispute from waiting for an additional week for financial relief. That is an extreme hardship. There seems to be a definition of hardship which is rather more generous; that if there is less than two weeks special or unemployment benefit in the household then the applicant is deemed to be in hardship and eligible for special benefit. But this refers to extreme hardship.

All the instructions indicate that a person must exhaust all his funds before the special benefit is paid. There can be no right to payment until the applicant is almost demonstrably out of money. We know what will happen in those circumstances. These people will be forced to seek assistance from their relatives, where they can, from their friends, where they can, and from the voluntary agencies to try to get emergency relief where there are such agencies. The effect on some agencies can be gauged by the effect on the Salvation Army in Victoria, which had to close down at the time of the Latrobe Valley industrial dispute some time ago. There is no way that this legislation can be justified. There is no way that this Parliament should pass legislation which tries to get at-as the Government seems to do-the guilty through the innocent. For this reason we put a section in the second reading amendment expressing our disapproval and, we hope, the Senate's disapproval of this legislation. At a later time we will oppose the clauses which provide for this harsh legislation.

We then come to the matter of family allowances, which were introduced by the present Government with a great fanfare. They were a substitute for the old child endowment which had become meaningless because of inflation over the years and the failure to increase the allowance. They were a substitute also for the rebate for dependent children in the taxation system. They were said to be, and I believe they are, a recognition of the fact that it costs money to bring up children and that there are costs involved with parenthood. During the last election campaign the Government and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in particular promised quite specifically late in the campaign that the increased oil revenues, which the Government said were then flowing in, would be used to help Australian families. The implication at the time was-there was no contradiction-that they would be used to increase the family allowances for Australian families, which had not been increased since they were introduced, despite roughly a 50 per cent inflation rate since then. In this same election campaign and in repeated speeches both inside and outside this Parliament the Prime Minister and his Ministers have said over and over again that they wish to direct funds to those in most need. In this Budget the Government has increased family allowances for those with three or more children.

I do not deny that those with three or more children deserve an increase in their family allowances. I do not begrudge that increase for one moment, nor would I oppose it. But the simple fact of the matter is that those families compose about a quarter of all Australian families. There are many more poor families with one or two children than there are with three or more children, even though the proportion of poor families in the large family group may be higher. This provision in the legislation gives 76 per cent of Australian families nothing. For about the same percentage of pensioner families in this country who have one or two children, this legislation provides nothing. When the Government introduced family allowances in 1976 the Prime Minister announced that it was the greatest advance in social services since federation. I remember that the present Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) was a bit more circumspect about it and she said that it was the greatest change in the decade. It was pointed out by speaker after speaker that it was a recognition of the costs of parenthood. It was pointed out on the Opposition side, which welcomed the change, that unless the allowances were increased each year to cope with inflation we would end up with the situation we have-of their value being eroded by some 50 per cent.

When the Government made the changes in this Budget-changes which are legislated for in this legislation-it said that it was part of a proposal to increase payments to those in greatest need. Not everyone agrees. Certainly no one on this side of the House agrees, and government members do not agree. Mr Ross McLean, a member of the House of Representatives, who is known to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), had this to say:

This money is distributed universally; that is, on the basis of a certain specified contingency-the number of children in a family-and not on the basis of whether a family is in a situation of financial need. The trouble with this approach is that millionaires' families and high income families, such as those of members of this Parliament if they have three or more children, will get help while low income families with two children or less will get nothing extra. I cannot see the equity in that.
I agree with Mr McLean. I cannot see the equity in that. Mr McLean continued:

It means that those families in real need are not being specifically targeted for assistance. Low income families with three or more children will certainly benefit from this initiative, and that is highly commendable, but they will benefit accidentally rather than as a result of deliberate government policy directed towards the needy.

We must get to the stage in this country where we target the needy and where we aim our policies at the needy. If the Government wishes to introduce a universal benefit like this and if it were government policy to do so, then it is up to the Government to make sure that t'e universal payment increases in line wit' inflation. If it wishes to take an alternative approach, I suggest an alternative approach would be that of the Australian Labor Party before the last election, to target on those families which have low incomes and large numbers of children and direct the family income supplement to them.

As the Government wishes to persist with a universal benefit of this type, we believe that we should point out that it is not being honest with the people in the community, that it is not keeping up to the promises that it made when it introduced the family allowances and that it should therefore be requested by this House, in line with its own policy to increase those benefits to all families in the community. If it did so, if the family allowances had been indexed after their introduction, a family with one child would now get an extra $9.30 a month; a family with two children would now get an extra $22.37 a month; a family with three children would now get $25.07 a month; a family with four children would get $27.77 a month; and a family with five children would get $30.82 extra a month. That is how much these people have fallen behind due to the failure of the Government to continue with its stated policy of 1976, when these allowances were introduced, to assist those with families. It is for this reason that we include that item in the second reading amendment that I shall move.

I then move on to a couple of the less controversial parts of the legislation. The first is the amendment to bring wives' pensions of those who live overseas into line with age and invalid applications. In other words, they will need to make their applications in this country. We believe this is fair and brings it into line with the rest of the legislation, but there is still what I believe is an unfortunate anomaly for those Australian pensioners living overseas. Bearing in mind that we have a policy of portability of pensions, despite the opposition to it by some Government supporters, we should treat people who live overseas equally. The situation is that if a woman qualifies for a wife's pension under our legislation, she is paid that pension. She has been granted it in keeping with our legislation but if her husband dies, she must return to Australia and at great expense apply for the widow's pension; otherwise she is completely dumped by the Australian social security system at the very time her husband dies and at the very time she may need help. I can see no justification for this situation. I believe it is an anomaly which should be changed and I believe the Minister should consider seriously having his Department look at this anomaly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree.

—I thank the Minister. The matter of providing the double orphans' pension for refugee children certainly has no opposition from this side of the House. We understand the Minister's difficulty with the drafting mistake and his attempts to correct that mistake. We are sure he will correct it as soon as possible but, as I said initially, that is typical of the problems which arise when the Government introduces legislation which has not been thought through. In general, the Opposition would want to see this legislation passed because we want to see the extra family allowances granted and we want to see the single unemployed receive their increase in the unemployment benefit. We would like to see increases in the unemployment benefit to those under 18 years. We would like to see an extension of the family allowance system to provide for those families which are in need. We certainly have no reason to object to the other provisions in the legislation. But I repeat that we do have considerable opposition to clauses 18 and 21-clauses which discriminate against the spouses of unemployed people and the spouses of those people who have lost their unemployment benefit through other circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: These clauses are not essential to this legislation. They certainly have no real effect on the Budget. There is no attempt made to suggest how much these measures will save the public purse. There is no attempt able to be made because I do not believe the Government could even make a close guestimate at what it is trying to save. The basic aim of the exercise is to attack the trade union movement, to try to use the Social Services Act to prevent people from taking industrial action when they feel that they need to, action that they never take lightly.

I point out that the contentious areas provided for in clauses 18 and 21 were so peripheral to the Government and to the Government's Budget that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) did not even bother to mention these proposals in his Budget Speech on 18 August. There is no reason for this Bill to stand or fall on the result of these two clauses. We find the principle involved in these two clauses so offensive that we will certainly oppose them. We certainly believe that the situation in the Senate is that they will be opposed, they will be defeated, a request will be made that they should go back to the House of Representatives. We urge the Government not to be bloody-minded, not to attempt blackmail, but to accept the view not only of the Senate-the view of the Opposition particularly in this place-but also to accept the view of everyone who has commented on these provisions, everyone who has knowledge in the area of industrial relations, in the area of social security and in the area of social welfare that these clauses should be struck out of this legislation. Then there will be no difficulty for the Government in getting its Bill through, no difficulty in paying benefits after next Sunday to the single unemployed over 18, no difficulty in fact with all those other provisions in the legislation.

An amendment has been circulated in my name. It sets out six points on which we believe the Senate should express an opinion as to how this legislation can be improved. We hope that the Government acts reasonably in this matter and realises the strength of conviction of the people who oppose those clauses that we find offensive. I move:
At end of motion, add '', but the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill should be re-drafted to provide for-
(1) the removal of the discrimination against tenants in government housing;
(2) the removal of the discrimination against the adult unemployed without dependants;
(3) an increase in the unemployment benefit for the under 18 unemployed;
(4) the inclusion of the first and second children in the provision of increased family allowances in line with those for third and later children;
(5) the removal of the provision discriminating against the spouses of union members affected by industrial disputes, and
(6) the removal of discrimination against the spouses of unemployed persons who fail the work test''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government would indeed like to see this legislation dealt with by the Senate today because, as Senator Grimes has indicated, the increase in the rate of the unemployment benefit payable to those persons aged 18 years and over without dependants is to commence from 1 November which, as Senator Grimes has already said, is in a few days' time. I am very sorry that this legislation has been introduced so late in this session but it was not deliberate, as Senator Grimes has said. Indeed, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) has been very clear on this. He has gone to great pains to explain why the legislation was delayed. He explained that the need as seen by the Government to strengthen the means test criteria relating to eligibility for the pension had proved far more complicated than was envisaged. As a result the introduction of this legislation was delayed, but not deliberately, as I said. For Senator Grimes to say it was deliberately delayed because the Government wanted the Parliament ro rise earlier than had been planned really has nothing to do with this matter. It does not matter when the Parliament rises. The Government needs this legislation passed by 1 November.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government cannot support Senator Grimes's suggestions to separate the provisions in the Bill or that there be a request to the House of Representatives for amendment. If either of those courses were adopted in this chamber today the Bill would have to go back to the House of Representatives and the Government would propose to return the Bill today to the House of Representatives. But it is interesting to note the number of honourable senators who have put their names on the speaking list. There are eight of us. If we all intend to take the time that we are allowed to take I think it would be clear to everyone that the Bill would not be able to be returned today to the House of Representatives. I have decided because of the time restriction not to speak any longer on this legislation. As a matter of fact, I am rather disappointed because I believe the legislation is extremely good. But I am willing to forgo my speaking time in the hope that there will be some co-operation between the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. I am not asking for co-operation with the Government. I am asking for co-operation with those over 18-year-olds, who Senator Grimes has--

TALK.START.PARA: —Blackmail!

—Senator Grimes did not hear what I said earlier. He was talking with someone else, and that is quite legitimate, but I did say that I do not agree with him at all that it was deliberately delayed. It is not blackmail. As I said earlier in my speech, Senator Chaney explained why the Bill was delayed. I have apologised for this delay.
—Why?

—I have already gone through all that. I could go through it again but if the honourable senator reads Hansard he will find why I have spoken in the way that I have. I am very happy just to indicate my full support for the legislation that is before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rather taken back. It is the first time I have followed Senator Walters in debate when she has spoken for two or three minutes. I had expected when she rose to speak that she would make a reasonable attempt to say something about her case but I suppose we can be thankful for some of the mercies that come our way occasionally.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon we are debating the Social Services Amendment Bill which attempts to bring into legislative form those initiatives which were outlined in the recent Budget. Talking about the Budget, it is quite remarkable that it is now late October and only four or five people have actually spoken on what we call the debate on the Budget Papers. I can recall one year, I think it was 1978, when, after the Budget was introduced, it was noticed that there was still one speaker on the Government side in continuation on the previous Budget papers. It seems as though we will have the same thing this year. Although we have been able to debate certain parts of the measures contained in the Budget as the legislation has come through to us, we have not been able to speak on the Budget as a whole because the Government does not seem to be able to arrange its timetable satisfactorily. This afternoon my colleagues and I on this side will make some comments in relation to those matters of social security contained in the Budget because they are oulined in the amendment Bill that we have before us now.

When the Budget was brought before us and we looked at the proposed social service legislation we saw little good news. There was some good news but not a great deal. I had hoped that the Government would have taken this opportunity, in a non-election year, to redress some of the injustices that exist in the social welfare area in Australia. I was disappointed, however, to see that some provisions concerning unemployment and sickness benefits were not included in the Budget. Having looked at the Budget, I wondered whether I was wrong and whether we would have had a better deal had it been an election year. The Budget was disappointing to me and to many people in the community who are dependent upon social security for their livelihood because so much was left undone. I should like to outline some of the things that were left undone and then go on to talk about some of the aspects that are contained in the legislation before us.

Many of us, quite rightly, meet pensioner groups to hear what they have to say. Many of us meet pensioners individually in the course of our duties as senators. When we do meet them, we find that the more militant pensioners are quite vocal about what they believe the Government should provide. I think they are quite rightfully vocal. If they are not vocal about their rights there will probably be very few people in the community who will support them. One of the difficulties is that many people in the community do not realise the problems of pensioners, particularly age pensioners, until they become pensioners themselves. I recently attended a meeting of pensioners in Brisbane where pensioners were outlining some of the demands, as they call them, or requests that they had of the Government. I was very pleased to see at that meeting a fairly youthful official from a trade union group. He had come to that meeting to listen to what these people had to say and perhaps even to give them a little bit of advice if that was warranted. He came to the meeting because he said it was quite wrong for him as a trade union official not to be interested in pensioner matters or matters of social welfare because so many of his members would eventually become dependent on social welfare. He thought the trade union should have some input into the area. I thought that was a refreshing attitude.

When we hear of the concerns of these people we realise that many of them feel that they have been let down. I should like to mention a few of these areas where nothing has been done. Perhaps we can have a look at these areas in future years. I refer firstly to the pensioners who are aged 70 and over. I can remember before the 1972 election that both major parties promised that they would ease the means test for certain pensioner age groups. Certainly there was a difference between the two parties about how they would do it, but prior to 1972 there was general agreement that whoever won the 1972 election would take some steps to ease the means test. In fact the Australian Labor Party won that election and it first freed the means test for people aged 75 and over. Later the age limit was reduced to aged 70 and over. I might use the words 'means test' from here on but I probably mean the income test, because that is what applies now. To talk about a free of means test or a free of income test pension for those people aged 70 and over is now a myth because this Government changed the policy in relation to these people and froze the amount of pension that a person could get free of income test.

Many people retired believing that they would be able to obtain a free means test pension when they were aged 70, and they ordered their life accordingly. Now they find that they are not in that position. The people I feel particularly unhappy about in this regard are not those who are aged 70 and over but those up in their eighties and nineties who cannot quite understand why suddenly their standard of living is dropping because the purchasing power of their free of means test pension is decreasing as inflation is increasing. They are falling further and further behind, and they cannot quite understand why this is happening. I think this is something that we must look at. I asked the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) earlier this year how much it would cost to restore a full pension to these people. It seems to me that it is an amount of money that we could have a look at quite readily.

Secondly, I should like to mention the fringe benefits for these people in the 70 age group and over. Surely in this age group we could consider giving them a pensioner health benefit card. I believe that if we gave them this card we would not have half the problems that we seem to be facing with people putting money into non-interest bearing accounts. When pensioners talk about their fringe benefits, the thing that dwells mostly on their minds is the pensioner health benefit card. Certainly there are other things that concern them, such as their rail and rate concessions, but the pensioner health benefit card is something that they particularly look forward to having. As the Minister has pointed out in this place, probably some people are arranging their financial circumstances in such a way as to be a disadvantage to them, but they are doing this so that they can get fringe benefits. If we gave them the pensioner health benefit card I believe a lot fewer people would be arranging their financial situation to their disadvantage.

Thirdly, I mention a matter which does not receive much consideration, but which I believe is an injustice to people who are age pensioners. I have mentioned this matter to the Minister for Social Security. He has not been convinced, and I am sure that he will not be convinced this afternoon. Nevertheless, I shall mention it in the hope that by the process of mentioning it on a number of occasions eventually he will see the injustice in it. I refer to the fact that Service pensioners are able to discount a certain amount of their disability pension for income test purposes. At present they can discount 50 per cent. When legislation goes through in this session they will be able to discount 60 per cent of their disability pension for income test purposes. Age pensioners cannot do so.

The argument which has been presented to me is that ex-servicemen should be able to have something extra to provide for their having fought for their country and for having gone overseas and been members of the fighting forces. Certainly that is so, because servicemen are able to apply for service pensions when they are aged 60 years. As well as that they are able to discount any part of a disability pension which they might have. A disability pension does not have to come to from war service. It may have been granted for a disability received whilst the serviceman was in Australia. There are a number of aged pensioners who did not go overseas but who incurred a disability whilst in Australia and therefore obtained a disability pension. They cannot discount that disability pension but have to count all of it for income test purposes. I believe that we should look at this matter to make sure that the aged pensioner who is receiving a disability pension for service purposes is able to discount that pension in the same way as the person who receives a pension through the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

I mention a fourth area in which nothing has been done where pensioners believe they have been let down. There is no change in this Budget to the income level for the income test for pensioners. The permissible income for a single person remains at $20 a week and for a married couple remains at $34.50. If they exceed either of these limits, they incur some loss of pension. If the amounts of $20 and $34.50 had been increased in line with rises in the consumer price index that $20 would now be about $34-which is quite a difference-and the $34.50 would now be about $50 . It seems to me that it would be more equitable for pensioners if this were increased especially considering the current high rates of interest that these people might earn on money invested.

Finally, in reference to the areas that have not been included in either the Budget or the legislation I mention a matter about which pensioners on a lot of occasions have complained to me. They have complained that the cost of living seems to be catching up with them even though their pensions are increased in line with the consumer price index. If we we look at some of the indices which are much more important for pensioners, especially the food index, we find that they are increasing at a greater rate than the consumer price index. Perhaps the consumer price index is not the best index that we could have for determining increases in pensions in order to keep them at a purchasing power the same as they had before inflation took its effect.

One matter that Senator Grimes mentioned is particularly important. I suppose that concerns another thing that was not done in the Budget, although it was indicated that that might be done then. That matter concerned the Government's giving a clear indication of what was happening in relation to the clamp down on people holding money in non-interest bearing accounts. There was something in the second reading speech of the Minister, though this did not really go far enough because pensioners are still apprehensive about what might be coming next year. I believe that there are a few things that the Minister should do. First of all, he should increase the ridiculously low permissable weekly income of $20 a week for single pensioners and $34.50 a week for married pensioners. As well as that, he should bring down the legislation that he intends to bring down or he should announce a total abandonment of it so that pensioners will not remain apprehensive as to what might happen in this area.

In the Budget and certainly in the social services legislation there is some indication of increases in supplementary assistance. Supplementary assistance will increase by $3 up to a mapimum of $8. This is some relief but it is still pitifully small. If the $5 we presently have had been increased in line with the consumer price index, it would be so close to $10 that it would not matter. If the increases had been made, that $10 would be available to everybody. But the $8 is not going to be made available to everybody. Apparently the Government does not believe in making adjustments to some of the benefits in line with the consumer price index.

That $3 is not available for all. It will be available only to those living in non-government housing. Those who are in government housing will not receive any increase but will stay on the $5 a week, if they are receiving the maximum of $5 a week at the moment. After the legislation comes into effect, they will not be able to receive the full amount. They will not be able to receive any amount if they move into non-government housing after a certain date. Those who do receive the full $8 will have to be paying $26 a week for their shelter whether it be housing, board or lodging or something like that. I guess that it is not possible to find housing for less than $26 a week so those who are paying rent will probably receive the full amount. It must be remembered that not everybody will receive the extra $3 a week. I do not believe that this is the real answer to the problem. The only way that we will really get to the bottom of the problem is to have a dramatic increase in the amount available for welfare housing. That would provide some relief for those people faced with exhorbitant rents.

At this stage, I mention that earlier this session I was given some misinformation by the Minister. I hope in his reply on this debate that he might indicate that I was given some misinformation. I seemed to ask a rather long question on 9 September. I do not like to ask long questions but I asked my original question and then a supplementary question, which I admit is unusual for me. My question concerned the first dollar of income that a person had if that person were receiving supplementary assistance. It had been indicated that that person would lose 50c out of that first dollar. In fact, in the supplementary question I said:

The Budget Papers mention that there will be a loss of $1 for every $2 of other income, which I suppose is the same as saying it is a rate of 50c in the dollar. At the moment a person who has $1 of extra income does not lose any part of the supplementary assistance.
That is the situation at the moment. I asked:
Does it actually mean that from February next year a person who has $1 of extra income will lose 50c out of that first dollar?
Senator Chaney gave me a very succinct answer by saying 'Yes'. I notice that the second reading speech, amongst other things, said:
. . . $1 of assistance is withdrawn for every $1 of income in excess of a $1 'free area' for single pensioners and $1 for every $2 above the first $2 for pensioner couples.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the present test, Senator.
—Maybe that is the present test. Perhaps the Minister will be able to elucidate later.
—Rather than waste time, I think the position I outlined to you in that answer is right. The answer is correct.
—I apologise if I misread the second reading speech. I will look at it again later on. I will take the Minister's suggestion on board.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the matter of unemployment benefit. One area that is disappointing here is that there has been no increase for those who are less than 18 years of age. The amount that is available to them has remained at a miserly $36 a week. I say 'miserly' because the amount has not been increased since this Government has been in power. It is the same amount as was available in 1975 when the Whitlam Government was in power. It seems the Government has abandoned this area altogether or it has abandoned this group of people under 18 years of age. It may be that the Government has the philosophy that the family should care for these people. But I ask: What if the family is in poor circumstances? What if the person does not for some genuine reason wish to live at home, or cannot? What about those in rural areas, where employment prospects are poor, who decide to go to some other rural area or perhaps to the city to seek work? How is he or she to do that on $36 a week? This anomaly must be looked at because there are significant problems for young people who are dependent upon that payment of $36 a week.

It is not as though in Australia this is a small problem. Youth unemployment is a massive problem. Some recent figures that I was able to find show that, of the 15 to 19-year-old group, almost 100,000 are unemployed. That represents about 15 per cent of the members of that age group. The figures are perhaps even more telling when we look at the breakdown. About 12 per cent of the males in that age group are unemployed but about 18 per cent of the females are unemployed. Thus, about one in five of all girls in the age group lacks employment. This is a large problem and one that is producing some fairly severe social effects.

I noticed in the Courier Mail of 22 October a headline which read: 'Boredom with lack of work led to robbery'. I would like to quote some parts of this rather long article to indicate what I mean. It states:
Two young women, well educated, from good homes, but bored and depressed by unemployment, robbed a 70-year-old taxi driver at knife-point, the Criminal Court heard yesterday.
Mr Justice Sheahan described the robbery as 'dangerous and stupid'. Two respectable girls had embarked on an armed robbery with a knife.
The article went on to describe what had happened, how the girls were brought before the court, where they had been living and so on. Then it stated:
Mr Justice Sheahan said the case was most unusual . . .
He felt strongly that the girls' robbery motive was a mixture of boredom, frustration and depression and being unemployed and a shortage of ready cash.

This is the sort of situation that we face when we have a large group of unemployed, in that age group especially. If as a society, we ensure that they will be short of cash by paying them only $36 a week when they are actually looking for work we are looking for trouble. It seems to me that in regard to this group the Government has its head in the sand. It is time the Government was given a push to bring it back to reality.

Another aspect which was mentioned by the Opposition's spokesman in this field, Senator Grimes, is the way in which the Government has failed to honour its responsibilities in regard to family allowances. The Bill allows for an increase in family allowances for the third, fourth and subsequent children of a family. That is fine. These people definitely do need an allowance. But families with one or two children have been left out in the cold. I remember well that when the family allowance system was brought down in this Parliament great play was made of the fact that it was one of the major advances in social welfare in this country. Probably it was, but at the time a trade-off was required. Taxpayers used to be able to claim deductions for their children. Those deductions were taken away. The amount that was spent on family allowances that year equalled exactly the amount that was saved by removing taxation deductions for children.

I recall that when I mentioned that fact a former senator, Sir Reginald Wright, who was sitting on one of the front benches opposite, interjected in his gruff but very perceptive way: 'Ah yes, that is correct but you must remember that the redistribution will be much better'. It may have been but the point I would like to make is that if those tax deductions had remained we would have expected them to be indexed in the normal way. If they had not been there would have been an outcry from the taxpayers. However, now that they have been subsumed in family allowances they have not been indexed. They should be so that the Government can keep itself honest in regard to trading one for another.

In addition, we must remember that many people are heavily dependent on family allowances. It is unfair that those with only one or two children should be denied an increase. As an indication of how some people are dependent on family allowances, I would like to read part of an article which appeared in today's Sydney Morning Herald. The article states:

A mother of six who was put on a bond yesterday in Blacktown Court of Petty Sessions for stealing goods worth $2.04 said later she only did it because she was tired of always having to ask for charity.
The article continues:
Mrs . . . who is separated from her husband, said she received a pension worth $232 a fortnight but it was not enough to keep her family.

The article is accompanied by a picture of the mother with five of her six children. Certainly, $232 is not much with which to look after one adult and six children. This sort of person does depend on family allowances very heavily. We should ensure that such allowances are indexed.

Finally, I would like to mention the aspect of the legislation that concerns me most. I refer to the decision in the Budget to prevent the payment of unemployment benefit to the spouses of people who are engaged in industrial action, who have been refused unemployment benefit or who have had such benefit cancelled or postponed.

In Brisbane at the moment some women are actually drawing a benefit because their spouses have not been able to obtain a benefit due to some other provision in the Social Services Act. One of the plants in Brisbane has been idle because it has not been able to get parts. There is in Victoria a dispute involving a union which also has members in the Brisbane plant. Therefore, those in Brisbane who have been laid off have not been able to get unemployment benefit; but at least their wives and children have been able to do so. Those wives and children did not have anything to do with what went on down in Victoria, yet under this type of legislation they will not be able to draw such a benefit. That seems to be an old fashioned measure which belongs to the Dark Ages-certainly not the type of democracy in which we live. If the Government wants to do something in regard to industrial relations to force people to stay at work and has a mandate to do so it surely should do so by way of industrial relations legislation, not social security legislation which, as the name implies, is intended to promote the welfare and well-being of people in the community. That as a proposal that the Opposition will be trying to remove because it believes that it is alien to social security legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) will be relieved to hear that the majority of the 24 clauses in the Social Services Amendment Bill are uncontroversial so far as the Australian Democrats are concerned-which is not to say that they are beyond criticism, because they are not. In the main, the Bill is an unexceptionable one. It provides for some increases in some pensions and benefits, although I would argue with the statement made by the Minister in his second reading speech that it embodies improvements in the field of social service pensions and benefits-unless he defines an improvement as something which manages to stop some recipients from finally tumbling into the realm of total and abject poverty. I do not question for a moment either that this Bill reflects the priority given by the Government to ensuring that assistance is provided to high need groups, as the Minister asserted in his speech.

SPEECH.PARA: What I do question is the morality of defining groups in the community as either needy or not needy and then dividing the group labelled 'needy' into two other groups, one marked 'needy-no extra assistance provided' and the other marked 'very needy-some extra assistance provided'. The proposed amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time indicates clearly the groups that we consider are discriminated against.
