They include: Some tenants of government housing; the adult unemployed without dependants; unemployed people under the age of 18 years; first and second children in some families-all first and second children have not been given an increase, but obviously some are more in need of an increase than others; the spouses of union members affected by industrial disputes; and the spouses of unemployed persons who fail the work test and who, therefore, are disqualified from gaining the unemployment benefit.

To us the present situation really is not good enough. Either there are needy people in the community, all of whom warrant government assistance, or there are not. If a goverment does define one or more groups in the community as needy, it should do adl within its power to provide all those groups with enough assistance to lift them out of that category. A lot of people in Australia believe that any government which can budget for a surplus of $1,500m can afford to be a little more generous to the poor. A great many people in Australia too wish that the present Government would be as generous and as sympathetic to the plight of the needy in the community as it is to the demands of the mining companies or the big multinationals, many of whose industrial relations and pricing policies are contributing to the hardships experienced by ordinary Australians. All that means, of course-to come back to the Minister's original statement-is that it is a matter of priorities. Clearly this Government's commitment to the needy is low in comparison with its commitment to things such as the oil companies, for example, or perhaps more appropriately at the moment the banking institutions.

There is no point in quibbling about this issue. We know where this Government stands on the matter. I think most people know where the Australian Democrats stand on the matter. The proposed amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time, which we support, makes that quite clear, as do our policies. Our policies have done so since the party was formed in 1977. It is our firm belief that a country allegedly as prosperous and developed as Australia should not force anyone, should not allow anyone, to live below the poverty line. Yet millions of people in this country are doing just that. Inevitably, they are the most vulnerable, the most susceptible, the least powerful members of the community, that is, children, supporting parents, pensioners and the unemployed-the very people for whom a truly compassionate government should and would show the greatest of concern.

I do not want to spend a great deal of time arguing about how much money the Government could have poured into its welfare system. That is a fairly futile activity at the best of times. It is enough to say that more could be done and more should be done-in fact, that much more could be done and much more should be done. It is enough to say that the additional assistance given to pensioners, supporting parents, the children of large families, refugee children and the unemployed over the age of 18 years, does not go far enough, but it is better than nothing. In fact, that is all that can be said of this Bill. If that is damning the Bill with faint praise, I am afraid that that is about all the Bill deserves.

That brings me to the clauses of the Bill of which I am critical-the ones which seem to me to have no redeeming features; the ones which should not have been included in this Bill in the first place as they have more to do with industrial relations than they have to do with welfare, as Senator Colston has already pointed out. Those clauses are clauses 18 and 21. They are clauses about which I, apparently like Senator Grimes, have had more frantic phone calls from individuals and organisations in the last few days than I can remember having received about any single issue for a long time. Clauses 18 to 21 are the ones which the Government is putting forward as its nomination for the 'blame the victim' award. They are clauses which wreak a punishment on people who have committed no crime and who are not even accessories to a crime. They are the clauses which deny the unemployment benefit to the spouse of a person engaged in industrial action and which deny special benefits to persons ineligible to receive the unemployment benefits under certain circumstances. The Minister had this to say in his second reading speech:

The present legislation permits a situation where trade unions can choose to strike knowing that through the operation of the social security system their members will be largely insulated from the effect of their actions. The Australian public for its part is attacked from two directions. First, it has to bear the personal disruptions, inconveniences and associated costs brought about by the strike. In addition, it is then called upon to meet the cost of providing income support for the families of those involved in that industrial action.

Having read that, one is forced to wonder just how aware members of the present Government are when it comes to such mundane matters as the day-to-day needs of families on low or limited incomes; of how far money goes and where it goes in such families; of the sorts of economic pressures those families live under; of just what it is like to try to live on the unemployment benefit or special benefits, even for a limited time. How can anyone seriously make statements like those I just read out? How can anyone believe that unemployment benefits can largely, or even partially, insulate strikers from the effect of their actions?

How can anyone believe that it is wrong or immoral for a government to provide income support for the families of people involved in industrial action when those families had no say in the decision to strike? It might be, of course, that the Minister, the Government or a bureaucrat is assuming that the situation which applied in Whyalla some years ago should apply in all strike actions; that is, that the wives of strikers should withhold their marital favours, for want of a better expression, until the men go back to work. How can anyone justify making innocent women and children pay twice over for actions which are not of their making? This proposal is worthy of a Shylock at his very worst. If this Government cannot handle the unions in this country other than by taking its pound of flesh, with a good helping of blood, and tears, if not sweat, tossed in from the families of those concerned, it ought to hand the reins over to someone who can.

The Government argues as well-this was stated in the Minister's second reading speech also-that some women in one-industry towns apply for the unemployment benefit when their husbands are out on strike but 'have no intention of joining the workforce'. One is forced to ask the question, first of all: Why penalise everybody because of special cases applying in one-industry towns? More importantly, is the Government not aware that it is in just those places-places like Whyalla, for instance-that the situation is most parlous for the families of strikers? It is in towns like Whyalla that people are likely to have the least money in reserve to cover times of emergency. A strike is a time of emergency, particularly for the families of the people concerned.

It is no good to argue that people should not go out on strike and that if they do they should be prepared to take the consequences. That argument is fallacious on a number of counts: Firstly, the fact that some unions are irresponsible is no reason for the Government to follow suit and, secondly, denying unemployment benefits, even single unemployment benefits, to wives of strikers is punishing them and their children for something which was not their fault. If I am beginning to sound like a cracked gramophone record, I do not apologise because that is the whole problem with the clause. It is penalising innocent people for something over which they have no control, presumably in order to achieve an end that the Government cannot achieve by any other method.

The irony is that the Government is ignoring the fact that it very quickly gets back into its coffers whatever small amount of relief it pays to families in these desperate financial straits because those families spend the money almost immediately-they have to; they have no other choice; they are not likely to save it-on the necessities of life, on the food and clothing they need to survive. It is absolute rubbish to suggest that any special benefit paid by this Government will be spent on luxuries or even more ludicrous is the suggestion that it is sufficient to let families keep up with their 'normal financial responsibilities', which was the term the Minister used. It will not and it does not. What it does do, and what they are entitled to have it do, is help tide them over, in the most minimal way possible, a period of intense hardship. If it is taken away from them it will place an additional and intolerable burden on local welfare agencies, as Senator Grimes pointed out, such as the Salvation Army, the St Vincent de Paul Society and others, which are in receipt of some Federal Government funds and which are already strained to their limits. This, in itself, will be a cost to the community.

On the matter of the denial of unemployment benefit or special allowances to people 'who voluntarily and without good reason give up their job or who are dismissed through misconduct', I would like to raise the question of just who defines what is a good reason for voluntarily leaving a place of employment. Unfortunately, during yesterday's debate on the matter of public importance I was cut off, if not exactly in my prime, certainly before I had finished what I intended to say. The matter omitted was that of harassment, particularly sexual harassment, of women in the work force.

Instances have been brought to my attention, as well as to the attention of the Women's Switchboard in Adelaide, the Working Women's Centre Inc. and the South Australian Commissioner for Equal Opportunity of women who have been forced to leave their place of employment because of harassment of one sort or another which has made their working conditions absolutely intolerable. When they leave, they do not list sexual harassment by either the boss or a colleague as their reason for leaving. A more tactful, more face-saving and less embarrassing reason is given and it is likely to be a reason which does not meet the requirements as defined by some bureaucreat and hence entitle that woman to unemployment benefit or special benefit. I acknowledge, as I think previous speakers have, that there are people who abuse the system. There will always be people who abuse the system. But we are being asked today to approve two clauses that will allow the system to abuse the people-in fact, to abuse an already disadvantaged group of people. That is simply not good enough.

I and my party are prepared to accept the fact that the Government does not see its way clear at the moment to extend family allowances to first and second children, despite the fact that to me at least for a variety of reasons those children are more expensive to feed and clothe than any subsequent child. But that is the Government's decision on that matter. We are prepared to accept that when money becomes available presumably it will extend the increase in family allowances to second and, hopefully, to first children as well. I and my party are not prepared to accept that clauses 18 and 21 are necessary, either to this Bill, which they are not, or to the community generally, which they most definitely are not. They are Shylock clauses; that is all they are. The Australian Democrats intend to do whatever we can to prevent them from becoming nothing more or less than instruments of welfare harassment in an industrial relations situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Far from ensuring assistance to those in 'the highest need groups', in the words of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), some of the amendments proposed in this Bill indicate an approach to social welfare which is hardly surprising to those of us who have no illusions about the capacity of this Government to apply anything but superficial solutions to the deep-seated problems which have become such a pervasive feature in this wealthy country. How can the Minister posture about his Government's concern for Australian families when three out of four Australian families continue to receive no more in family allowances in money terms and considerably less in real terms than when this reform was introduced with great fanfare in 1976? Erosion in the value of children's allowances now means that those families with two children, and that includes 820,000 families of whom 63,000 are pensioners, are approximately $22 a month worse off than if the allowance had been indexed.

SPEECH.PARA: Why has the increased allowance been granted to larger families with no apparent concern for those on low incomes? It seems to me to be a very raskq assumption that those with more than two children are the impoverished and in most need of assistance. In the absence of evidence to back up that assumption-and I see nothing to that effect in the Minister's speech-it occurs to me that larger families in these days of more or less effective contraception may well include a fair proportion of the more affluent. We do know that at the end of June 1980 there were 162,000 pensioner and unemployed families with one or two children all living-'existing' might be a more accurate term-below the poverty line. If it were possible for the Government to find no more than an extra $124m for family allowances, surely the money could have been directed towards those in greatest need-a gesture at least towards halting their rapidly deteriorating living standards.

It is becoming very clear not only that the unemployed are in chronic financial difficulties but also that low wages and greatly impaired purchasing power are amongst the prime causes of poverty. The policies of this Government are accelerating the process to a point where it is becoming intolerable for many households. Escalating home payments, greatly increased costs of keeping a car on the road, pressure to take out private medical insurance and cruel State utility charges will inevitably lead to wage pressures as workers attempt to maintain their living standards. This piece of legislation acknowledges this by clear implication and seeks to impose the crudest imaginable sanction-withdrawal of the right to a benefit from the spouse of the worker who dares to take industrial action. The very fact that this provision appears in the Bill indicates that this Government will stop at nothing in its mindless determination to depress still further the real wages of Australian workers. Because the Government has tried everything else, intimidation of spouses and dependants is the new name of the game.

As Senator Haines has suggested, these are people who have committed no crime. I might remind the Minister that even the dependants of convicted criminals are entitled to social security benefits. About 38 per cent of Australian households are dependent upon one income and of these about two-thirds include dependent children. At least, I suppose, if the breadwinner is on strike these latter will have the family allowance between them and complete destitution, providing pension day comes at the right time. It is a wonder that the Government has not thought of stopping that too as further punishment. What a use of social security legislation! Perhaps it is not so surprising, considering the Government's lack of success with its industrial legislation. I refer to the Australian Financial Review of 14 August 1981 and to an article entitled 'ABS on strikes: who solved what' by Paul Malone. The article states:
Intervention by Federal Government officials did not lead to the settlement of one industrial dispute during 1980.

Figures released yesterday by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for the year show that 21 per cent of disputes were solved by negotiation and 7 per cent by industrial tribunals under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.
In 65 per cent of the disputes, work was resumed without negotiation.
Federal intervention has not led to the resolution of one dispute in the last five years.

There is, as most of us know, a generally acknowledged right to strike. It is concomitant with the right to bargain collectively, which was the subject of Convention No. 98 of the International Labour Organisation, a convention which has been ratified by Australia.

The appearance of this anti-worker/anti-union clause in social security legislation indicates just how little regard this Government has for international labour conventions and for its own international obligations. The Government knows well just how vulnerable the families of ordinary workers can be. Average minimum award rates for males in August this year were just on $5 an hour, a little less for females. Even where there is more than one income, the second income is likely to be a part time job, bringing in from $60 a week to $80 a week-just enough to lift the household out of poverty and, incidentally, in many cases to make it ineligible for a disadvantaged health card unless there are several children.

The capacity of most households to save is very limited. To use Frank Crean's phrase they are just one week's wage off destitution. In many cases they are just one pension cheque off destitution. In at least a third of the cases, this can be the very reason for industrial disputes amongst the employed. These are the people who, if the Government has its way, will be forced to go begging from the emergency relief agencies which are already finding that their meagre resources are stretched to capacity.

In my own State of Western Australia, the Opposition spokesman on community welfare, Mr K. J. Wilson M.L.A., was reported in the West Australian of 26 October as having said that the demand for emergency relief had increased by 65 per cent in the last financial year. As the combined policies of State and Federal governments bite into the budgets of those with low incomes, it is not uncommon for some people in Western Australia to live without electricity until they can afford to pay the bill and a reconnection fee. Some are able to get a once-off payment from a voluntary agency and then hope that they will be able to pay the next bill in two months' time.
Another article in the West Australian of 26 October quotes Mr George Smith, the director of the Christian Welfare Centre. He said:
People have given up luxuries and no longer come to us with hire purchase bills. They are battling for food, power and rent money.

These are the people whom the Government plans to penalise if they are forced to take industrial action to maintain or to try to improve their standards of living marginally. And what of those 38 per cent of workers involved in disputes in the March quarter of this year, for which we have the most recent information, who stopped work because of what the Australian Bureau of Statistics describes as managerial policies? There are countless well-documented cases of stoppages being deliberately provoked by managerial policies, especially in the mining and construction industries, which the speech of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) singled out for special mention as being a target for the proposed victimisation of workers and their families. One of the most protracted stoppages in recent years in the Pilbara was the Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd strike of 1979. Its cause and its protraction had much more to do with the stockpile of iron ore than with the intransigence of the workers.

Of course, the proposed withholding of benefits will give no heed to the rights or wrongs of any individual dispute, of any individual union or of anq individual worker. The Minister and his Government may have been seriously misled if they believe that bullying and threatening workers and their dependants are likely to be an effective way of quelling industrial unrest. Workers' spouses are more and more likely to be workers themselves, or potential or hopeful workers. It should not be assumed that they will not be ready and willing to support industrial action.

We all know that there are reactionary organisations and institutions which are dedicated to confusing the public, especially the nearest and dearest of striking workers, about individual industrial disputes. However, over the years of Australian industrial history, there have been heartening examples of workers' wives who have fully understood and thoroughly supported their husbands' industrial action. The Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd strike of 1979, to which I referred, is a case in point. The women of Mount Tom Price, Paraburdoo and Dampier organised to pool their resources and set up a co-operative. Their cohesion and support proved to be a tower of strength. Incidentally, the Tom Price co-operative is still functioning. I do not know whether the payment of the unemployment benefits on that occasion was a significant factor. I doubt it very much but I am sure that withdrawal of the benefit, as the Government now intends, would only add to the resolve of such workers and their spouses.

Inevitably there will be hardship if the Government has its way. In particular there will be hardship for those who do not necessarily have the support of the trade union movement. I refer to those who are out of the work force, who are categorised as unsatisfactory people, having failed whatever work test happened to be enforced at a particular time. I am absolutely certain that this type of action will have no discernible effect upon the number of industriad disputes. I doubt very much whether the availability of the unemployment benefit was a significant fact in the very determined support of the wives for their spouses of the Queensland coal miners last year or, in another instance, in Pinjarra, Western Australia, where the wives of striking Alcoa workers, despite being bombarded with anti-union propaganda, held a picket line while their husbands attended meetings.

By seeking to apply primitive social welfare sanctions the Government aligns itself with provocateurs. This particularly nasty section of the Bill cannot be allowed to become law but at least all workers and their families can now clearly understand the priorities of this Government and can be able more adequately to assess just how genuine are its assurances of concern for their economic and social welfare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate on a rather pessimistic note. The second reading speech encompasses 16 printed pages. Speakers in this debate, in common with that speech, have put emphasis on various categories of social security recipients. I contrast those with a very effective paper that was prepared-I think fittingly-by my deputy leader, Senator Grimes. That paper deals with the history of social security payments in Australia. We started our meagre social security payments just before World War I. Spotted action was taken by some of the States in this area with the most notable being New South Wales on child endowment. Ultimately these efforts were consolidated by the Curtin and Chifley governments during the War and post-War years.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Grimes emphasises the contrast between our attitude and that in Europe where a better system of funding was introduced. I say 'a better system' because, at the end of the Chifley era, a surcharge of, I think, 0.25 per cent was imposed on taxable income. The money collected was to go into a welfare fund. The man who brought the operation of that welfare fund to an end was the former Country Party member, Deputy Prime Minister and Treasurer, Artie Fadden. I do not think anyone needs a super brain on financial matters to visualise how much money would be in a fund of that nature after a long period of high employment.

The theme that comes through here is that people who suggest certain innovations in some area in which there has been unquestionable hardship or mixed priorities are told that the Government is limited by its Budget. The value of imposing a surcharge for a welfare payment is that the levy is based on income. As a result a process worker would not pay the same amount as a production manager. The Whitlam Government had one or two other social security initiatives in this regard on the blocks at the end of its era. The Government can always offer excuses but its Budget revenue is such that by robbing Peter to pay Paul it can placate the more vocal element. The Government has to go into the market place, as it were, every succeeding year in the compilation of the Budget and decide who will get what.

The paper produced by Senator Grimes indicates how we missed the bus. We had opportunities. A very costly inquiry was undertaken into national insurance at the beginning of World War II. That inquiry recommended that a national insurance scheme should be funded on the basis of a contribution of 1s.3d each from the employee, the employer and the Government. This scheme was put in mothballs until after World War II. Of course, a much more stable system operated in Europe during the Bismarck era. Senator Giles referred to the Government's endeavour to portray industrial disputes as the evil dragon that is affecting these things. Probably the main reason why most Western European countries have had effective and stable industrial relations is that social security payments have been self-funded and taken out of the realm of annual Budgets.

I notice that the Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee, David Connolly, in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald, referred to population trends and the ratio of those working to those who will be retired in 10 years and beyond. I do not agree with his conclusions. Whilst he did not come out with what I advocate in respect of the levy concept-the Chifley welfare levy-it is obvious that he thinks that something has to be done. It is true that people want reduced income tax. However, they also want reasonable welfare payments. I hope that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) will give me more hope than is indicated in the written word about how he will cope with the situation and provide an equitable solution. By that I mean something like the social welfare fund levy which was part of the Chifley thinking and which was sabotaged by Fadden, who only looked from one year to the next.

I would now like to deal with specifics. I read a in a certain newsletter that Elaine Darling, a member of the other place, had made a suggestion about permissible income to a Minister. I would like to draw attention to the incidence of stress in industry today. Unskilled female factory workers in their late thirties are often employed in uncongenial work. In some cases unskilled operatives in the printing industry are put on the scrap heap when the firm for which they work is unable to be awarded a tender. A woman of about 40 years of age who uses a guillotine in a biscuit factory and who has to do a lot of bending to pick up things can suffer from varicose veins. In many cases the boss looks upon such a worker as stock for the paddock when it comes to re-engaging her. Senator Grimes and Senator Coleman, with whom I have served on Estimates committees, know that the Director-General of Health and his friends had to do mental somersaults in trying to define what was meant by 85 per cent disability. We know that the pressure on women in non-craft industries is tremendous. The great tragedy is that when workers crack under the system some people say: 'They are only 38; they should be able to rehabilitate themselves'. I know of cases in Sydney where women have cracked and, following psychiatric treatment, have been told by social workers: 'You had better apply for an invalid pension'. There is no doubt that medically one could argue such a case. Some of these women say: 'I want to get back into the work force'. They are faced with a dilemma-they have to try themselves out.

A girl can work in Sydney on Saturdays and Sundays as a Totalisator Agency Board operator-Senator Giles probably would know more about female awards than I-and bring in with penalty rates about $40 for the weekend. A girl who did that as rehabilitation would be transgressing the social security regulations. It would be difficult for her to move out and rehabilitate herself. If she tried and failed after a few weeks she would have to get back on side to be eligible for an invalid pension. I believe that we would not be so locked into Budget commitments if we adopted the levy concept of funding which I am advocating. I have talked about females in receipt of invalid pensions. However, a male manual worker who experiences back injuries could seek such a pension. It is very easy for the top insurance bureaucrats who sit on their fat bums and who do only half a day's work every two days to talk about phoney compensation claims, but they do not think of the other cases where people try to get back to work. Take the case of a male manual worker with two or three children who has to put off a hernia operation for 12 months. The great tragedy is that in many of these cases the initial ailment is compounded by the higgledy-piggledy approach taken to social security.

Senator Haines and Senator Giles drew attention to the Government's belief that the man out on strike is an evil person. We hear much about the danger that such strikes pose to society. However, very few strikes these days go more than a week. One of the reasons for this is that people cannot afford to go on strike and get behind with their hire purchase payments. However, we have to look at the double standards. The crimes against society by Gale and Huxley were much greater than the crimes being committed by strikers who go out for a week and cause production to be impaired. Mr Huxley is now living on the north side of Sydney in luxury. It could be said that he paid his debt to society. He may have. But so have a lot of other people who have gone back to the bottom rung. However, the Gales and the Huxleys do not.

We can talk about the morality of society. People may occasionally transgress in respect of an extra week of eligibility for a social security payment, saying: 'He gets away with it in bigger chunks than we do'. The law has never been geared to meet that situation. Not only should the Gales and the Huxleys have done their gaol sentences for misappropriation but also all of their moneys should have been confiscated by the state. I stand by that. All of the assets of the big financiers who milk Australia should go back into welfare to help the people they swindled. It is time that we got our ethics straightened out and did not have double standards. The judge regards people who went to posh schools as great men and in many cases reduces their sentences. However, the judge is never quite so friendly to people from Blacktown or Richmond and disposed towards giving them the benefit of the doubt.

As I say, in this whole general discussion on social security the whole theme seems to be: 'We will give you a little advantage here but we will recover what we spend in other areas'. Overdue adjustments have been made in some areas. But it is quite apparent to me that we have to get back to the concept of Prime Minister Chifley and build up the coffers for social security during boom years and periods of high overtime. We should adopt standards comparable to those that apply in Western and Eastern Europe. I say Eastern Europe because I went to Eastern Europe during the 1950s and at that time some of the industrial conditions there were far superior to ours. Former Senator John Wheeldon had some outstanding visions about what could be done in the social security area. However, insurance companies and other vested interests do not want any change at all.

I regret the punitive nature of the legislation which will apply if someone's husband or the main defendant is on strike. If definition is to be argued, I venture to suggest that there could be cases where it could be very close to a lockout. It could be an indirect effect caused because the boss stands down people in another section. I suggest that there will be as much trouble here with appeals to the Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court as there has been in relation to other legislation dealing with deportation. When one gets into definitions, one gets into a lot of difficulty. Honourable senators will find that we could try to placate some of the newspapers and the National Country Party elements like Mr Anthony who was talking about his blind prejudice on trade unions. I can think of somebody else at the moment going through a legal Gethsemane who was a good friend of Mr Anthony's. I will not name him. I believe that long term funding is lacking, preferably that under the Chifley system. I hope that in reply the Minister will give us some indication of what the Government proposes in that area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is at present debating the Social Services Amendment Bill 1981. It is always good to listen to my colleague Senator Mulvihill speaking on social security measures, because he has, I think, proven to the Senate over the years that he has been here that he has very great concern for the lower paid people and, as we term them, the have-nots. He is never afraid to put a case for them or to criticise the haves. Unfortunately in this country the gap is continually widening between the haves and the have-nots. In many instances this Government shows little concern for those people who, we on the Opposition side claim, are the underprivileged section of the Australian community, particularly many of those in receipt of pensions.

SPEECH.PARA: While the Government claims that social security is one of its largest costs in the Budget each year, it fails to admit that many of the people in receipt of pensions in this country today are those who worked hard to make this the great country that it was until some six years ago. Unfortunately the situation is getting worse as the years go by. The time is well nigh for another election to bring about a change of government and put into office an Australian Labor Party government which has at heart the welfare not only of people in need but also of people in industry right across the board. We have their welfare at heart. In doing that, we also have the welfare of all Australians at heart. We need to get this country back on the good footing that it was being put on under the jurisdiction of the Whitlam Labor Government.

We all know that we were not allowed to carry out our task in remedying many of the problems which were created under 23 years of conservative governments. We were not given time to rectify those matters. The first thing that this Government said when it came into office was that it would not interfere with Medibank which was of great benefit to people in social need. That was one of the main planks of Fraser's platform. He said: 'We will not interfere with Medibank'. But the Government was not in office very long when it started tinkering with Medibank, and after six years Medibank no longer exists. Under the Labor Administration and under the Hayden plan for Medibank when Bill Hayden the Leader of the Opposition was the Minister for Social Security, people who could not afford the necessary medical attention for themselves and their children could receive that medical attention without any fear. But now we have reverted to the position where people who receive over a certain income and who need medical attention, both for their families and, in particular, for their children, have to pay for it out of their own pockets if they do not belong to a private medical fund. Of course, we know by looking at history, that this Government supports private medical funds and private doctors. It is for those organisations and people that this Government shows the most concern. When we were in government we showed our concern for the real needy people of the community. It is unfortunate that because of the many amendments to the National Health Act, we are now back to where we started prior to 1972. The clock has been turned back some nine years. But we have made the promise that immediately we are elected to government we will advance the clock again and bring justice to those in social need. The Opposition spokesman on social security has moved an amendment. I will repeat the words of the amendment for some of those who may not have heard it. I think that the terms of that amendment are worthy and I hope that it will be carried. The terms are:
The removal of the discrimination against tenants in government housing.
Previous speakers from the Opposition have broadened that out and pointed out to the Senate a lot of the problems that will beset those people because of this discrimination. The next point states:
The removal of the discrimination against the adult unemployed without dependants.
The third one states:
An increase in the unemployment benefit for the under 18 unemployed.

I think that is something that this Government deserves very severe criticism for, because, in my view-I have reared three children-a human being who is 14, 15, 16 or 17 years old in the main wears the same size clothes as a person who is 18 years old. He eats just as much food and burns just as much electricity in his parents' home, if he is living at home. As a matter of fact, he uses exactly the same commodities as a person over 18 years of age uses. Yet here we have a government saying that those people can live on less. I think it is very unfortunate for any government to have to have that sheeted home to it. The fourth point states:
The inclusion of the first and second children in the provision of increased family allowances in line with those for third and later children.
That is what we are advocating in our amendment. The fifth point states:
The removal of the provision discriminating against the spouses of union members affected by industrial disputes.
My colleague from Western Australia Senator Giles spoke at length on that matter and I will have a few words to say about it too. The final clause states:
The removal of discrimination against the spouses of unemployed persons who fail the work test.

It appears, when we look at this document that we are now debating, that the Government is doing everything possible-or trying to do it by way of legislation-to force people to work in industry against their wills and for a very small pecuniary interest. I heard Senator MacGibbon yesterday talking on the education legislation. He used that as a vehicle to once again castigate the trade union movement and tell the people of this country of all the evils that are brought about by activities of trade union members trying to get justice for themselves. He also spoke against the trade union secretaries for trying to get justice for their members.

Those of us who have come up through industry know what a battle it is to get proper working conditions and wages. Senator Mulvihill, as an ex-railway worker, well knows this, and I, as a person who has done every menial job that it is possible to do in this country, apart from coal mining-I spent over 20 years as a shearer and then worked as a poultry farmer-know it. When I was in industry no benefit was even given to a working person in this country unless he fought for it. No matter how good a worker one is, no matter how loyal one is to the boss, he never comes along and says: 'You have done a good job. I think you are entitled to better working conditions, shorter working hours or an increase in pay'. The only way that the work force of Australia can get benefits is to go to the barricades and fight for them. Then we find people on the other side saying: 'You are holding the country to ransom'. They have gone further and coined the term 'dole bludgers'. That is a terrible thing to say against young people, and this Government does not provide work for them.

When we get up and talk about that we find people on the other side immediately saying: 'But look at the unemployment figures when Labor was in government; look at those unemployment figures'. Those unemployment figures have certainly escalated now that we have a change of government. We do not even see the true unemployment figures now because of the method used by this Government to find out who is unemployed. When we were in government we used the true figures from the Commonwealth Employment Service of those people in receipt of unemployment benefits. But what does this Government do to come up with the statistics of the unemployed? It uses the Australian Bureau of Statistics. We all know-we have discussed this in this chamber many times-how those figures are arrived at. They are arrived at by the ABS sending people around to do a random sample test, knocking on doors-not every door in the district. If a person who answers the door admits that he has worked for one hour in any one week, he is classed as employed. So every month when the unemployment figures come out from the ABS we find that they are not as high as they really are because many people who have worked for one hour in one week-the rate of pay would not be enough to keep them for one week-are not considered to be unemployed. This Government is using fictitious figures. Many thousands of unemployed people are hidden from the public gaze because they are not recorded in the proper way. I think that also leads to some very stringent criticism of this Government.

We all know that the cost of social security is escalating every year. But why is it escalating? It is escalating because this Government is cutting down on the Public Service. It is paring money for public works. It is not prepared to create public works projects so that the people in this country who are prepared to work can get some dignity by having a job. These people cannot get jobs. When they cannot get jobs the Government says they are dole bludgers. This Government claims that it is a great advocate of private enterprise. Governments manufacture nothing except, as I have said in speeches I have made before about most governments and particularly Liberal governments, hot air to attempt to fool the electors. If the Government had any sense at all it would be prepared to create public works projects because its own friends in private enterprise are the first who will benefit. The people who will benefit secondly are those people in the work force. If the Government is not spending money on public works there is no avenue for private enterprise to tender for and to construct the works which are necessary for the benefit of this country. When we have a look around every State and in every town if Australia, we find any amount of work could be carried out if only the Government had the ability to do it. When Labor was in government we had what was known as the Regional Employment Development Scheme under which people were able to go to work. The benefits that local government achieved under that Scheme can still be seen around the country. When that Scheme was stopped we made money available to State Governments under what is known in South Australia as the unemployment relief scheme. Anyone who looks around will see in many country towns the great structures which were built-civic centres, halls and swimming pools.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clyde Cameron introduced apprenticeship training too.

—That is right. I am very pleased that Senator Mulvihill has reminded me of that because only today I read in the Press that industry is looking for skilled tradesmen but cannot find them. In some instances industry is not training apprentices because industry does not have any jobs for these people.
—They lack the vision of Clyde Cameron.

—Of course, they lack the vision of the Labor governments. I well recall when Bob Menzies was asked to attend the laying of the foundation stone for the great Snowy Mountains Scheme, he boycotted the ceremony. He said it would be a white elephant. What is it today? It is one of the great wonders of the world and it is the salvation of the south-eastern States. Senator Peter Baume may well laugh, but that is a fact. I well remember the criticism that was levelled at a Labor government when it spent taxpayers' money on constructing the transcontinental railway. Until recent years that has been the main link between the east and west of this country. All those projects were commenced by Labor governments as were many other schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me back to the point I was trying to make. If this Government were prepared to make money available for public works it would not have to spend so much money on social security. In the first place, it would not have to pay so much in unemployment benefit and, secondly, by putting people into work it would get something back into the Treasury by way of income tax. It is time that somebody in the Government considered these things instead of saying all of the time when it is criticised about high unemployment figures that it is all because of the dole bludgers. Government supporters have only to look at the number of job vacancies that are advertised every day in the Press. They do not even add up to the figures that Government supporters use. They are fictitious figures. There are not enough jobs to go around, whatever way one looks at it.

TALK.START.PARA: —They scrapped all that.
—The Government uses the Australian Bureau of Statistics' figures which, as I said a while ago, do not give a true picture.

SPEECH.PARA: Getting back to the matter of pensions, Senator Chaney stated that the pension rate has risen 70 per cent in six years under this Government. However, under Labor it rose 94 per cent in three years. I can well recall when we were elected to government in 1962, because of the very low rate of the pension, we immediately increased the rate for pensioners so that they had something worth while to exist on. I have tabled in the Parliament and I have incorporated in Hansard on many occasions a table setting out the figures over a number of years. It can be seen from that table that under successive Liberal-Country Party governments in some years there was no increase in the pension; in other years there might have been an increase of 5s or 7s 6d, as the currency was then. The only year in which pensioners could expect any worthwhile increase was in an election year. Just prior to an election the Government would give them 10s or #1 a week. But Labor saw fit to bring in a decent increase. As Senator Grimes has pointed out, and as I have already said, our increases in the pension amounted to much more over three years than the increases this Government has made in six years.

My memory goes back to another thing which Senator Chaney's predecessor tried to do. This illustrates how niggardly this Government is in respect of people in need. The Liberal Government tried to take away the $40 funeral benefit for pensioners. I well remember Senator Guilfoyle, sitting where Senator Chaney is sitting today, was most vicious about that proposal. But because there was a split in the ranks of the Government she had to capitulate and that proposal did not come about. But of course those people who split the Government's ranks could not have achieved the defeat of that proposal if it had not have been for the Labor Party. The same position applies today in respect of the amendments which we have moved. They will be carried, I am sure, or they should be and we will endeavour to get some benefits for those people who are in need.

Criticism has been levelled by the only speaker from the Government side so far in this debate. It astounds me that the Government has put up only Senator Walters to speak in support of this legislation. If it is so good--

TALK.START.PARA: —For four minutes.

—She spoke for four minutes. If the legislation is so good the Government would have had speakers telling the world at large what great legislation it is. But the Government could find only Senator Walters to support it. We Labor members, because of time strictures, cannot say as much as we would like to say either. My colleague from Tasmania, Senator Coates, has very many important things to say about this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think my colleague from Western Australia, Senator Giles, outlined very forcibly the problems that will occur if this legislation which takes away the unemployment benefit from the husband when he is on strike is carried. The Government will force these people on to the State authorities, to go cap in hand to community welfare organisations asking for a hand out for themselves and their kids to exist because of the heartlessness of the Government in this part of the legislation. The Government has no concern for these people at all. If these companies were prepared to pay a decent wage and were prepared to give the workers decent conditions they would not go on strike. No worker goes on strike unless there is some good reason for it. In talking about strikes I recall these well paid people on the Government side going on strike here in 1975. They would not get off their backsides to pass the Budget. Honourable senator's opposite cannot criticise a working man for going on strike when members of parliament went on strike here for months and refused to deliberate on the Budget and to pass it. As time is getting on and my colleague Senator Coates wants to say a few words, I will resume my seat to allow him to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I would like to point out in this debate on the Social Services Amendment Bill is the total lack of Government interest. If I remember rightly, I think the second reading speech--

—I raise a point of order. There has been one speaker from the Government side for reasons that were plainly explained at the time. The position has been misrepresented twice in the last few minutes in this debate. Senator Walters made it quite clear that the reason Government senators were not entering the debate and why she was speaking for a very short time was because of the concern of the Government to deal with this legislation.
—There is no point of order. I call Senator Coates.

—I was referring to the total lack of Government interest-not only the lack of speakers from the Government side but also to their attendance in the chamber for a large part of the debate. The only person in the chamber was the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) with no back benchers at all even to listen to the contributions from this side of the chamber. Senator Walters spoke very briefly but she did not even attempt to refute any of the accusations made by Senator Grimes in his speech on behalf of the Opposition. It was a totally weak contribution from the Government. But I suppose it just reflects the generally grudging attitude of the Government in social security matters. The whole difference in the atmosphere, in comparison with the Labor Government period of 1972-1975, is very marked. That was a period of exciting advances. The present Government claims some innovations such as the family allowance and the change to the income test as examples of its innovations. It cannot rest on those laurels.

SPEECH.PARA: Previous speakers have emphasised the matter of family allowances. Point four of the Opposition's amendment refers to the need for the inclusion of the first and second children in the provision of increased family allowances in line with those for third and later children. Even the increases for the third and later children are inadequate. But the fact is that the present allowances for the first and second children are the same as those which were introduced in 1976 when the changeover was made from the tax allowance, and the lack of any increase in this area at all shows how far behind family allowances have fallen. For the Government to keep on referring to family allowances as a great innovation rings hollow and has done so for the last couple of years.

Also there is the supposed great innovation of the change to the income test in place of the income and means test. Again that has fallen flat because of the Government's attempts to fill the gap that has shown itself in recent times because of people abusing that change. The Government claims that it introduced indexation. The Government actually put it into the relevant Act but it was the Labor Government in 1972-75 which began the regular indexation of pensions and benefits. While indexation is worthy and this Government actually included it in the Act as a permanent feature, honourable senators will recall that in 1978 the Government attempted to apply indexation once a year instead of every six months. So we have a situation where pensioners and beneficiaries are permanently behind. They have still not caught up. They have lost about $60 permanently because of that lack of indexation in 1978. Certainly the Government finally succumbed to public pressure and reverted to six monthly adjustments-not for all beneficiaries, as we know-but this did not catch up with the permanent loss which pensioners suffered.

It should be emphasised that indexation as an adjustment applied to an amount which is not the minimum wage or anything like it. It is an amount much smaller than that. Pensioners in the community are falling behind all the time in real spending power because the indexation is applied to a fraction of the amount that it takes people in the work force to live on. I think the time has come for a quantum jump in such rates, a catch-up as it is referred to in industrial relations terms. This applies especially to the rate for children and to those who are furthest behind, those who are most below the poverty line.

One particular absence from the Bill that is referred to in the Opposition's amendment is an increase in the unemployment benefit for those under 18 years who are unemployed. That rate still remains at a disgraceful $36 as it has done for the last six years. If one adjusted that rate for the last few years by indexation it would be almost doubled. It ought to be almost doubled to catch up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-At the commencement of this debate I refused to co-operate and grant leave to make a cognate debate of this Bill and the Repatriation Acts Amendment Bill. I was unaware at that time that an agreement had been made between the Opposition Whip and the Government Whip that this should be done. In keeping with the spirit of goodwill from this side of the chamber and in regard to the keeping of agreements, I would prefer it that this Bill be considered part of a cognate debate with the Repatriation Acts Amendment Bill. I will use the Committee stages to make my remarks on that legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.
General Business taking precedence of Government Business at 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered-

(1) Intervening business be postponed until after the further consideration of Government Business Order of the Day No. 1, Social Services Amendment Bill 1981 and the Order of the Day relating to the resumption of debate on the second reading of the Repatriation Acts Amendment Bill 1981.

(2) Upon the receipt of any message from the House of Representatives relating to the Social Services Amendment Bill 1981 and/or the Repatriation Acts Amendment Bill 1981, such message shall be immediately reported by the President and dealt with at once.
Prior to the suspension of the sitting, the Senate was debating the legislation referred to in that motion, the Social Services Amendment Bill 1981. The debate had not--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I understood from the sessional order explained to us today that until 16 minutes past 8 this evening we would be debating the papers which were brought in. Therefore, it would be inappropriate for the Minister to introduce without leave at this stage any other matter.
—With respect to that point of order, Standing Order 65 states that:

SPEECH.PARA: Any motion connected with the conduct of the business of the Senate may be moved by a Minister of the Crown at any time without notice.
I think that Standing Order overrides the sessional order suggested by the honourable senator. I submit that there is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no point of order. I call Senator Chaney.
—I thought that the Minister might have explained that fact before he moved his motion. That is the conduct we would expect of the Minister.
—There is no practice in this chamber for announcing the Standing Order under which one is moving. If that is thought to be necessary--
—Particularly when you are interfering with the normal sessional order that operates. But that is the sort of behaviour that we expect.

—We have before us an issue which involves whether a substantial number of Australians will get benefits. I suggest that we address ourselves to the issue rather than engaging in petty chiacking. Before the suspension of the sitting, we were considering the Social Services Amendment Bill 1981. We had not concluded the second reading speeches. The fact that the Government wished to have the Bill considered and completed today was indicated quite clearly by Senator Walters who was the only Government senator who spoke. She made it clear that it was necessary for the legislation to be dealt with today if the beneficiaries who are to benefit from the beginning of November are indeed to benefit. Senator Walters pointed out that as a result she would restrain her speech and that the Government would be seeking to have the legislation dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: She also made it clear that if any action was taken in this place in respect of the Bill-that is a possibility that the Government has to consider-the message would be sent to the House of Representatives and dealt with there. The motion which I have moved is to enable the Senate to complete its consideration of the legislation and for a message to be sent to the House of Representatives so that the matter can be dealt with. I am a little surprised that, in the debate which has taken place this afternoon, there has been no concern expressed-except I think, by the first speaker for the Opposition-about the effects of this legislation not being dealt with. The fact is that it will result in at least a delay in the improvement of the position of some 200,000 or more single unemployment beneficiaries without dependents and special beneficiaries.

There has been a great deal of debate about the difficult situation in which some Australians find themselves. Indeed, there have been many complaints about the failure of the Government to improve more greatly a number of areas of pensions and benefits. Therefore, I think it would be very fitting if this chamber devoted its attention to something which it does have an influence over, namely, the improving of the position of a group of beneficiaries who, honourable senators opposite assured us, are being rather shortchanged. The fact is that there is an opportunity here for the beneficiaries position to be improved as from next week and it is this chamber that can prevent that happening.

Two clear areas of concern have been expressed on the other side of the chamber. I understand that it is the right and the duty of honourable senators opposite to raise matters which are of concern to them and to seek to amend legislation. In the present case, that is complicated by the nature of the legislation which is before us. I think that, to assist the Senate in its consideration of my motion, it would be helpful if I indicated that the means are within the Senate's power to deal with the concerns which have been raised. As I understand it, the concern on the part of the official Opposition and the Australian Democrats is in respect of two clauses of the Bill. From memory they are clause 18 and clause 21. There were objections to those clauses. The balance of the Bill was supported except that there were some complaints that more was not being done in this area.

On my understanding of the constitutional position, it would not be possible for the Senate to amend this legislation. It is also my view that it would not be possible for it to divide the legislation. That is a matter on which there may well be differences of opinion. There could be no argument that the Senate has the power to request amendments to the legislation. There can be no argument that it has the power to request the deletion of any clauses which it wishes to delete. Whatever view one has of the constitutional position, there is no argument that this chamber has the power and the authority at least to do that. In those circumstances it seems to me that it is the clear duty of the Senate, on the views expressed this afternoon, to express the view in some proper way-not merely in debate-that changes ought be made by the legislation and for the legislation then to be returned to the House of Representatives. It seems to me that, at the moment, we have a situation where the Senate has, I believe by use of a filibuster, simply avoided coming to grips with this legislation on a day when it is important that it should do so.

We are now in a situation where there has been no vote on the legislation; there has been nothing but debate on it. I suggest that it is most appropriate that we should move to the stage where we can vote on the second reading and where the Opposition and the Democrats, if they intend to act in unison, can put down the resolution that they wish to put down in respect of the legislation. The motion that I moved makes clear that we would anticipate, if that were done, that we would hope to get a message from the House of Representatives in respect of the legislation and to deal with it this evening. The important thing about what I am proposing is that this seems to leave the onus in this situation on the Government. At the moment, however, it is clear that the onus is on the Opposition and upon the Australian Democrats. They are in a position to deny the opportunity for this legislation to pass. They are in a position to deny the 200,000 plus people who, they told us earlier today, are people in need, the benefits which the Government indicated in the Budget that it wished them to have. I believe that it is appropriate for the General Business of the Senate to be postponed until we can give further consideration to the legislation which was before us this afternoon, so that the opportunity can be made for the benefits which flow from this legislation to be made available to the people for whom they are intended.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were not concerned about that in 1975.
—I say also that other legislation is involved. The repatriation legislation is involved and once again there is a question of denial of benefits to people who are entitled to get them.
—They have brought in the big guns.

—There has been reference by way of interjection to 1975 and reference to standover tactics. I think those comments would be fine if it were not for the fact that honourable senators opposite have a course of action open to them which puts the onus on the Government. In other words, this is not a situation where honourable senators opposite are being asked to give away anything that they believe in. They have expressed themselves as being opposed to only two clauses of the legislation. Unless, in the unlikely event, there is a Labor senator who crosses the floor against Caucus it would appear that the position is that they are prepared to deny those 200,000 plus people. I make it quite clear that at this stage the responsibility is clearly on the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. Let me say that if a message is sent to the House of Representatives and returned here, clearly the responsibility will then lie with the Government. I am very happy to pick up that challenge but I say to honourable senators opposite that if they refuse to deal with this legislation and regard that on the Notice Paper at the moment as more important than legislation which affects the unemployed of Australia, fine; but I would like to make quite clear on whom the onus rests. At the moment it rests on the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. I would be more than happy to have the onus rest on the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise merely to support Senator Chaney and to draw attention particularly to the situation with regard to beneficiaries under the repatriation legislation. The doubt that now exists with regard to the passage of the Repatriation Acts Amendment Bill does show very clearly the lack of concern on the part of the Opposition for those who really are the most disabled and in the greatest need. In fact, there are benefits which are in some doubt with regard to the payment of persons with two arms amputated, those with two legs and one arm amputated, and those with two legs amputated above the knee, as well as many other persons in these categories. It would be of the greatest concern to the Government if this legislation were not passed and consequently we were not in a position to meet our payments and commitments to that group of people in November. That is the appointed hour which the Government did agree to support and which was mentioned in the Budget statement.

SPEECH.PARA: There are also other categories of persons in this field, the payments to whom are now thrown in doubt. I refer to perhaps the most disadvantaged group of all, the orphans of repatriation beneficiaries. Again, the Government expresses its grave concern at the situation. As Senator Chaney has pointed out, clearly there is a course of action open to the Opposition and to the Australian Democrats in this regard and we look to them to fulfil their responsibilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have witnessed tonight an act of cynicism the like of which I have not seen since I have been a member of this place. Before I entered this chamber tonight I was approached by several journalists who said: 'What is happening in the Senate at 8 o'clock? Mr Barnett, the Prime Minister's Press Secretary, has been running around telling us all to be in the gallery of the Senate tonight because Senator Chaney is going to do something sensational'. We have now seen Senator Chaney's sensational performance.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the history of what has happened here today and how this situation has arisen. We are dealing with two pieces of legislation. The first to which I will refer is the Social Services Amendment Bill 1981. The provisions of that Bill were announced two months ago in the course of the presentation of the Budget. The Bill was produced in the House of Representatives on Tuesday of this week, two days ago. I suggest that the delay was deliberate. I suggest that it was to enable to arise a situation in which the Government would try to blackmail the Opposition, and the Australian Labor Party in particular, into bulldozing this legislation through with two clauses, clause 18 and clause 21, which we find extremely offensive and utterly discriminatory, which we oppose and which the Australian Democrats have said they oppose. Senator Chaney has explained that the reason for the delay was the difficulty that the Government had in deciding what it would do about pensioners who were using means whereby they could avoid the income test. That does not apply to the Repatriation Acts Amendment Bill, which is being similarly delayed.

Last Thursday night in this place we were to have discussed General Business. That was delayed because the Government introduced an important statement and wished to continue with it. This afternoon the Government introduced the legislation in question. We had a guarantee from the Government that General Business would be continued tonight. Now, on the phoney excuse that the Government needs to get this legislation through at once, we are asked to give up General Business again. We are not going to be blackmailed in this way, any more than we were blackmailed at the time Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle got up in this place and told us that if we opposed the funeral benefits pensioners would not be paid.

The simple fact is that we are willing to sit tonight and tomorrow, after General Business has concluded, to get this legislation through. If the Government wants the Opposition to sit then it will happily do so and, as it has said in the past it would, it will carry through the legislation. But we are not going to be stood over in this way. The simple fact is that the single unemployment beneficiaries who are to receive some $4 out of this legislation will receive it, after the legislation has been passed, from 1 November. If the Government wants to come back next Tuesday and pass it there will be no delay at all. If it wants to come back next Thursday there will be a minimum delay for a few people.

Tonight Senator Chaney is indulging in a stunt and he knows it. He knows that he and his associate Minister have been approaching me for two days to see whether we could do a deal about this situation, and they have not succeeded. They are not going to succeed with standover tactics like this tonight. We believe that General Business, which is on the Notice Paper for tonight, should be proceeded with. The Government has already interfered with the order of General Business tonight. We are willing to continue to consider this legislation after General Business has been completed. We will deal with the legislation and send it back to the House of Representatives then. The problem is that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) wants to get the House of Representatives up and does not want to accept the consequences of facing the House of Representatives in that regard. The simple fact of the matter is that the offer is there.

Of course, an alternative would be for Senator Chaney to say that the Government will accept the requests that would obviously go back from this House. Those two requests will involve clauses 18 and 21 of the legislation. They are not essential to the operation of the rest of the legislation. They are absolutely peripheral to the Government's Budget. They make no difference to it. The Treasurer did not even mention them in his Budget Speech. If Senator Chaney is willing to get up and say on behalf of the Government that the House of Representatives-which means his Government-will accept those requests, we will proceed to pass this legislation. Otherwise, we will proceed in the normal way and return after General Business has been completed to discuss the legislation tonight, tomorrow, Saturday, Sunday or whenever the Government likes; but we are not going to be stood over by publicity stunts like this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not been here quite as long as Senator Grimes has, but events of the last couple of months have indicated to me quite clearly that we ought not to be surprised at anything the Government tries to put over the Senate. The simple fact is that this legislation could have been here weeks ago if the Government had not dithered around trying to catch some groups of pensioners. The Government delayed the legislation until it discovered that it could not get them as adequately as it wanted, and the provision has been put aside. What Senator Grimes says is quite accurate. If the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), who should know the answer to this question, will give an assurance that the Government will accept the requests that are put by this side of the House there is no reason why we cannot accede to the Government's request. However, this is quite unlikely to happen because the rather veiled hints by the Minister that this is the likely outcome of sending them back were just that, merely veiled hints.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats are not in the business of giving up the General Business of this Senate on the first night that it has been given the opportunity to apply. The late receipt of the unemployment benefit by the 200,000 people to whom the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, referred will not hurt those people in the long run. As we all stressed in the debate this afternoon, a very small amount is involved-what I think Senator Macklin last night kept referring to as a piddling amount, in fact. They will receive it in the long run. They will be no worse off in the next week, or in the next two, three or four weeks, than they were in the last week, or in the last two, three or four weeks.

What is involved here is a particularly important principle involving the question of what legislation can be presented with what other form of legislation. No matter what the Australian Labor Party chooses to do in the future, the Australian Democrats will not accept the concept that the Government, in order simply to play grubby little games, can tack on to one set of legislation other pieces of legislation which are totally irrelevant to it. The Australian Democrats will not accede to the Government's wishes tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I doubt that there is any wish in the Senate to prolong the debate on this motion. We might as well get a decision on it. But I do wish to respond to the matters raised in response to the motion I moved and the comments I made on it. I am terribly relieved by Senator Haines's comment that the unemployed will be no worse off in the next two, three, four or whatever number of weeks it was that she indicated. I am sure that they will be very pleased to know that they are no worse off than they have been in the past.
—Don't be cheap; you can do better than that.

—After the abuse I have had in the last few minutes, I think such interjections are really rather unnecessary. In any event, the fact is that it is within the power of this Senate to deal with this legislation or not to deal with it. That is a matter which apparently honourable senators sitting opposite are determined not to pursue this evening. After all, we have to look at the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill 1981, a matter of pressing importance which I doubt has the public of Australia panting for an early decision; the Industrial Democracy Bill 1981 of Senator Siddons, which again I doubt that the public of Australia are panting for a decision on; and the Senate Elections (Queensland) Bill 1981, which I do not see as having any immediate short term relevance. I also reject the suggestion that an approach was made to do a deal. I certainly spoke with the spokesman for the Australian Labor Party on this matter and I indicated to him that I was anxious to have the legislation dealt with. I spoke to him on that basis. If he regards that as some form of deal--
—You double speak.

—I would not have mentioned any conversation I had with the shadow Minister had he not raised the matter here a few minutes ago. I simply deny that there was anything in what I said other than that I was anxious to get the legislation dealt with because of the problem of payments next week. One serious question was raised in the debate, as against the abuse which has been hurled across the chamber; that is, the question of what will happen with respect to any messages. I made it quite clear that if a message were sent to the House of Representatives it would become a problem for the Government and the onus would then be upon the Government to decide whether those payments would be made. The responsibility now rests on honourable senators opposite-on honourable senators from the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. I am happy to accept the responsibility for what follows if the Senate goes on to deal with this legislation. It will then become my responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: One other matter I wish to address is the allegation of deliberate delay and the allegation of blackmail. I have explained publicly the basis on which the legislation was brought into the Parliament later than I had wished. That has been referred to. The fact is that additional clauses in the legislation were removed because, after careful consideration, it was decided that they were not in a form in which we should bring them before the Parliament; they were not sufficiently certain. That has been said clearly; it has been said publicly. It is a fact. That is the fact and I reject any suggestion to the contrary.

I again remind honourable senators opposite that they cannot say that they have been blackmailed because it is clear that they have the numbers required to send a request to the House of Representatives. They have that very clear power and, in using it, they can put the onus upon the Government. If I were seeking a course of conduct from the Opposition which took the matter out of its hands and left the Government free to do as it wished, I think there would be some force in the points that have been made. I wish that the journalists who are in the Press Gallery now had been here for the earlier debate. Had they been here they would have heard and they would have seen for themselves that the bulk of the debate this afternoon was for no purpose other than to delay the consideration of this Social Security Amendment Bill. It was a clear tactic. The floating nature of the list of speakers, the preparedness to go on adding names to it just to make sure that no vote would be taken on the Bill before 6 p.m., is proof of that. Mr President, I say to honourable senators opposite that if they are genuinely concerned about this legislation they will proceed to deal with it and, if they believe that sections of the legislation are objectionable, they will move requests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek-
—Mr President-
—The question is-
—Mr President-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate is closed.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the motion (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I wish to make a personal explanation. I claim to have been misrepresented. Senator Chaney in the course of his speech said that the Opposition speakers list this afternoon was a floating one and that the names on that list changed. As the Manager of Opposition Business who is responsible for that list, I point out that the only change made this afternoon to the Opposition speakers list was that Senator Coates and Senator McLaren changed places. The real change was that Senator Walters spoke for only four minutes-an extraordinarily short time. If there was any floating it was on the other side.
—Mr President, that is not absolutely correct.
—Seek leave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —An additional name was added to the speakers list.
—Who?
—Two names were added-McLaren and Coleman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.
