TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation as well.
—For what reason, Senator?
—I wish to make a statement on this topic.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very simply, I appended my name to the list in our Whip's office yesterday, 24 hours ago.

—by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation in relation to this matter. Earlier this afternoon I indicated to my Whip that I would be speaking on the Bill. At that stage I was not aware that I would be required to be in the chair for the length of time that I was. Having that in mind, and recognising that the other Temporary Chairman on duty today had requested another Temporary Chairman to take his place because of urgent business that had come up, I then placed my name back on the list. It was not an addition. My name had been taken off the list and was replaced on it.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the first annual report of the Bicentennial Authority is disappointing. Although the objectives of the Bicentennial Authority are set out very carefully and very properly on pages 4 and 5, it is nevertheless a disappointing report. The report relates to the 18-month period from the beginning of 1980 to the middle of 1981. It has more to do with the financial accounts and staff arrangements for the Bicentennial Authority than it has to do with substantial planning or programs for the bicentennial year. I believe that we should expect in the second report a much more substantial set of determinations for the programs for the year.

SPEECH.PARA: Maybe we are too optimistic in thinking that the first annual report of the Bicentennial Authority should be more substantial. I believe that we have a 20-page report which is only a very initial offering, one that needs considerable substance to be added to it if we are going to see the kind of bicentennial celebration that many Australians are looking for. At one point in the report there is reference to fireworks and historic re-enactments. Whilst these may be popular and jump immediately to mind when one considers bicentennial celebrations they are, nevertheless, not the substance that most Australians are looking for. They are looking for things that are lasting, for evaluations of where Australia has come from, where we are now and where we are going.

Senator Evans has spoken along these same lines about his disappointment in this report. But I want to disassociate myself from his comments about the Constitution needing reform as coming from the Bicentennial Authority. It is inappropriate for us to look to the Bicentennial Authority as a constitutional convention. I believe that any constitutional reform in this country is much more in the hands of parliament, the people and constitutional conventions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not saying they should run it but just that they should acknowledge it as something which ought to happen on this occasion.

—That is a political matter. It is a matter which I believe the Bicentennial Authority has wisely left untouched. It may well be argued that constitutional reform is something that politicians and others may promote in the year of the bicentenary. I happen to think that there is room for some reform in the Constitution because the Constitution is so important. It must continue to endure and to be a living document on which the parliamentary and political life of our country is based. But that is for others to initiate. It is not fair to relate that matter to the Bicentennial Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: The second initiative that Senator Evans called for was a new flag for Australia. I am puzzled that he should be seeking such wild, kitsch innovations. I think he was even self-aware on the matter. I believe that at a time of our bicentennial celebrations we should remember the flag that has flown proudly and high in all the years of our history. The traditional and historic elements of the Australian flag should continue to inspire Australians to acknowledge the continuity of our history. For all of the remarks that have been made about the Southern Cross-I happen to have a particular fondness for and a real sense of personal identity with the Southern Cross-it is on the Australian flag and no one has complained about it. It is something of pride to most Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not on the Australian flag.

—I do not accept at all the innovative and minority views that Senator Evans expressed on that matter. So much for the interjection by Senator Button. The one particular matter I suggest with regard to the Bicentennial Authority relates to the year of 1988 itself. As everybody knows, Australia Day is on 26 January. I believe that on that day there will be a number of celebrations throughout Australia, in every State and indeed here in the capital, Canberra. One matter that is unresolved and that I believe we ought to comment on at this stage before the program for that year has been planned by the Bicentennial Authority is the involvement of this Parliament in the events of Australia Day 1988. Some senators and members believe that the new Parliament House should have its official opening on Australia Day 1988. I do not agree with that. I believe that there will be so many other popular events to celebrate the bicentenary of Australia on 26 January that it would be quite inappropriate for the new Parliament House to be officially opened on that same day. It would draw people away; it would draw the focus of attention here to Canberra rather than having some focus of attention on every city, town, country district and territory of Australia where the people themselves can be involved in the celebrations. Accordingly, I register my view that the Parliament should begin to operate in the Budget session of 1987. In August 1987, we should move from this chamber to the new Parliament House.
—If you are here, Senator.
—If we are here-if any of us are here. Then, in about May of 1988-the reason I suggest May is that this Parliament House-
—Is it your birthday?

—It is not my birthday; my birthday is in September. May 1988 is a very appropriate time as May is the month of the year in which this Parliament House was opened. We should seek to set that month as the time for the opening of the new Parliament House. I want quite genuinely to register that view at this very early stage of the Bicentennial Authority's planning for the celebration by all Australians in the bicentenary year. I hope that other senators and members will urge a common view towards the acceptance of the idea that the new Parliament House be opened in May of 1988 rather than having an unnecessary complication of the very popular celebration throughout all of Australia on 26 January, Australia Day, 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to agree with Senator Teague's criticism of the report of the Australian Bicentennial Authority, although perhaps not with the other matters to which he alluded. It is a very disappointing report. I find centenaries and bicentenaries to be a total and utter bore. They are really just meaningless symbolism, an absolute heyday for people wanting to market logos and an absolute bonanza for jingoistic cliches. To make it worthwhile, one really has to pick up some sort of theme or focus of activity. We did think of several activities. The first idea was to have an Olympic Games in Australia. That fell through in Sydney; it was then naturally taken up in Melbourne but it fell through there because it was going to be too costly for the State Government. Then the Minister down there, Mr Brian Dixon-the Minister for getting his photo in the paper-decided to approach private enterprise, that gung ho institution in Melbourne, to take it over but it would not have it either.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to refer to one or two areas-I know that Senator Evans has concentrated on the constitutional aspect-that we might take up. We might make 1988 a year by which we have actually helped the Aboriginal population of this country. In many ways, the bicentenary celebrations will be a celebration of shame for the way that we have treated the original inhabitants of Australia. Maybe for the next seven years we could set as a target the raising of health, educational and economic circumstances of Aboriginals in our community. The second thing we could do, as Senator Evans said, is to try to get a new Constitution by 1988. I am not much of a betting man but I am sure it is a rather hopeless chance. The third area in which we could take action is to make 1988 the year that we introduce democracy throughout the whole of Australia. Why do we not make changes to the Constitution and the various electoral Acts to make this a democratic country. We will then be able to go to the rest of the world, celebrating this 200 years of Australia and pointing out to countries like the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics what a democracy is like. Are we not proud of that democratic heritage? Of course, any time we want to take action such as this, as Senator Gietzelt did this afternoon, what happens? We are blocked, as he was blocked, at every turn.

The only other aspect to which I want to refer which relates to parliamentarians is the Parliamentary Handbook. We have all been issued with proposals to have a special handbook in 1988. I agree with most of the suggestions and ideas in regard to that. It seems as though it will be a different type of handbook that will record almost forgotten aspects of Australian political history. I would encourage those who are working in that particular area to continue their work. As I said at the very beginning, this particular report is disappointing because the only theme I can find in it is under the heading of 'Objectives' where it says that the major promotional theme will be 'Living together'. I might have a different interpretation of what that means but I think we might be in for a bonanza year in 1988. It will not be too good for the churches or the civil marriage celebrants, but I am looking forward to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take about 60 seconds to make a couple of comments on the report of the Australian Bicentennial Authority. Unlike Senator Teague, I find it very difficult to get enthusiastic about the bicentennial or bicentenary, whichever it is. I wish we could get an authoritative ruling whether it is a bicentennial or a bicentenary. I suspect that by 1988 we will be heartily sick of the jingoism involved in this whole thing. There may well be some worthwhile things which will come out of it, such as some history writing and that sort of thing, but overall I cannot get enthusiastic about the whole idea. However, I can report that the former Leader of the Opposition in this place, Ken Wriedt, has settled in as the Executive Director of the Bicentennial Council in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other thing I want to mention relates not to the report of the Authority but to its newsletter which I received in the last few days. It has a beautiful photograph on the front cover of one of the nicest parts of Tasmania, Table Cape, near Wynyard. The only problem is that the caption is wrong.
