PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 August, on motion by Senator Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the motion for the second reading of the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill 1981. This private member's Bill was presented by Senator Evans on 19 August of this year. Senator Evans, in his second reading speech, dealt fully with the purposes of the Bill and the proposals in the Bill. Although this is a private member's Bill brought forward by an Opposition member, it is in essence a Bill which is an implementation of the very thorough report of the Australian Law Reform Commission entitled 'Insurance Agents and Brokers'. I know that the Bill which Senator Evans has introduced is a replica of the draft Bill which was presented in that report to which he has added provisions relating to penalties under various clauses which were not set out in the report. That was contemplated. I must say that I think the bill faithfully records the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make it clear that I support the Bill and I propose to vote for it. I trust that many of my colleagues on this side of the Senate will likewise support the Bill. I am aware that the Government, in the person of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), who represents the Treasurer (Mr Howard), expressed opposition to the Bill at an earlier date and that the Government is generally opposed at this stage anyway to the implementation of the Commission's report. I believe that Law Reform Commission reports are prima facie deserving of acceptance. This report has taken some years to compile. The Commission had before it a vast number of witnesses. With unstinting effort it has travelled across Australia and seen the people who are concerned with and affected by the problems that this Bill deals with and has made a report which I believe, failing other cogent reasons, should be accepted. The need for this legislation is well set out at the beginning of the report. The Commission said:

The private insurance industry is today organised on a national basis. It is undesirable that, in important aspects of the law governing relationships with the insuring public, this national industry should be subject to vague and uncertain rules developed long before the growth of modern insurance. It is equally undesirable that it should be subject to differing legislative requirements from one jurisdiction to another. The needs of the industry and of its customers can only be met by development of a national law of insurance contracts in Australia. This law should promote:
uniformity, to the extent that the Federal Constitution permits
clarity, by removing doubts in existing case law and statutes
relevance, in recognising the realities of the respective positions of the insured, the insurer and the intermediaries (agents and brokers) who facilitate and effect contracts of insurance.

I believe that that statement sets out, very fairly, the need which was there and the recommendations justify the action which has been proposed. A curious course has been adopted over a number of years in getting to some position where there will be regulation or some control of the various defalcations and losses which have been suffered by the investing public due to the defaults of a number of brokers. This problem has been with us for many years. Indeed, after this Government came into office there was in April 1976 a statement by the then Minister Assisting the Treasurer, the Honourable Eric Robinson, who announced that the Government would introduce legislation for the licensing of insurance brokers. On 11 March 1977 the Government changed its mind and announced its intention to pursue a scheme of self-regulation. I shall certainly be dealing with that matter of deregulation during my speech. The decision at that time to refuse the regulation of the industry was based on the complexity of the proposals and the thought that it was too excessive a weapon to use.

In February 1979 the Treasurer announced that he was seeking the Government's approval to develop legislation for a voluntary regulation arrangement for brokers. After six months there was a change in those plans. The Government then, saying that there was no consensus in the industry, decided to await the delivery of the Law Reform Commission's report. That report was subsequently tabled in September 1980. It must be pointed out that the Government gave the insurance reference to the Law Reform Commission. The Government sought that the Commission should do this work and find a solution to the problem. Unfortunately we waited some considerable time before there was a further development.

I think it also ought to be borne in mind that the report of the Commission came down in 1980. The consumer affairs Ministers of the States met in Melbourne after that-on 14 November 1980-and resolved as follows:
Insurance Brokers
Ministers agreed to express their concern to the Commonwealth the need for urgent action to implement the Australian Law Reform Commission's proposals to regulate the activities of insurance brokers.

It was agreed that there was a need for the Commonwealth to examine legislation involving a fidelity fund to compensate consumers for losses caused by cases of brokers failing to perform. It was also agreed that the legislation should provide for the registration of insurance brokers.

That is very clear. It is all States. Of course this is not something which has been imposed on the States. It is something which the States have requested. Subsequent to this, in a few short months, this was repeated when the Honourable Jim Ramsay, the Victorian Minister, pointed it out in May this year. He urged the Federal Government to introduce legislation to register insurance brokers and require them to set up trust and fidelity funds. He pointed out that there had been recent examples of collapses of insurance brokers. In March one liquidator had been appointed for Kinloch (Insurances) Pty Ltd with debts of $3m. Later the same month Anthony H. Bown and Associates Pty Ltd went into liquidation and One Stop Insurance Shop Pty Ltd collapsed with debts of $322,000. So there is a constant need. Those examples call for action. State Ministers have supported those claims and demands.

To complete the order of events, let me say that since that time the other action taken was that Senator Evans introduced this Bill, the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill 1981 on 28 May this year, which, as I say, implements the Law Reform Commission recommendations. Then the Treasurer (Mr Howard) made a ministerial statement on 10 June 1981 which rejected the recommendations in the report. So we come to a position where we are endeavouring to decide whether we will implement the recommendations in this report. The legislation is based upon the report. As I have said, and I reiterate, the recommendations are based upon consultation which went into the making of that report. They are also based upon the fact, of which details are set out in the second reading speech, of defalcations, something of the nature of $7m in the years before the report, and from the time that the report was prepared at least another $7m appears to have been defaulted. From my inquiries and discussions with representatives of the insurance industry-I have spoken to quite a number of them in the last two or three months-the total is probably more like $20m now because it is not known precisely what are some of the losses among a number of the companies. The report has pointed out that there is a need to do various things. It first sets out the action needed with respect to the responsibility of insurers for the conduct of their intermediaries. There have been many examples where they have failed and taken moneys and not accounted for them. The report also shows that:
It is necessary to protect members of the public from financial loss necessary to resolve conflicts between interest and duty inherent in the form of remuneration of brokers.

There are a number of other aspects in the report, nearly all of which are picked up in this Bill. The Bill clarifies the law, which is obscure in regard to agents. It also provides a statutory system of broker registration. I think it is worth recalling that when this report was being agreed upon many people in the insurance industry contributed their work to the Commission's action. It is described in information supplied to me by the representative of the Australian Mutual Provident Society. It appears that some 24 senior officers, brokers and agents from life and general insurance companies gave up weeks of time at their own and their companies' expense to act as consultants to the Commission. The Commission travelled all over Australia and hundreds of other members of the industry attended full day meetings in all capitals. That time, faithfully devoted, was wasted as were tens of thousands of dollars of company funds and thus policy holder's money in a fruitless exercise-that is assuming that this Parliament does not proceed with this legislation. The AMP Society further asserts:

While there were differences of opinion within the industry on the exact form of controls which should be introduced, all elements favoured controls to protect the public against embezzlement of premiums and insolvencies by brokers and against professional misconduct.

They are greatly disillusioned at the lack of Government action. I hope that we and the Government can do something. If this Bill is passed and it goes before the House of Representatives, I hope that the Government will be in a position to wipe away that disillusionment. There is no doubt that the Commonwealth has power to deal with this matter. This is not a case of the Senate and the House of Representatives seizing some power that is not properly there. There is such a specific power in section 51 (xiv) of the Australian Constitution which enables this Commonwealth Parliament to make laws 'with respect to insurance other than State insurance, also State insurance extending beyond the limits of the State concerned.' So the founding fathers had this very much in contemplation even before the insurance industry spread, as it has, right across the country, enmeshed, with agencies all over the country. Even before that situation they realised the desirability of giving this power to the Commonwealth and they gave it. As I say, it is even more, a fortiori, now that that industry is an Australia-wide industry, both in life and general insurance, and that power ought to be exercised by a responsible parliament. I do not apologise for the references which I make now to paragraph 8 of the Commission's report. It has been said that we ought not to proceed with this matter, that we ought to leave it to the States and not take Commonwealth action. The Commission had this to say about that in paragraph 8:

Given the existence of Commonwealth power over the vast majority of life insurance contracts and, equally, over a large majority of general insurance contracts covered by the Commission's proposals, Commonwealth legislation ought not to await agreement following attempts at a Ministerial level to obtain uniform, complementary, State legislation. To delay action pending agreement in such a matter might be a formula for inaction. There is a pressing need for reform of the law relating to insurance contracts. As the private sector insurance industry is organised and regulated on a national basis, it is appropriate that the laws which govern the relationships between the industry and the public should also be national in character. Commonwealth legislation to effect the present recommendations would not place the private sector at a disadvantage compared with State Government offices.

So I think there is no doubt about the need and no doubt about the fact that the States have requested and want this. They do not want to see themselves setting up eight different registering agencies, eight different systems the cost of which somebody has to pay. It will either be governments or, more likely it will be the people who take out insurance policies who will pay for it in some way or other. I suggest that this is a total waste. It is not the same situation of, for example, registration of lawyers, because they are controlled under State Acts and there is no Federal power to deal with them. But in the case of the insurance industry, this is a responsibility which we have as a Federal Parliament. The Government, in its reply, which I referred to, and which was delivered by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, made what I think are four different arguments. I propose to deal with them individually. It was said in the first place that there was really no need for Commonwealth regulation, that the States could do it, and it had been traditional. As the Government states:
Such a need has not been established.

It also recognised that the States traditionally are the regulators of intermediaries such as solicitors and estate agents and in areas of general consumer protection. Honourable senators will note that it was the State Ministers responsible for consumer affairs who asked for the Federal legislation. I think I have answered that as far as the lawyers and these other bodies are concerned. There is a different situation in regard to them. Here we have clear Commonwealth power. The Commonwealth Parliament has already intervened and taken action in regard to insurance. We have the Life Insurance Act of 1945 and the Insurance Act of 1973. There are certain regulatory bodies and commissioners operating already in this field. As is proposed in the Bill they will play a very active role in the regulation of brokers. So we are already in this field but we are not yet effectively in it. Obviously during the period we have been ineffective in this field there have been great losses and we cannot deny the responsibility to an extent for that. It was also said in the Minister's speech that there has not been very much loss really. She said:
We are fortified in our approach to this matter by the fact that the vast majority of broker transactions have been conducted in a satisfactory manner.

She went on to say that the figure of losses is small, and represents less than 0.1 per cent of premiums handled by brokers. Of course, superficially that sounds attractive but the important thing is that in any of these regulatory activities it will be found that most of the people are honest and most of the payments will be honoured. But the amount of $20m which appears to have been defaulted in the last 10 or 12 years is still very substantial. It is also, I think, important to note the extent to which a number of these companies are involved in many small claims and many individual claims. I think it was in respect of the one-stop insurance body that there were 34,000 separate claims. I think that is significant. One of the interesting statements on this matter was made by Mr Nick Renton of the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, after the Government had indicated that it would not implement the recommendations in the report. He said:

Opponents of legislation to control insurance intermediaries sometimes point out that losses from broker failures represent only a small proportion of the total premiums involved. Mr Renton said that such arguments completely overlooked the fact that if a client is hurt by a broker failure then his personal loss can be one hundred per cent of his premiums and in some cases could be one hundred per cent of the payments he was entitled to expect in the event of a claim.

This occurs not only because a person has paid his premium to a broker, found that he was not covered and then very often that the insurance company will not meet the claim but also because brokers often default on payouts on claims. The claimant loses the whole of that claim. Possibly the claimant is in very great need of the money from that claim because of an injury which has been suffered. Consequently, I suggest that the losses argument is not an answer to this problem. The losses are quite considerable. Regulation in the interests of the honesty of this industry and particularly, as the honourable senators will see in what I have to say, because the industry wants it as well, are reasons for the legislation.

The third argument that was put forward by the Government on this subject was that self-regulation should be tried. The Minister said that the Government's view remains that the most effective approach to the basic issues relating to insurance brokers is the development of sound self-regulatory practices. We know, as I have said before, that the Government has toyed with self-regulation on occasions in the past and then has changed its view. In fact, self-regulation is rejected by the industry. In this industry, which is not as big as some others but which is big enough, it is agreed by practically all parts of it that self-regulation is not satisfactory to deal with the matter. The report of the Law Reform Commission considered this aspect very closely. I want to read to the Senate from paragraphs 125 and 126 of the report which deal with this proposal. Paragraph 125, which gives examples of evidence that was before the Commission, states:

It is not without significance that it was because of the danger of anti-competitiveness that the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, in its submission to the Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, specifically rejected broker self-regulation.
The report of the Commission quotes from that submission in these terms:

. . . this Department recently strenuously opposed suggested legislation which would have had the effect of limiting competition in the insurance broking industry. This Department was concerned that if the legislation was enacted brokers would have been permitted to engage in collective anti-competitive conduct, without the government directly supervising it to ensure that it was in the public interest.
That point was made by a department of this Government. Further, in speaking of the competence and self-interest that would be involved in self-regulation, the report goes on to state:

But even if the competence of brokers as administrators could be guaranteed, the prospect of decisions being taken by members of a relatively small occupational group who may have a direct or indirect personal stake in the outcome of those decisions is simply unacceptable. As the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange-
Honourable senators will recall that that important Committee of this Parliament stated:

. . . regulation of a securities market involves inquiry into fraud or abuse which will not be voluntarily confessed and with respect to which governmental investigatory power is needed. We do not believe that such investigatory power or the power to apply sanctions should be conferred on a 'self-regulatory' body. We consider that such powers should be entrusted to the administrative executive and judicial arms of government.

I rely therefore on the Committee of this Parliament with its repute as supporting the case I make against self-regulation. The last major argument which is used in the Minister's speech is that somehow there are divided views in the insurance industry about this self-regulation of the industry. Senator Evans in his second reading speech said:

. . . there has been a striking unanimity in the calls for compulsory regulation of brokers, for professional indemnity insurance and for implementation of the Law Reform Commission's other recommendations.
It was stated on behalf of the Government:

In fact, we are advised by the major insurance industry bodies, representing both insurance brokers and underwriters, that they are most concerned about a number of provisions of the kind contained in the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can tidy them up.

—Of course, as Senator Watson says, we can tidy them up. But in fact I have been very careful to ask the various parts of the industry about this. Sure they have different views about some aspects of the Bill. But at the same time they are quite determined, and quite unanimous as far as I can see, about the need for regulation by the Commonwealth. I read to the Senate earlier a note from the Australian Mutual Provident Society from its statement about the agreement which exists but I also read this further note from a letter recently written on this subject by that Society. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Evans has said, there is a good deal of unanimity within the industry on many points. On the other hand there are some aspects where it seems most unlikely that any compromise will ever be reached, because of the differing commercial interests of the parties.

I ask the Senate to note therefore that one expects that those different views will never be satisfied completely but of course there is agreement upon the need for regulation. The letter from the AMP goes on to state:

It is for this reason that the Society has steadfastly maintained, as a mutual organisation concerned for the public welfare, that self-regulation will be sheer impossibility, and that the Federal Government (hopefully not eight State and Territory Governments) must act as ''umpire'' to protect consumer interests.

I point out that this society is important in the sense that it has between 30 per cent and 40 per cent of the life business in this country. In addition-I briefly give to the Senate these other views-the Insurance Council of Australia Ltd, which represents the general insurance section, in a letter to me dated 25 August the Council stated:

For some time this Council has expressed concern at the lack of control over the operations of insurance brokers. We believe that it is essential for Federal regulation of this important sector of our industry. However, there are a number of provisions in the Private Member's Bill which may create difficulties for insurers and brokers.

I have discussed those areas with the Council and although I do not at this stage support the alterations which it has made, I think there is considerable merit in the argument it has advanced. If the Government is to consider this Bill, seriously of course, it ought to look at those matters. In addition in a Press release the Life Insurance Federation of Australia stated:
A speedy announcement by the Commonwealth is necessary, as several State Governments are contemplating their own legislation.
I interpose to say that I think Western Australia has already done so. The news release continues:

In fact, Western Australia has already introduced its own Bill. LIFA strongly believes that separate State measures would be a poor second best and that all insurance regulation is an appropriate subject for national legislation.

In addition the Australian Consumer Association has supported Federal legislation. Finally, the Confederation of Insurance Brokers of Australia-the people most directly affected by registration-in the editorial in the latest copy of its report states:
We were very disappointed when the Commonwealth Government announced that it would not proceed with the introduction of legislation to regulate the activities of brokers.
Because of this decision State Governments are now proceeding independently to prepare and implement legislation in each State.

CIBAust and IBA are working closely with representatives of each State Government, including the Northern Territory, but it is already clear that there will be differences in legislation being introduced by the various States.
No matter how carefully State legislation is prepared clearly it will not be as cost effective as a National system.

The public service in each State will have to be involved in the administration of the local Act, brokers who operate in more than one State will face the additional administrative costs of complying with supervisory requirements in each State and so on.
Although the Commonwealth Government decided that there was no cause to regulate insurance brokers, the State Governments obviously disagree and are determined to proceed.

Given this, surely it would be in the best interests of taxpayers, the insuring public and the insurance industry if the Commonwealth Government were to acknowledge the fact that there is a desire by Government across the Nation to regulate insurance brokers and this could be achieved more effectively and efficiently through a centralised national system introduced through the Commonwealth Parliament.

I cannot think of putting it in any better way than it has been put by the very people most directly affected by this legislation. I think that answers the last of the arguments raised by the Government against the Bill.

As I say, I support the Bill. I believe it is a matter of judgment and I have made it very clear for some months that I am persuaded very strongly by the arguments raised. I have discussed this matter very fully. I have not heard very much, I am afraid, from the Ministers or the Government on this subject but I have pressed it-I make no apology for that-among my colleagues. I have given what assistance I can give by bringing facts before them about this matter.

I know that in the course of debate on this Bill there has been some criticism by some sections of the industry. There is a feeling that multi-agents ought to be included with brokers and regulated in the same way. I have certainly found some persuasiveness in those arguments. But I fall back finally on the Australian Law Reform Commission and its belief that this is not necessary and not desirable. But I say again, in whatever form this Bill goes through this House I think the Government should look at this particular problem.

The second of those major problems is a question of time limits and a desire by some of the insurance groups to amend clause 13. The problem is that many of the brokers hold back money and the insurance companies maintain that they do not have sufficient control to deal with this aspect and that credit control is necessary. On the other hand again the Australian Law Reform Commission does not see the necessity of this, and it heard a lot of evidence on the subject. It has been pointed out to me that cases where there has been default mostly relate to small brokers and that they are the people over whom the insurance companies have or ought to be able to exercise reasonable control. I say again that there is quite a strong argument for such a provision.

I support the Bill. I trust that my colleagues, having heard the argument over the last few months, will also support it. I believe that there is a strong prima facie case in all circumstances for the support of the Australian Law Reform Commission. Its recommendations should not be turned down unless we are satisfied that they are unsound. I have seen no reason to believe that they are unsound and therefore I trust that the Senate will carry this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to support the Bill proposed by Senator Evans which is very similar, as Senator Missen has just pointed out, to the Bill appended to and recommended by the Australian Law Reform Commission's report No. 16 of September 1980. The report determines that while there were differences of opinion within the industry on the exact form of controls which should be introduced, all elements favoured controls to protect the public against the embezzlement of premiums, insolvencies by brokers and professional misconduct. The industry is greatly disillusioned by the lack of government investigation.

SPEECH.PARA: My investigations have shown that the registration system recommended by the Law Reform Commission falls far short of what many in the industry feel is necessary. Perhaps the Commission was influenced by Treasury submissions that the controls should be as few and inexpensive as possible. Nevertheless, it is very clear that the industry prefers to have something rather than nothing at all. Worse than that, if this Bill is not passed the industry will be saddled with negotiations with eight different State and territory authorities and, ultimately, with a patchwork of differing State and territory statutes. This negotiation and these statutes will cause great expense to the industry and thus to the insuring public.

It is of no use for the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to talk of the Commonwealth's lending its aid to achieve a uniform State and territory system. The States are already proceeding on widely divergent paths and the lessons of workers compensation legislation, the companies and securities legislation and all the rest make a mockery of the suggestion that we can get uniform State legislation with the assistance of the Commonwealth. It is clear that the Commonwealth does have the power. It also has the existing insurance legislation and the experience which the States clearly do not have. It has the responsibility to see that policy holders are protected, and not by unnecessarily expensive State and territory schemes.

Government spokesmen have raised the bogey of a new bureaucracy to administer the Law Reform Commission's proposal. In fact, this is nonsense. The Bill does not propose a new bureaucracy; it does not propose a new police force; it does not propose new imposts on the Commonwealth. All sections of the industry-insurers, brokers and agents-have said that they are willing to take on the work and the expense involved in regulation so long as they get the legislative backing essential to make the regulation work.

The Australian Democrats made it clear when this Bill was introduced last May that they supported its concepts. I and my colleagues have had many discussions with representatives of the industry and we have had voluminous correspondence on the subject. The Bill was designed to meet the needs of both the insured public and the industry. A number of amendments have been made at the suggestion of various people within the industry and other interested parties. We believe that this Bill is the best solution to the problems revealed in the Law Reform Commission's report. It is the simplest approach that can be adopted in view of the conflicting interests withan the industry and the urgent need for the public to be protected. I commend the Law Reform Commission's report to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that I may be one of a few Government members, along with Senator Missen, to support this private member's Bill which seeks to control and regulate certain activities of insurance agents and insurance brokers. I do so with a very good reason. I believe that in Australia today too many innocent Australians are being ripped off-I repeat the words 'ripped off'-by some unscrupulous operators who are giving the decent people in the industry a bad image and a damaged reputation. I am here to protect those people in society who cannot help themselves. I believe this is one of the important roles of politicians and I seek to use that position to support this Bill tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: Although there is a call for less government intrusion into business, I believe that it would be wrong and an abrogation of my parliamentary responsibilities to the people whom I represent to allow on an occasion like this the Bill before us tonight to lapse. Therefore, I will support the Bill. In doing so, I do not really believe that I am in any way embarrassing the party that I represent in this chamber. After all, this is a private member's Bill. I believe that essentially the Bill flows from the deliberations of the Law Reform Commission.

Many words are spoken by politicians about the problems of being bound by party dogma and discipline but I believe the private members initiative in bringing forward measures such as this are indeed good for democracy. I believe that appropriate Bills, the right Bills with the right wording, should be encouraged. On the other hand, I recognise that it is very difficult for a private member to be able to muster sufficient support to pass a Bill. Some members may have utopian ideas and the implementation in the practical world of those utopian ideas may be difficult. I believe that this is an attempt to seek some justice in a difficult world. I believe some changes are necessary to the Bill. But let us talk about the Bill; let us get it towards finality: Then, perhaps, the appropriate amendments will come. Let us not wipe it off the slate in the first instance.

The Bill attempts to do a lot of things. But in an attempt to do a lot of things-for example, in income tax law-one will essentially get inconsistencies and problems. This Bill is attempting to provide a code of ethics, to protect innocent and uninformed individuals and to set penalties. Naturally for these sometimes conflicting ideals-these are just some of them-there is criticism or praise depending on one's philosophy towards the legislation before one. But I believe that the Bill is a step in the right direction. There are some shortcomings. My own attitude would tend to suggest for example that there is a need for the trust bank account to be audited by a registered auditor or accountant-at least once a year-in the same manner as solicitors' trust funds are audited. There is no point in having a trust fund if no one will exercise discipline or control over that fund. An independent audit by a registered company auditor, for example, would provide that discipline and would report differences and deviations to the appropriate authority. I believe that this is essential if the Bill is to succeed.

While section 25 attempts to ensure that the insurance brokers give certain information, I believe that there is an escape clause in sub-section (2) where some of the more astute could tend to seek shelter under, say, section 15. I believe that the more astute and the more devious will tend to seek this type of protection. Also registered insurance brokers are deemed to be the agents of the insurer. This is a commendable provision. But, unfortunately, the funds-this is the inconsistency -do not have to be handed over immediately or even expeditiously by the broker to his principal, that is, the insurer. I trust that the lawyers with wisdom and integrity will put together a form of words with an appropriate provision to overcome this problem and also to require appropriate audit of the trust account.

Some people may say that these remarks could destroy the intent of the Bill. However, it must not be seen to give brokers and insurance agents what I refer to as a protected or closed shop situation thus not allowing an entirely clean industry. I think some cynics could say that this is what the Bill is trying to do. They would attack the Bill on this particular score. In our Federation, there is always the danger of each State enacting laws for the protection of its own citizens although the implications of some of those laws could flow across State boundaries. Therefore, we have a problem of different standards and different laws. For example, a person could be insured in one State and require the insurance in another State. I believe that, through the multiplicity of State laws, some people could escape some of the obligations and penalties of individual State laws. Hence we do have a need for a Federal law to govern this area.

As in the company area, where we are moving towards Federal regulation, I believe that it is appropriate, to avoid difficulties of standards and ethics in law, that we should attempt to make sure we get as soon as possible a statute. (Quorum formed). Before the quorum was formed, I referred to the problems of having different ethics and different standards with different laws in various States where, for example, a person could be insured in one State and the agent be in another and so on. With this possibility there could be opportunities for unscrupulous people, by virtue of moving contracts between States, to overcome individual State laws. Hence we have a need for a Federal law to cover insurance agents and brokers.

I return to the problem of differing standards. There is recognition of this in the Bill. I acknowledge that the Insurance Council does not like this aspect of brokers and agents being the agents to the insurer. But I believe it is important to have this relationship. Some people may argue that we need go no further than this and that, having established this relationship, there should be sufficient discipline by the insurers over their agents to exercise sufficient authority. Coming back to the question of bank accounts and the agent being able to invest money on his own account, I would have thought there would have been a moral duty on every honourable agent to hand over to his principal as expeditiously as possible moneys to the company that is going to carry out the insurance.

However, I believe it is here that these high ideals tend to break down since not only have the brokers power to invest in prescribed securities but the interest, dividend, or any other income which flows from that investment, need not be paid into that trust account. In fact, it can be paid into another account. The matter goes even further. That income does not flow to the principal; it does not flow back to the person seeking the insurance. The real problem lies in the fact that it flows to the broker himself. I believe that here we have a fundamental breakdown in the high ethical standards that we are trying to achieve with this Bill. I believe that this provision certainly needs amendment. Otherwise there will be a problem of hypocrisy.

I believe that, if we are to try to clean up the industry, we have to clean it up entirely and not allow these people to invest money except under very rigid conditions. The income flowing under those tight conditions must flow back either to the person who is taking out the insurance or to the insurer which is the company involved. In the present form this aspect is certainly open to a lot of abuse. Certainly, I will be looking to lawyers to formulate appropriate words to overcome this anomaly. We must make provision in the Bill so that those funds flow as quickly as possible from the agent through to the insurance company. Therefore we must limit those circumstances which permit the broker to hold funds in his account for what is an unduly long period. I believe that it is appropriate and proper for the Federal Government to legislate in this area. At the beginning I referred to the rip-offs that had occurred in the industry. Too much money has been lost on the general insurance side. Earlier tonight my colleague Senator Missen referred, I believe, to some of those circumstances and to the extent of some of the losses as a result of defalcation. If we can eliminate or reduce that it will be a very good thing.

To my understanding, the more recognised life assurance companies and the Insurance Council, according to a letter I have received, appear to support the Bill. However, the Insurance Council has reservations about clauses 10 and 11. Clause 10 places liability on the insurers for agents' conduct and clause 11 provides that certain insurance intermediaries shall be agents of insurers. I disagree with the Council's view, since this responsibility is fundamental. Reputable insurers, such as the CMLs, the AMPs and the Royal Insurance companies of Australia, would exercise their proper and appropriate obligations. Unfortunately, in recent years we have seen the emergence of a number of fly-by-night companies. Some of my colleagues would argue that the Bill should go no further than establish this principal-agent type of relationship, but unfortunately a lot of these newcomers to the life assurance and general insurance business scene are not as morally responsible and may be called fly-by-nighters or sharks or be given some other appropriate description which would indicate self-interest or rip-off. That is what I am determined not only to identify but also to try to eliminate from the industry. That is the purpose and intent of the Bill and it is what we, as senators, should see fully enacted. Laws are made not for the honest, the upright, the principled but rather for the exploiters of this world. Regrettably, laws, regulations and sanctions go only part of the way and I do not believe always get the real crooks. Western Australia and Queensland have statutes which regulate brokers and South Australia and New South Wales could well be moving in that direction in the near future.

To illustrate the general confusion and the multiplicity of bodies involved, I point out that six State life assurance bodies and one Federal body constitute the Life Underwriters Association, which has some 2,000 members. Unfortunately they exercise no overriding power concerning individual members. Some argue that the Association should be able to discipline itself, but there are no sanctions and there is a multi-agent situation. Because of the advent of these new companies to the insurance industry, cut rate premiums are offered and excessive commissions paid to certain brokers just to buy business. Although excessive bonuses are promised in regard to life insurance, it is not until a person is deceased that his relatives realise that perhaps he was sold the wrong sort of policy. There is a need to protect people from that sort of operator. Those who seek protection and pay for it must be looked after, otherwise the widow is placed in a distressing situation. All too often, as politicians, we see the financial plight of people who have been unable to protect themselves and who have been exploited. I, for one, am not going to stand for that and therefore will support the Bill.

I repeat, the situation is confused because there are various State and Federal bodies and an absence of discipline. Agents with whom I have had extensive discussion all agree on the need for this Federal legislation. I hope that tonight, or at a later date, the Senate will resolve to look at some of what I might refer to as the self-interest clauses which might unduly help brokers. I believe that certain purging amendments are necessary to purify the intent of the Bill. Over the years the problems of the general insurance industry have been exacerbated by the strength of the brokers in the general insurance industry, who are said to be milking the general insurance companies dry. One has only to look at the profit performance of many of the insurance companies which operate in Australia to see the truth of that remark. If one is not satisfied with that-because there are always exceptions to the general rule-one need only look at the annual report of the Insurance Commissioner, who complains constantly about problems created by low level premiums, cut throat competition and difficulties within the industry, but some of the main problems arise from what I refer to as multi-agents, who exploit their position by directing business to the company which offers them the highest commission, kick-back or reward. Perhaps we should consider registering these multi-agents.

The Bill contains a provision which requires the furnishing of a document showing the amount of commission or payment received by them and this must be communicated expeditiously to the person who has taken out the insurance. I hope that such a provision will be adequate. If a person sees that someone is going to get several thousand dollars, or an unreasonable reward, as a result of his taking out insurance possibly he will give thought to going to somebody else who might take a slightly reduced commission and thereby lower his premium or give him greater benefits or bonuses. So a provision which requires a person to state the emolument or commission that he is to receive should be sufficient inducement to weed out the less scrupulous in the industry. I support the Bill but hope that in due course appropriate amendments such as I have suggested will be agreed to. I repeat, I support the intent and purpose of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to support the Bill introduced by Senator Evans. I will not delay the Senate unduly. I, as well as many other senators, have a plane to catch at 7 o'clock in the morning, so I will speak in brief and general terms about the desirability of such legislation. However, at the outset I must commend two of my colleagues for their role in getting the Bill to this stage. The first, of course, is the honourable member for Hawker in another place, Mr Jacobi, who, for over 10 years has sought persistently to have legislation such as this implemented. We can learn from the history of his efforts that no matter how necessary and desired legislation and reform may be, the road to reform in this parliament and country is extremely hard and difficult. The other person I must compliment is Senator Evans who, despite facing hurdles tonight, has been able to succeed in having this piece of legislation introduced and debated in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation that we are discussing tonight is not radical. Its history has been well documented in earlier speeches. I will not go into any great detail but the need for the legislation has been shown time and time again over the last 12 years. The Australian Law Reform Commission, in its report in 1980, presented the draft Bill which is very much the subject of our debate tonight. In its report the Commission managed to document that for the 10 years to 1979 insurance brokers had gone insolvent to the extent of causing a loss of $7m to consumers. Since that time, in the years 1980 and 1981, a further $7m has been lost to consumers because of insolvencies. The need was great in 1979, when the matter was presented to us by the Australian Law Reform Commission. The need has become much greater in the last two years, as can be evidenced by the facts.

As I said, the Federal Government has shown great reluctance in supporting this piece of legislation. However, that has not always been the case. In April 1976 the Acting Treasurer at the time gave a commitment that the Government would introduce supervisory legislation to cover that field. That was a follow-up to the Bill prepared by the Whitlam Government in 1975; it was a follow-up to legislative measures taken in Queensland as early as 1960; and it was a follow-up to legislation enacted in the United Kingdom in 1977. However, the Government, having made that commitment early in 1976, time after time since then has moved itself away from that initial commitment. In March 1977 it revoked its promise and said that it would be looking at a system of self-regulation of the industry through the Insurance Brokers Council. Then, in 1979, the Treasurer announced that no longer would the Government look at that sort of system but rather that a system of voluntary regulation would be implemented. Six months later the whole commitment of the Government to reform in that area was scrapped. To quote another person in another time, the Government in this respect has taken 'more positions than can be evidenced in the Kama Sutra'.

The States have recognised the need for such legislation. As late as November 1980 a council of State Ministers met and decided that Federal legislation should be enacted. In the meantime, three State governments have adopted measures to implement some type of regulation of the industry. What we will have has been very well stated by Senator Siddons, who spoke before me: We will have a mismatch of legislation; we will have a number of organisations implementing legislation with no real consistency, with no real ability to have consistent regulations and industry controls. That was something which the Australian Law Reform Commission in its 1980 report, suggested was vital. That is something which the Government, by its inactivity in that area, is disregarding.

The problems involved, which this Bill tries to meet, are varied and wide-ranging. They range from the ability at the moment for anybody, irrespective of their qualifications or background, to set up in the industry, be it as a broker or an agent. At the moment one does not know how liquid or financial a broker or agent is when one deals with that broker or agent. We are not talking of petty amounts of money; we are talking about big business and millions of dollars. In fact, the Australian Law Reform Commission indicated the amount of money involved in the industry. As I mentioned earlier, we also talk of collapses which in 12 years have involved over $14.3m. The need for regulation is there. The Government has not responded to that need. However, I am pleased to note that the Government honourable senators who have spoken thus far in the debate tonight have accepted the Bill, albeit in principle.

As I said, the needs are many. I list them very briefly without going into them to any extent. I have mentioned the way in which a broker can set up business without training or qualification. There is the way in which the moment brokers are bound to, or heavily influenced towards, the policies of one particular company, be it by some type of financial commitment or otherwise. but what derives from that situation is a situation in which brokers find that they deal with companies that give them the greatest commission. Those companies might not be those which offer the best security for their clients. In this respect it is the interest of the broker that is primary and not the interest of the person for whom he or she is acting as agent. In that respect one also looks at the further danger that a person interested in obtaining insurance can be seriously misled by incompetent, careless, biased or dishonest advice. It is the advice not of the honest broker but of that sort of broker which this legislation attempts to cover.

At the moment there is no clear cut, coherent code of financial practice governing the handling of money by brokers on behalf of insurance companies. The Law Reform Commission report in that instance, recognised that there very well could be a situation in which, because of insolvency of a broker, an insurance company might also find itself in financial difficulties. Of course, we have also the other area of concern; that is, that in the case of insolvency of brokers, consumers lose money in one of two ways: They may have to repay their premiums, but in many instances, as has been instanced time and time again in the last twelve years, they may find themselves in a situation in which they have no insurance at all because of the deliberate action of brokers to maintain funds in their own accounts in order to obtain financial gain from those funds. I believe that previous speakers in this debate have canvassed the area quite widely. As I said earlier, I do not want to speak too long on this area. In summing up, I give one quotation from the Law Reform Commission report No. 16 on insurance agents and brokers. I turn to page 81 of that report, which at paragraph 127 states:
The recommendations for imposing regulatory controls on insurance brokers are directed primarily at ensuring financial probity.
I can now understand why this Government, with its ministerial record, does not accept that financial probity should be applied in government administration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill 1981. There seems to me to be an unholy alliance at this stage. At one point in my career in this Senate I was called 'the underwriter' by Senator Wheeldon, who was the Minister for Social Security at a time when the Opposition was trying to nationalise the insurance industry. I have had a continuing interest in that very important sector of the Australian economy. I think that people often tend to disregard the significance of the insurance industry in Australia. That industry is committed to providing a considerable amount of revenue for the Government for its purposes. I think that for some time now this measure has been requested and desired, yet the Federal Government has chosen to sweep it under the carpet repeatedly, although I think that inherent in some of the previous activities of the present Government is an admission that something of this nature may be required. But it has never accepted the challenge associated with it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Law Reform Commission gave consideration to submissions made to it by the industry. In many instances, although the Law Reform Commission recognised some of the points made by the industry, it did not entirely agree with some aspects of the industry's submissions. However, I think that the Law Reform Commission has made a good contribution in this matter. The industry stated in a submission to the Law Reform Commission:

. . . a multi-agent (i.e. an intermediary who acts as agent for more than one insurance company in respect of a single class of business) operates like a broker, in that he is free to recommend to his client which insurance company (out of those for which he acts as agent) will best suit the client's needs. To this extent the multi-agent, like the broker, acts as agent of the insured not of the insurer. Secondly, it may be difficult or impossible for an insured who receives wrong or misleading advice from a multi-agent to determine to which of the agent's principals he will be able to have recourse for the conduct of the agent.
The Law Reform Commission's response to that was:

It is in the public interest that there should be a clear demarcation between agents and brokers: any insurance intermediary other than a regulated broker should be deemed to be the agent of the insurer . . .
In the second paragraph it goes on to state:

. . . the problem of recourse to an insurer for a multi-agent's misconduct arises only with respect to conduct during the (usually) short period of time before the multi-agent identifies a particular insurer with whom the insurance will be placed-from that moment on, that insurer is liable for the conduct of the multi-agent in relation to that contract of insurance (Bill cl. 10 (1)). The limited risks to the public which arise before particular insurers are identified do not warrant the additional regulation of tens of thousands of life and general multi-agents for the sake of requiring them to possess professional indemnity cover.

The Commission that was set up to examine this subject goes on to give other reasons why that submission does not entirely appeal to it. I think it is significant to realise that the industry wants some sort of regulatory control over agents in the interests of the protection of people. I think it is evident throughout the community that some agents have not acted in an entirely ethical way and have offered enticements to their clients to accept propositions which are not soundly based or in the best interests of the client concerned. I think that has been quite clear in many cases where people have been coerced into undertaking an insurance cover either in the life or general area. In the long run it has been shown that the cover has not been in the best interests of the client who the agent purports to serve.

Secondly-this is quite important to me and it has been mentioned before by previous speakers in the debate-the six States of the Commonwealth agree that it is a requirement and a necessity to bring some regulatory control into the whole industry. That weighs very heavily on me and persuades me to support the Bill quite clearly. Some people may suggest that the Commonwealth may not have the constitutional power to do this but I am assured by reading the background papers that have been presented that that is not the case. The Commonwealth clearly has the constitutional power. I have checked that with my learned colleague, Senator Missen, who has reinforced that conclusion. I believe it is a requirement that should be introduced. This is a necessary Bill that should be passed in the interests of the industry at large and the community that that industry serves. With those few remarks, I hope that the Senate will support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am opposed to the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill and the amendments for two reasons.
—Shame!

—I am not surprised that Senator Withers says: 'Shame'. It is well known that he has supported the insurance industry for years. That should teach him to interject. The first reason I oppose the Bill is that its introduction would be yet another interference by the Federal Government into commerce in a completely non-useful way. Secondly, my State of Western Australia has already legislated quite well, thank you very much, and I am quite certain that the Premier of my State would say exactly the same as I am saying. The State has legislated quite effectively to prevent the excesses of crooked or careless brokers. We have to concede that there has been quite obvious crookedness on the part of some people and, on the part of others, outright carelessness with moneys that were entrusted to them.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that I am not really impressed by the insurance companies' case which seems to attempt to drive brokers out of business. The companies obviously do not like being harrassed by brokers who, on behalf of clients, will always seek the best deal for those clients. The biggest problem for me and others who are concerned about this situation is that, as Senator Watson pointed out, there are many simple, good people who are robbed by the unscrupulous and the smart. This happens in any industry, not just in the insurance industry. The big problem is how far one can go to protect people who have money in their hot little hands. As we all know, one is quickly parted from the other. There are some people who thrive on doing that; it is their living and their businesses to do just that. Our wonderful English language is so comprehensive and varied in meaning that it becomes almost impossible to frame laws about commerce which do not have holes. Senator Withers, as a well-known lawyer, would know--

TALK.START.PARA: —How do they manage in Western Australia, then?

—Senator Evans, who interjects, would know that what I say is true. The holes in the legislation which we try to frame are of a size that would allow a team of horses to drive through. In fact, a panzer division could not only drive through the holes; it could drive all over them. Honourable senators know that that is the whole essence of the laws in commerce; it is impossible to protect members of the public completely from those who are determined to rob them. I can see that it is our duty as legislators, when there is sufficient evidence, to try to protect people. We are here on their behalf to protect them if we can. But as I have said, the difficulties of doing that sometimes leads us into greater difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the Western Australian State Government has done the job of protecting the public in Western Australia sufficiently well for me, as a Western Australian senator, to accept that and to say that we in Western Australia have reasonable protection. Therefore, I do not want Commonwealth legislation which may confuse, interfere with or attempt to override Western Australian laws on this matter or-I will say this while I am on my feet-any other matter. I think we have sufficient difficulty between the Commonwealth and the States now and, for the sake of my own skin, I do not intend to spend too much time emphasising those difficulties. They have gone on for a long time. There is enormous resentment in many of the States, particularly in Queensland and Western Australia, about the interference of the Commonwealth Government. Already I, as a comparatively new senator in this place, have found myself in situations where I have had to spend a lot of time explaining what we are doing here. That does not seem to be understood by people in the remoter parts of this continent, particularly in Western Australia and Queensland. I will not contribute in any way to the difficulties that already exist. I think we can say, as a general statement, that there is far too much legislation about everything.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—Hear, hear!

—I am pleased to see that there is some agreement with that statement at least. The time has come for us to look at some of the laws we already have on the books, examine them and see whether we can do without them.
—Like abortion law.

—The only trouble is that that particular law is not upheld. It is there. It is a good law. However, I will not be diverted, as I seem to be too easily, on these matters. The whole problem is that we have too many laws about too many matters which cause confusion in this country. I invite the Opposition, and the absent members in the political centre to give consideration to some of the laws we already have. Let us spend time in eliminating them, because there are far too many. I cannot agree to have the Commonwealth involved in legislation like this which will exacerbate the problems among the States and certainly I will not vote for it.

SPEECH.PARA: As I recollect what Senator Evans had to say, it seemed that he made a very good case for doing something about the laws of Canberra as they relate to Canberra. There may be some point in that but certainly the bulk of Senator Evans's case and his amendments should encourage the States of this country to legislate on these matters themselves. We should not, as the central Government, be involved in matters like this. We are involved too much and too often. That is the cause of the difficulties among the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know that Western Australia wanted the Commonwealth to legislate two years ago?

—Yes, but history records that the Western Australian Government has legislated for this. The laws are there. I would have to say, as a Federal parliamentarian and as a senator, that Western Australia does not need these laws that the Opposition proposes. I am aware that I take a slightly different line from some of my colleagues and from honourable senators opposite. Senator Jessop said that the industry has asked for regulation. Frankly, I find such a request absolutely horrifying. Whatever evidence is available to us, inquiring as we do and from moving about the country, from our constituents who complain that they are being robbed by unscrupulous brokers should force the States to take the necessary action. But, when the industry comes to the Government and asks for guidelines and regulations, I would say that that industry is in a very sad state of repair.

SPEECH.PARA: The worst thing that any industry can do is ask the Government to be involved. It is the worst thing. It has ruined more industries than I can enumerate this evening. Sure, the Government will come in; it is only too anxious to do that. As I said before, instead of spending our time profitably in eliminating some of the unnecessary laws, regulations and ordinances in this country, we want to get involved in more. Sure, the Parliament will always respond to a request by industry for more regulation. After all, that is our business. We love it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The cock crows twice.

—The note I have just received is not very complimentary at all. I will not tell the Senate the text of a note that was handed to me in another place a few years ago. It was more disrespectful than that. In any case, Senator Jessop's statement that the industry had come and asked us to regulate horrified me.
—I did not say that. I will have to get up and explain. You are misrepresenting me.

—I am sorry; that is what I heard the honourable senator say. That is a travesty. We know already why the insurance companies have come to us. I have already said that the insurance companies have come to us for one reason only: They do not like the competition that they are forced to be part of when the brokers go about and look for good prices for their clients. This sort of regulation will stifle competition. I concede the necessity for legislation if we have enough complaints from our constitutents about being robbed; but the only concession I will make is that the legislation should be State legislation, not Commonwealth legislation. That is why I will be opposing the Bill and the amendments.

—I wish to state the Government's position with regard to the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill. The Government's attitude was quite clearly spelled out during the speech of the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, during the second reading debate in this place on a previous occasion. The Government will not proceed with the introduction of any legislation along the lines recommended by the Law Reform Commission for the regulation of brokers. Substantially the arguments that have been put down by Senator Martyr on this matter are the ones which the Government generally supports. Clearly our position is that we oppose this Bill and we will continue with that attitude throughout.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am indebted to honourable senators who have spoken tonight for, for the most part, their careful, thoughtful, well researched and conscientious contributions to this debate. I am grateful also for the contributions made not only originally by the Australian Law Reform Commission, on whose shoulders my effort and that of Mr Jacobi ultimately rest, but also by those representatives of all the various parts of industry who have been so active in recent weeks and months in talking to all of us and putting their points of view. Not only have they put their views as to the necessity of national legislation-in fact they have been unanimous about that-but also they have put different points of view as to what the contents of the legislation should be. It has been very helpful to those of us on all sides of the chamber in reaching here tonight what seems to be very close to a consensus.

SPEECH.PARA: Several criticisms have been made of the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill, most notably in the original second reading reply of the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, back in August and also tonight by Senator Martyr and more briefly by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner. Those criticisms seem to be five-fold: That no demonstrable need has been established for the Bill; that no demonstrable benefit would flow from it; that the costs involved in applying the resources needed to police it are not justified by the return to the industry or to the community that would flow from that application; that the industry is not in fact completely unanimous as to every jot and tittle of the content of the Bill; and that there is no need for legislation of this kind so long as the States are capable of enacting their own legislation.

Given the time and the anxiety of most honourable senators to have this matter wrapped up tonight if possible, I will not say anything more about the questions of the need or the benefit that would flow from this legislation. Senators such as Senator Missen very amply stated that case tonight, as indeed have several others. Nor will I say anything about the state of play within the industry except to acknowledge the fact that, as I have indicated, not all sections of the industry are completely happy with every aspect of the Bill. That is inevitably the case with major regulatory legislation of this kind. Compromises are inevitable and not everyone will be perfectly happy. But it is certainly inaccurate to convey, as Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle did originally in her reply, the impression that there is genuine hostility to this. On the contrary.

Let me focus on the two questions of the resource cost of this legislation and the capacity of the States to produce a satisfactory solution in this area. In regard to the resource cost of the legislation it needs to be said, and said quite clearly and specifically, that first of all, there is certainly no necessity or justification for superimposing a new and highly costly structure for the receipt and investigation of complaints in relation to offences or potential offences under this legislation, given the existing avenues for consumer complaints through the Consumer Affairs Bureau, the Trade Practices Commission and of course the offices of the Insurance Commissioner and the Life Insurance Commissioner, not to mention the existing industry organisations. Where it appears to any of these bodies that an offence may have been committed under the legislation, the matter can, should and will be referred to the Australian Federal Police for investigation and, if necessary, prosecution. To the extent that we are talking about an elaborate enforcement apparatus being necessary, that enforcement apparatus in fact will be the existing police force.

The second point is that it was never intended to establish investigative machinery within the offices of the Life Insurance Commissioner or the Insurance Commissioner because the emphasis in this legislation is on establishing standards of conduct with which all participants in the industry are obliged, subject to heavy penalties, to comply. Obviously there will be a degree of scope for evasion but the Law Reform Commission is confident-I think honourable senators who have spoken tonight are equally confident-that the vast majority of insurance operators will comply and that the prospect of heavy penalties for individuals will be, in itself, a very severe disincentive to illegal conduct where there is any possibility, as there will be, of that conduct coming to light subsequently, not least in the context of insolvencies.

The remaining point that needs to be made about costs is this: Staff duties and the kind of staff quotient that we contemplate being involved in the apparatus established under this Bill will be quite limited. The staff will be involved in no more than the registration of brokers, the receiving of fees and the checking that insurance requirements of the basic kind have been met. The commissioners have the power to order an inspection and audit of a broker's accounts. Clause 33 covers the worries that I think Senator Watson had in that respect. But this power is expected to be used sparingly and the cost of those audits can be expected to be covered by the brokers themselves.

To the extent that it is possible to do any arithmetic about this, it is our estimate that the costs of establishing this kind of secretarial apparatus will in fact be covered by the registration fees themselves. If we base our calculation on an estimated registration of about 1,000 brokers nationally, and that is out of the existing estimated population of between 2,500 and 3,000 intermediaries which are presently describing themselves as insurance brokers but, of course, not all of them are properly so described, and if we base the calculation also on a registration fee of around $200 per broker, the administrative budget for the whole exercise would be about $200,000 only, which would allow for two permanent staff plus a couple of casual staff together with the costs of phones, rent, equipment and so on. That will in fact produce a situation where we have a thoroughly manageable apparatus within the framework of a self-financing registration system.

The costs to a small broker, looking at it from his point of view, we would estimate roughly as follows: The annual audit of the insurance broking account, the centrepiece of the regulatory apparatus, about $500; the minimum payout that would be required for professional indemnity and fidelity guarantee insurance, which is also a central component here, about $1,000; a registration fee of about $200; creating a total annual liability of about $1,700. They are the sorts of orders of magnitude we are talking about. I think it is important to get that into perspective, not least in the light of things like the Age editorial of 25 May 1981 which came up with this extraordinary proposition:
The draft legislation would require the creation of another 50 to 60 Public Service positions and cost the taxpayers more than $1m per year to operate.
The not very invisible hand of the Treasury is at work again, I think, when we are looking for a source for that piece of inaccurate and wholly misleading data.

The remaining point to make in response to the criticisms that have been advanced of the Bill, particularly by Senator Martyr, tonight relates to the capacity and enthusiasm of the States themselves to legislate in this area. I think the basic point to be appreciated is that as late as November 1980 the consumer affairs Ministers from all States, including Western Australia, were requesting explicitly, overtly, on paper that the Federal Government implement the Australian Law Reform Commission's recommendations as a matter of urgency. What has happened subsequently, with the Commonwealth announcing its position as it has, is that each State successively, regrettably, has been obliged to talk about enacting legislation of its own and in the case of Western Australia actually proceeding to such legislation. The difficulty about this, although the mere existence of that legislation does acknowledge the fact that everyone believes there is a need for legislation in this area, is the difficulty of keeping that legislation uniform across the country in a situation where we are often talking about what is essentially a national industry with nationally based insurance companies, many national sized brokerage firms operating around the country and a fast flow of cash to service the various clients involved. It is a national industry; it needs national legislation. Indeed, that national legislation has long been sought by the States themselves. For those reasons, I urge the Senate once again to follow the lead of the many honourable senators from all sides of the chamber who have spoken so carefully and effectively tonight in support of this Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Page 4, clause 10, leave out sub-clause (1), insert the following new sub-clause:
''(1) An insurer is responsible, as between the insurer and an insured or intending insured, for the conduct of his agent or employee, being conduct which-
(a) it was reasonable for the insured or intending insured in his circumstances to rely on; and
(b) was in fact relied on in good faith by the insured or intending insured,
in relation to any matter relating to insurance and is so responsible notwithstanding that the agent or employee did not act within the scope of his authority or employment, respectively.''.
2. Page 14, clause 28, sub-clause (2), paragraph (a), leave out '', as soon as it is reasonably practicable,'', insert ''forthwith''.

The first amendment is to clause 10 of the Bill. The amendment is designed to modify slightly the proposition contained in the original Law Reform Commission Bill governing the liability of insurers for the conduct of their agents, whatever it might be and whether the conduct of the agent went beyond the scope of the authority that had in fact been granted to the agent in question. It has been argued by some people, I think plausibly, that that perhaps imposes an excessive obligation in some ways upon the insurer in situations where no reasonable insured could possibly have thought that the conduct in question was in fact that of an agent acting as an agent. It is for that reason that the modification of language embodied in this amendment is in fact advanced.

The other amendment proposed is to clause 28, which relates to the obligation, again, of agents to pay over the premiums they receive to the insurer. At the moment that obligation is cast in time terms as an obligation to pay over 'as soon as it is reasonably practicable'. It has been felt, I think rightly, by some critics of the Bill that that is not sufficiently precise for the kind of financial obligation that ought to be involved here. The proposal in this amendment is accordingly to substitute the word 'forthwith'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support both amendments. It seems to me that they are both sensible and they have been asked for in discussion with industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I would like to pay a compliment to the sponsor of this Bill, the Industrial Democracy Bill 1981. I suppose it could be likened to the early British trade union movement developed by the Cadbury family in Britain. I think Senator Siddons's influence in the Victorian industrial relations area as a very benevolent employer is well known. There are two points to be made about the Bill. Its ramifications on industrial democracy have to be evaluated against some of the experiments in countries as far away as West Germany and Yugoslavia.

SPEECH.PARA: The one point I would make is that I understand that the honourable senator who sponsored this Bill is to meet the Australian Council of Trade Unions tomorrow. Our own party manpower committee has examined the Bill. It was very receptive to it in principle, but we realised that with our dual wage structure, with Federal and State awards, there would be areas about which we would certainly want to consult the trade union movement. The fact that this preliminary conference is taking place between the honourable senator sponsoring the Bill and the ACTU, I think, justifies the discussion being adjourned. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later date.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
