TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, there is some confusion.
—That is the understatement of the year.

—That may be regarded as the understatement of the session, but let me put it in these terms: What has happened in the last few minutes, if I can just enumerate it for those honourable senators who were not here, is that the Industrial Democracy Bill 1981 of Senator Siddons was called on. Senator Mulvihill spoke on that Bill for a few minutes and then asked that the debate be adjourned. It was then moved that it be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting. That was done by the Opposition in order to facilitate the progress of the business in the Senate tonight. Senator Colston's Bill was then called on, and I thought an agreement had been reached with the Government that that would be dealt with quickly, Senator Grimes having moved for the suspension of Standing Orders for it to be proceeded with and that motion for the suspension of Standing Orders being carried.
—That is what the motion is now.
—Yes. We are at the stage now where the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders in relation to Senator Colston's Bill is the subject of this division.
—What about Senator Siddons's Bill?

—It has been adjourned. It has gone. It might be helpful to the proceedings of the Senate if, under Standing Order 165, the call for the division were withdrawn and the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders carried so that the Bill can be dealt with very quickly, as I understand it would be. Then we would accede to any suspension of Standing Orders in order that the Government might bring on urgent business, which I believe it has. I suggest that that course be set.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Australian Democrats support what the Leader of the Opposition has said. We are quite prepared to allow this matter to proceed.

—Thank you, Senator. I do not want to appear to be holding you down, but Senator Button has given a very clear background to the motion before the Chair for the suspension of Standing Orders. Having cleared that, you have indicated that you support what Senator Button has said. I do not want an open debate at this stage of a division. If the Leader of the Government in the Senate wants to make some statement to the chamber I will call him, but I will ask him also to confine his remarks and to be very brief.
—Mr President, I would not have sought to make any comment but it is necessary to clarify the Government's position. The position tonight is this: The Government had--

—Mr President, I am endeavouring to respond to what the Leader of the Opposition said. He was given the opportunity to make a point and to ask that there be a clarification. I therefore seek leave to make a reply on the same conditions as applied to Senator Button.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation tonight is this: The Government had sought at 8 o'clock to continue the debate on two Bills that were necessary to function by early November. We sought that debate so that, if there were any messages to go across to the other place, they could be dealt with in another place and be sent back here. That mechanism was clear. It was the only mechanism that would work to enable the Bills to be dealt with. The Opposition insisted that three other Bills be given priority to take over the period of General Business for this evenang. The period for General Business this evening was thrust upon this chamber and was carried out.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact of the matter is that at 10.30 p.m. in the ordinary course of business the Industrial Democracy Bill, which was sought to be debated tonight, was called on. It was decided by the Opposition to change its tactics and to have another Bill called on. We have adopted the simple practice of observing the business that was called on tonight. I do not want to have to draw attention to Standing Order 68, but the simple fact of the matter is that it says that no new business shall be called on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, can I briefly point out that this division --
—Order! Senator Grimes, do you seek leave to speak? I did allow your leader to speak without leave to clarify the reason for the debate. Do you seek leave?
—I seek leave.

—I merely point out to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) that the reason for this division is to get over the problem of Standing Order 68. The reason for the opposition to the motion for the suspension of the Standing Orders quite frankly was the confusion of the Government front bench at the time. We can overcome Standing Order 68 by this very division. Honourable senators opposite are on the wrong side; that is the problem.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will proceed with the division.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Carrick) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) has moved that the Senate do now adjourn. I think it is important before the Senate adjourns that there be some understanding of what has taken place here tonight. I do not want to enter into recriminations but I think it is important that the position be on the record. What happened tonight, leaving aside the debate earlier today in relation to the social security legislation, which in part was somewhat acrimonious, was that two motions were moved, one by the Opposition and one by the Government, in relation to the program of General Business which would take place tonight. They were not voted on. Honourable senators will recall that they were not voted on for very obvious reasons-because neither side is succeeding much with procedural motions in the Senate at the moment. The position was accepted by us that the order of General Business tonight would be according to Senator Messner's amendment to Senator Robertson's motion. So what we had tonight was, first of all, a debate on the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill and that was disposed of by vote. Then we had the calling on of Senator Siddons's private member's Bill, the Industrial Democracy Bill. In order to facilitate the progress of the Senate's work and to facilitate the carrying out of the offer which was made quite explicitly by Senator Grimes this evening, that the Government could introduce its social security legislation and we would be quite prepared to deal with it tonight-that offer was made by Senator Grimes-Senator Mulvihill spoke on the Industrial Democracy Bill for just five minutes and then moved that the debate be adjourned. It was then resolved that the debate on that Bill should become an order of the day for the next day of sitting. That was done to facilitate the progress of the Senate's business.

SPEECH.PARA: The next matter which was due to be called on in agreed General Business order was Senator Colston's Bill, which has had a very chequered career in the Senate in relation to Senator Colston's capacity to have that Bill dealt with. The suspension of Standing Orders was moved in order that Senator Colston could bring that Bill on. I must say that I consulted at the time with both the Government Whip and the Minister in charge of the House, as I thought, about that Bill and I was told that there were no Government speakers on that Bill. So the intention of the Opposition was to bring that Bill on and dispose of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which Bill-Senator Colston's Bill?
—Yes, Senator Colston's Bill.
—Many speakers.
—I suggest that the Minister had better get his act together, as people say.
—I have the carriage of that Bill.
—Well, the honourable senator was not here. I find that an extraordinary admission to make. A Bill was called on in the Senate and the Minister in charge of it was not even here.
—We did not even hear it over the air; so you just watch what you are saying.
—It was our intention--
—You do not like it, do you?

—The Warrnambool redneck is coming in here to yell again. He always does so at this time of night. What we were concerned to do was to facilitate the progress of that Bill through the Senate, and we acted on the advice given to us by Government spokesmen that there were no Government speakers on the Bill. That Bill would have been disposed of very quickly and then we would have voted for the suspension of Standing Orders in order to bring on new business, namely, the Government's Social Services Amendment Bill.
—Would you have supported that Bill?
—I thought the Government--
—Order! Let us have a little more decorum in the chamber so that the Leader of the Opposition can be heard.

—I thought the Government's complaint was that the debate on the social security legislation had taken too long. It clearly did not take long enough, as it has not got through to Senator Teague yet that we would not be supporting that Bill in its entirety. We are not coming here under the sort of conditions put upon us by the Government that we support the Bill. It is not our function in this place to support anything the Government puts up, and that was not what we intended to do. That was made quite clear in what was described as a very long debate this afternoon. That was the course which we envisaged the Senate would follow tonight. I do not know whether the House of Representatives is still sitting.
—It is.
—I was told five minutes ago by Senator Carrick that it was not sitting, that its members had gone home.
—I did not say that.
—The honourable senator did say that to me. He should not deny it. He came up to me and said that the House of Representatives had gone home. That is what I was told.
—You do not like the cold steel, do you?

—The honourable senator is a know-all about all these things. Perhaps if he had been here he would have been able to contribute at the right time rather than now. That is what I was told. I was told that there was no point in the Senate's going on with any business tonight because the House of Representatives had gone home. I think that was said in heat. I think it was said in a spirit of huffiness rather than anything else, if I might use that word.

SPEECH.PARA: It was the Government which was concerned, I was told, to get the passage of the social security legislation, that moved for the adjournment of the Senate, and that is what we are now dealing with. I invite any honourable senators who have a contribution to make to the adjournment debate tonight to speak. I certainly would be quite happy on behalf of the Opposition to have any consultations with any competent Minister who knows what he wants to do in connection with the Government's legislative program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the matters of considerable interest tonight in the Senate has been the social security legislation about which there was some discussion earlier this evening. I understood that it was common ground that it was important legislation and that the Government was evidencing a little more concern than other elements in the chamber about the fact that if we did not process the legislation tonight there would be delays in payments which are to be made under that legislation. The proposition was put to the Senate that if it dealt with my motion at 8 o'clock or soon thereafter the Bills could be dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: I pointed out that if the Opposition and the Australian Democrats wished to make changes to the Bills we had the machinery to send messages to the House of Representatives. My motion included a requirement that the messages should be returned to us, and I offered the prospect that the Bills therefore could be dealt with this evening. That, of course, is one of the points which are still floating around in the subterranean currents in the chamber at the moment and which are causing some agitation and concern. As I said earlier, I have been agitated and concerned myself to see that the legislation is passed for the reasons that I will not canvass again. However, it is quite clear that further consideration of the Bills will take a considerable time. My own understanding was that, if we accepted that there was a way of meeting the objection which the Opposition had to several clauses in the Bill by sending messages to the House of Representatives, then it was perhaps feasible that the Bills could be dealt with, and indeed I had made every effort to arrange it so that the Bills could be dealt with.

It is not simply a matter of running over to the House of Representatives and saying that we have done something. It does require certain technical things to be fulfilled. Compliance with section 56 of the Constitution is necessary if one is to make a change to those Bills as is a further message from the Governor-General to the House and so on. It is not simply a matter which can be dealt with by saying that we will do it any time of the day or night.

The brief conversations that I had with some of those concerned with the legislation indicated to me that it was thought that there would be many more hours of debate. There would probably be some constitutional dispute about the ways in which it was dealt with. Senator Grimes indicated to me, and I understand that he has indicated this publicly, that he is not going into any debate with any conditions imposed. So the position is that we have no chance of dealing in an orderly manner with these Bills, of getting them to the House of Representatives, of having them dealt with and of getting a message from the Governor-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, let us go home if you do not want them.

—That is precisely the point that I am trying to explain to the Senate so that a lot of the agitation might be eased. I thought that there was an invitation to give some indication. I indicated at 8 o'clock that I thought that this legislation should be given priority. I indicated that the mechanism was available to enable us to get a message to the House of Representatives, if that was the will of the Senate, and that it could be processed this evening. That is no longer the case. We can, if we wish, stay here and, for the edification of those who like to think that Parliament is a pretty hopeless place, try to prove them right. I personally think we have got past that point. We have clearly got past the point where this legislation can be passed tonight, and I believe therefore that the Senate should now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to clarify the issue and give a contrary view to that which we have just heard from Senator Chaney. I made the offer on behalf of the Opposition, shortly after 8 o'clock, that after General Business was dealt with tonight we were perfectly happy to deal with Chaney's Bill, the Social Services Amendment Bill. We could have finished the second reading debate and gone into the Committee stage and moved our requests on clauses 18 and 21 without much debate. The Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats had made the reasons for their objections to those two clauses perfectly clear. Those requests could then have gone to the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The House of Representatives is still sitting. Opposition members of the House of Representatives have been told that they can be expected to sit into the early hours of tomorrow morning. Those requests could have gone over to the House of Representatives, been considered, come back here and we could have sat tomorrow as we offered to do to consider those requests. The obligation is now on the Government. If it wants to complete this legislation, it can do so by allowing us to continue the discussion of this legislation tonight. It was not willing to do so. The Government was not willing to do so because I believe Senator Chaney got his messages garbled.

I believe it is still possible under the Standing Orders for Senator Chaney, if he is fair dinkum, to move for the suspension of Standing Orders so that we can very briefly consider this legislation tonight and send our requests to the House of Representatives. We offer to do so. We offer to come back tomorrow and consider any requests which come back from the House of Representatives. It is obvious the Government does not want to do that. It wants to make cheap political capital out of the fact that this legislation did not get through this House today.

This legislation, which involves 28 per cent of Budget expenditure, was debated in this House for only a couple of hours today. The only contribution we have had from the Government was four minutes from Senator Walters-someone who is notorious for getting up and taking her full time. The opportunity is there for the Government to suspend Standing Orders to bring this legislation on. If the Government does not want to do so, so be it. If the Government is saying that the single unemployed will have their increased payments delayed by a short time, it is the Government's responsibility; it is not the responsibility of anyone on this side of the House. The ball is in your court. Do what you will with it!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight, in discussion with the Australian Democrats on this matter, the impression was conveyed that there would be quite some hours of debate.
—Nonsense!

—That is something that perhaps Senator Grimes could tell the Australian Democrats. Am I to understand that Senator Grimes is saying that there will be no debate tonight, that procedural matters will be put and that the Social Services Amendment Bill will be dealt with in a quarter of an hour or in half an hour? I will explain the situation to honourable senators. If in fact that was the position, and has always been the position, why was it not done between a quarter past eight and a quarter past nine tonight? Why was the consideration not given between those times so that the Bills could have been debated under those procedures. Quite clearly, the intention was that it would not be done that way. Am I being told now by the Opposition that in the space of half an hour, or something like that, this matter can be disposed of? Am I being told that?
—Of course you have been told that on our behalf, but ask the Democrats.
—Am I being told that quite clearly by the Opposition?

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the Leader of the Government to resume his seat. As I understand it from the Chair, the Leader of the Government is giving some indication to the Opposition. He is looking for clarification as to the situation. He then wishes to do the same with the Australian Democrats. I ask that the Leader be heard in silence so that he can be fully understood. If there are interjections, he will not be understood.
—Mr President, I make the point--

—Mr President, I do not think that the explanations given in this chamber are doing anything but exacerbating the situation. Might it not be better if somebody else who has a contribution to make in the adjournment debate spoke so that the leaders or the deputy leaders of the respective parties can discuss the matter and resolve on a course of action that is satisfactory to all parties?
—Mr President, may I indicate on behalf of the--
—Order! Senator Mason, are you seeking to take a point of order?
—I wish to--
—If not, I ask you to defer to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. He had the call, and I interrupted him.
—I will, but, Mr President, I wish to speak after the Leader has concluded.

—Mr President, I believe the motion before the Chair is that the Senate do now adjourn. Our leader has made the suggestion and invited honourable senators to speak on the adjournment while perhaps some--
—Order! The Chair asked the Leader of the Government to resume his seat. As far as the Chair is concerned, Senator Carrick still has the call. I call Senator Carrick.
—I was saying that the situation, as understood by the Government, was quite clear--

—My apologies, Senator Carrick. I have been informed by the Clerk that I overlooked that as you moved the motion for the adjournment you must seek leave if you wish to speak again without closing the debate.
—I seek leave.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I have no intention of trying to close the adjournment debate. I make the point that, quite clearly, tonight the intention was that there would be a very lengthy debate; otherwise the matter would have been disposed of before. A totally new situation has occurred. I consulted, as did Senator Chaney, with the Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Mason) who indicated that he considered that there would be a lengthy debate. I take it that there is now some change to that advice. I am perfectly prepared, if it will help the occasion, for the three party leaders to adjourn for a very short while to clarify the situation. If that is the intention, I am perfectly prepared to adjourn with Senator Button and Senator Mason to see what is the intention. If the intention is that a procedure could be so brought about that in an expeditious period we could deal with the measures here and send them to another place to be dealt with there, quite clearly I would be prepared to co-operate. That was never the understanding and, clearly, it was never the intention earlier tonight. I now invite the leaders to come and discuss that matter with me.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MASON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —That invitation is acceptable to me after I have had the opportunity of having something to say in this chamber and of putting our position on the record, which I think is absolutely essential in this matter. Indeed, if conversations that I have had with the Leader of the Government (Senator Carrick) are going to be quoted in this place, I think it is fair enough that I explain the context. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I did have more remarks to make on the Bill; but, in view of the situation at this stage of the night and the desire to get through the legislation, I will conclude my remarks at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of the frequent complaints that have been made about the failure of Government senators to support this Bill, I really do feel that I must make a couple of remarks in closing. They will be brief but I do wish to have the record clear. The first thing I would like to say is that, at my request, Government senators did not put themselves on the speaking list, for the reasons outlined by Senator Walters-briefly, to endeavour to ensure that we could reach these Bills, deal with them today and have them passed into law.
—I wished to make a long speech.

—Senator Teague interjected that he wished to make a long speech and I understand that a number of honourable senators on this side wished to speak in support of the positive aspects of the Bill. I will not canvass at length the matters raised in the debate but I draw attention to the fact that this legislation represents the minor part of the changes made to the social security payments system during this financial year. The major part of the payments are made under the automatic indexation provisions and were referred to in the second reading speech. The annual cost of the increases which are granted automatically in respect of pensions and benefits this year is of the order of $700m. It would have been very easy, from listening to the major debate, to forget that this year we are looking at a social security budget which is $35m short of $10 billion-an increase of $1,265m or 14.7 per cent over last year's figure. I just say that to indicate the framework within which only limited discretionary changes could be made to the system.

SPEECH.PARA: During the debate Senator Grimes suggested-other honourable senators referred to it also-that there was a need for a more selective approach to welfare. I point out that the changes made do generally meet that category. I do not believe that anyone would dispute that the increase in the supplementary assistance to pensioners and the assistance to single unemployed are in that category. Although there was criticism of the change in family allowances, in that it was not selective, I point out that even Professor Henderson suggested that the position of poor families should be tackled by making considerably increased payments to large families. I believe that if one examines the speeches made on the Bill one will find a considerable amount of conflict between speakers on the other side about whether it is desirable to be more directive, but that will have to wait for another day. Usually I have to thank honourable senators on the Government side of the chamber for their support of a Bill. On this occasion I have to thank them for their restraint in trying to reduce the time spent on the legislation with a view to getting it passed. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

With respect to an item of great contention upon which presumably brief speeches will be made in Committee-the question of reducing the right to unemployment benefit of spouses of strikers-I can only say that whilst that has been described in this chamber as an example of the Government using the social security system for industrial purposes I ask honourable senators to contemplate whether indeed it is not a case of the reverse being true, of the present social security system being one which provides a buttress to the industrial situation and ensures that the burdens which are incurred when strike action is taken are not borne by those who are responsible for taking the strike action but are spread to taxpayers generally. Whilst it was said during the debate that many letters had been written objecting to what is proposed in the legislation, I can only say that I received much correspondence objecting to a situation in which the taxpayer generally is called upon to subsidise the cost of strikes in this community. It is a matter on which I have had a great deal of correspondence and I believe that there is a very strong feeling in the community that that situation should not occur.

Needless to say, the Government opposes Senator Grimes's amendment and does not accept it. In the interests of brevity I will not canvass all of the items. I simply say that we reject all of the points listed in the amendment and commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Grimes's amendment) be added.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

It is obvious that any legislation introduced into this place which will impose a penalty on the innocent-in this case, the wife of a person involved in an industrial dispute, or the spouse of a person who has lost entitlement to receive the unemployment benefit-should not be tolerated by this Parliament, this Committee or any other place. It is for that reason that I have moved this first request to excise clause 18 from the legislation.

Clause 21 (Special benefits).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Pages 10 and 11, clause 21, leave out the clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition again opposes this request.
—You will be the Opposition soon.
—The Government opposes this request for the reasons set out in the second reading speech. That was not a Freudian slip. I just have a bad memory. I am always six years behind the times.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the request (Senator Grimes's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill should be re-drafted to-
(1) Remove the discrimination in the provision of supplementary assistance against those in government housing;
(2) provide repatriation benefits for those who served in peacekeeping forces before 1 November 1981, and
(3) provide eligibility for service pensions for all Allied ex-merchant mariners as is provided for Allied ex-servicemen'.

The amendment is self-explanatory. The first part of the amendment refers to the discrimination against those in government housing and is the same as the amendment which was moved to the Social Services Amendment Bill. It refers to the fact that those in State government housang will not be able to receive supplementary assistance. We believe this discriminates against those people and we believe that that discrimination is unnecessary.

In regard to the second part, we believe that repatriation benefits which will be provided to those who serve in peacekeeping forces after 1 November 1981 should be provided to those Australians who served in peacekeeping forces before November 1981, in particular those who served in Kashmir, in the Middle East or in Cyprus. We see no justice in introducing these benefits for people who serve after 1 November 1981 and not for those who have served before then.

In regard to the third part of the amendment, the Government has promised on many occasions-many Government members support this-that allied ex-merchant mariners would be provided with service pensions. We believe it is quite wrong to provide these pensions only to Australia ex-merchant mariners when many persons who are presently Australian citizens or residents served in war zones during the last world war as Allied merchant mariners in conditions which were as dangerous or more dangerous than those experienced by some servicemen. I think the reasons for the amendment are clear and it is for those reasons that I have moved it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to rebut the arguments of Senator Grimes in respect of the amendment he has moved. In particular I refer to the second part of his amendment which is in connection with peacekeeping forces. It relates to the period prior to 1 November 1981. This is a matter which was decided by the Budget Cabinet as part of its policy and it is the undertaking that was given in the Budget Speech. With regard to any other representations on this particular matter, of course the Government is prepared always to consider them in terms of the Budget context.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the third part of the amendment regarding allied ex-merchant mariners, as has been pointed out in the Senate on previous occasions, the Government's position was to support Australian ex-merchant mariners and, therefore, it moved to extend eligibility for service pensions to that group of mariners rather than to the broader group at this stage. This is a matter of using the resources available in the best possible way on behalf of Australian ex-servicemen and those other categories of ex-servicemen and beneficiaries who are entitled to benefits under repatriation legislation. In the light of the hour, the Government opposes the amendment. I wish the legislation a speedy passage.
Amendment negatived.
