SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a Bill in relation to the provision of senators for the State of Queensland. I think it would be worth while to read the relevant part of the Constitution so that we know precisely what it is we are debating. That part states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate shall be composed of senators for each State, directly chosen by the people of the State, voting, until the Parliament otherwise provides, as one electorate.

But until the Parliament of the Commonwealth otherwise provides, the Parliament of the State of Queensland, if that State be an Original State, may make laws dividing the State into divisions and determining the number of senators to be chosen for each division, and in the absence of such provision the State shall be one electorate.

The important proviso there, of course, and the reason that this Bill is before this chamber, is that the Constitution says quite clearly 'But until the Parliament of the Commonwealth otherwise provides'. This is not a matter for the State Government; it is a matter for the Commonwealth Government.

If I relate some of the history leading up to the inclusion of this provision, I think it will be clear why this provision was put in the Constitution and why the Commonwealth ought to make provision under that section. Initially it was conceived in the constitutional conventions that the senators would be chosen by each State parliament. That remained the settled opinion of the conventions till well into the 1890s. At the juncture of 1897 there was generated some considerable debate about the selection of senators by the State parliaments. At that time Queensland and New South Wales had upper Houses nominated by the Crown. The argument propounded at that time was that since these Houses were not elected by the people it would be undesirable to have Federal senators elected by any legislation one branch of which was not elected by the people and therefore was not responsible to them. The argument was put that it was highly desirable that senators representing the various States should be elected on a uniform basis, but there would be no such uniformity if some senators were elected by nominated chambers and others by chambers deriving their existence directly and democratically from the people.

That proposition was debated most strenuously with people taking opposing sides for quite some time until it was finally settled that indeed the people ought to elect the senators; that senators ought not to be elected by the State parliaments. Once that became the settled view it was a very simple step to move to the provision which is now currently embodied in the Constitution; that is, one State, one senatorial electorate. The view was easily pressed, and with great force, that the people of each State in choosing senators for that State should vote as one constituency. It was argued in the conventions that if a State were divided into electorates and if a locality became the guiding principle of selection, the special purpose for which the Senate was constituted would be obscured. That purpose was that each State should be represented as a whole, as one entity, and not as divisions or sections.

The counter argument proposed to that was that the election of senators was a matter of State concern and that each State should be allowed to decide how the senators were selected, by whatever means and whatever type of divisions they so chose. That was in fact opposed by all the leading members of the conventions. It was pointed out that if such a proposition were adopted it would endanger the principle of State representation in the Senate and would indeed prevent in some cases and in some States a fair view of what the people of that State might decide. It was further argued that local representation was adequately provided for in the House of the people; that is, the House of Representatives.

That then became the settled view and the clause which was agreed upon to go into the Constitution was the first paragraph of section 7 of the Constitution. However, at the last hour at the Premiers Conference in 1899 the Queensland Premier, in response to a vote that had been taken in the Queensland Parliament some eight months previously in which it was decided to divide Queensland into three States, argued forcibly that he could not possibly bring Queensland into the Federation unless an additional provision were provided. That provision is currently enshrined in the third paragraph of section 7 of the Constitution. I will come shortly to the proposition in respect of new States. But I believe that the idea of new States was the basic underlying reason why that item was included in the Constitution. I invite the honourable senators who feel that that may not be the case to read the transcript of that Premiers Conference, which is readily available.

The situation is that the Premier of Queensland, as shown in the transcript, made it quite clear that he was happy and he felt that the State of Queensland would be quite happy if that recognition of the regional differences which existed in Queensland were contained in the second paragraph of section 7 of the Constitution. He made it quite clear that he was happy that the power to take it out be reserved to the Commonwealth. The argument has been propounded from time to time that, if the clause were taken out and if any action were to take place under this provision, that type of action ought to be initiated by the State Parliament. Unfortunately the proposition that it ought to be initiated by the State Parliament is based on an historical inaccuracy. History makes quite clear where the Premier of Queensland stood in 1899, why he argued for that provision and why he was satisfied that the power to act under that provision ought to be retained by the Commonwealth, not by the State of Queensland. I think it is extremely important to make sure that what we are arguing about in historical terms is understood by everybody because there has been some fair misconception of this whole proposition over the 80 years of Federation.

The arguments in relation to the item have been canvassed exhaustively by Senator Colston in his second reading speech and I do not intend to go through them again. I simply raise the point that what we would be looking at here is the possibility-a possibility which, by the way, was discussed in quite some detail at the conventions-of a gerrymander. It was not put in those terms. The terms were that by a careful adjustment of the boundaries of districts and the grouping of populations within those districts a State parliament would be able to colour unduly the political principles of the senators returned for the State. That is a nice way of saying that a group of people would be returned from a State because of the way that those boundaries were drawn.

What we are looking at here pre-dates the solidification of the party system. The major concern of the Premier of Queensland at the time was that Queensland could be subjected to far too many protectionists lumping themselves into the Senate so that free trade in Queensland would be disadvantaged. But, of course, the party system soon solidified and in six to seven years into the Federation this proposition about an undue colouration of the political leaning of honourable senators who came here would and must now mean that we would have an undue weighting from one or other of the political parties, depending on who controlled the State Government at the time. I think that honourable senators in the chamber tonight would see that the proposition in relation to one State would not only colour the political affiliations of those honourable senators but also would have a marked effect on the Commonwealth Government.

The second point I would like to reiterate is that since 1949 the numbers have always been fairly close. We have changed the electoral system in the Senate in such a way as to create a fair distribution. What happens in that case is that any move on the part of Queensland to arrange boundaries for the election of senators would affect not only the honourable senators from Queensland but also all the governments of Australia. I believe that the change in the electoral law in relation to senators since 1949 must be given due weight and emphasis in any discussion in relation to movements on this constitutional item.

I return to the proposition in relation to new States. For a long time-indeed, ever since I grew up in north Queensland-I have been a promoter of the notion that we should have new States. One of those is that we ought to have a new State in north Queensland. I believe that such a move is long overdue. But I would not support this item because I believe that it would militate against north Queensland. It would not enable north Queensland to move forward with the thrust which is currently under way to gain a State government of its own which would be concerned, interested in and responsible to, the people of north Queensland. To attempt to move under this provision would enshrine the second-rate citizens standing that the people of north Queensland currently have. It will not enable them to move forward to what is their reasonable expectation; that is, if the Northern Territory can be a new State then north Queensland-which has larger infrastructures, a larger population, more transport, more educational facilities and more expertise in a whole range of primary, secondary and tertiary areas-and its people ought also to be able to look forward to a new State.

I speak as a strong supporter of the new State movement. I know that Senator Colston is not in agreement with me on that issue, but we coincide in our views that it is necessary that if we are to get any movement in this area, if we are to get justice for the people of Queensland either as one State or as more than one State, then it is absolutely necessary that the Commonwealth Government pronounce on this item.

It has been suggested that the situation could be left as is. After all, it has been going on that way for 80 years. I believe there are strong arguments why this ought not continue in relation to this provision. It was a temporary provision included for temporary purposes. The fact that no movement has taken place to date does not absolve this Senate-which must have a special interest in this item-or this Parliament from inaction if others have engaged in inaction. It is not a valid argument in any shape or form to point simply to the past and to the inactivity as to the reason why we ought stay our hand in relation to this. Neither is it an argument to suggest that the Queensland Government has no intention of acting under any of these provisions. I think no honourable senator could stand up in this chamber and rightly claim that he would be able to predict what the current Queensland Government might do or what a future Queensland government might do. Such a proposition could not be tested or upheld. It would be open to a party of any political persuasion, whether it be a National Country Party government, a Liberal Party government or an Australian Labor Party government in Queensland--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or a Democratic Party government?

—A government under any political party could seek to change those boundaries in such a way as to advantage itself in the Senate, and it could do that with great rapidity. I suggest that the urgency of this Bill lies in our recent history as well as in our past history. I think that the items surrounding the resignation of Senator Gair point very clearly to the fact that it is open to a State government to move with great rapidity in relation to any item that it so chooses. One wonders sometimes, looking at the forms of this House, how it is possible for State chambers to operate so efficiently from time to time when I am quite sure that if such a similar proposition were put to this House we would probably spend weeks debating whether we should even look at the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: This proposition is important for another reason apart from the ones I have already raised and that is, that Queensland is a State which, of all the States of the Commonwealth, is growing at a tremendous rate in terms of its population, its infrastructure and its industries. It seems to me that we need to make sure that Queensland has the possibilities and is capable of being treated in this chamber and in the Commonwealth as an equal. In that sense that particular provision is a concession that my State no longer needs. It is a concession which accepted that, because of internal problems, it was not possible to undertake a particular move.

Regional differences have not diminished. Rather, they have increased. But that very increase paradoxically means that we need to introduce this motion that the Commonwealth Government, as set out under the Constitution, ought to take action so that it is decreed that the principle enshrined in those conventions with one State, one senatorial electorate, ought to be enshrined not only in States other than Queensland but also in Queensland. As movement takes place, as growth takes place in Queensland, there will be increasing pressure-I hope successful pressure-for the creation of a new state in north Queensland. At that point it will be vitally necessary to have this out of the way because the creation of a new State in north Queensland, or a division of the State of Queensland, in constitutional terms, if this is left in, will raise the ticklish problem of whether the north of the State is allowed to have this provision or the southern part of the State is allowed to have this provision.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many senators would a new State get?

—I would be quite happy at any stage to have a lengthy debate in relation to the new States. The representation of States and new States within the Commonwealth is very clearly provided for within the Constitution. The Constitution provides that a founding State or an originating State cannot have less than six representatives. The proposition I think to be adequate would be to create an additional State in the Northern Territory and an additional State or two in Queensland. I believe Queensland is such a prosperous and growing State that it could very well support three States. What we would have then would be 60 senators-ten States, six senators from each State. There would be equal numbers, as we have now. I am certainly not proposing that we should have any more senators in this place-not unless, of course, we manage to increase our population to such a vast extent that that may seem to be desirable. The proposition that I am putting forward is that I hope the imminent division of Queensland into a number of States needs to be settled before we move ahead into the next item.

SPEECH.PARA: The legalities in relation to new States are relatively complex. There have been in fact a variety of judgments in relation to this. If the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) is interested in this item, he will be able shortly to purchase a book which I have edited on the whole legal and historical basis of new States. If he purchases that book-(Quorum formed). Madam Acting Deputy President--

TALK.START.PARA: —We were seriously interested in how many.

—I have just suggested to Senator Baume one possibility in which we could engage. The final reduction line without a change to the Constitution would be six. I think that clarifies the numbers in relation to that item. The proposition boils down to one simple item, that is, that Queensland's senators ought to be chosen on the same basis as senators from all other States. It is a simple equality of representation-equality of the methods of choosing senators. I believe, as it was argued in the conventions, that it would be intolerable for one State to choose its senators by one method which is at variance with the methods used by the other States. I believe the strength of the Federation has been based to a large extent on the type of power that this chamber can exercise and also on the type of moral power that this chamber has because of the way senators are elected. In any democracy, the very essence of a chamber is the way its members are elected.

SPEECH.PARA: So I suggest that the proposition enshrined in Senator Colston's Bill that Queensland's senators ought to be elected by the same method, in the same way and based on the same types of divisions as every other State, is one which is based on a democratic thrust, and that is equality of representation. The one difference with this chamber compared with the House of Representatives is that the House of Representatives is based on people and the representation of people. Senators represent people on a State boundary basis, not a population number boundary basis. That essential difference characterises the different thrust that this House has compared with the House of Representatives.

I believe that to maintain and to enhance the equality of this chamber we must secure that proposition, that is, that senators from Queensland be directly chosen by the people of that State voting as one electorate, and that the Commonwealth Parliament should make it mandatory for the States to operate in that way. It should make quite sure that the State of Queensland does not make laws pursuant to section 7 of the Constitution which would allow it to divide the State because to allow the State to act in such a way would not only divide Queensland but also would create a serious imbalance within the political structure of this country. It would create, I suggest, enormous instability within our parliamentary system.

I believe that that item ought now to be disposed of and that that instability ought to be taken care of because if there is anything that we are aware of concerning this chamber it is that it is necessary to repair a lot of the damage that has been done in this decade to this chamber and to the relationship between it and the House of Representatives. (Quorum formed). I was on my last sentence. The proposition which is contained in Senator Colston's Bill I believe ought to receive the support of the Senate in order to do two things: Firstly, to enhance the position of the Senate in the Federation; and, secondly, to make sure that the State of Queensland has exactly the same laws in relation to the election of senators as all other States and, it is hoped, of the new States which will come into being in the Federation.
Friday, 30 October 1981

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: (12.21 a.m.) I understand that Senator Jones was seeking the call. I imagine that there will be time for all honourable senators interested in this debate to speak. I was attracted to Senator Macklin's speech. I will make clear in my remarks as I proceed that the Government is quite attracted to the idea behind Senator Colston's Bill, the Senate Elections (Queensland) Bill. I want to make that clear at the outset. But I should like to start by commenting on one of the points raised by Senator Macklin, I think in response to a question asked during his speech, about the number of senators who might make up the Senate if there were new States. Senator Macklin indicated that it might be possible to have Queensland divided into three States and the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory classed as States. In that way we would end up with 10 States each with six senators. He pointed out that the Constitution provides that none of the original States would have less than six senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I sat down and did some pencilling and found that that is indeed a very quaint proposition. There are five senators, I think, from New South Wales in the chamber and five from Queensland. It is very interesting. The representation in the Australian Capital Territory, with its 200,000 citizens, would go from two to six senators. The Northern Territory representation would go from two to six senators and representation in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania would come down from 10 to six senators. I wonder who would be the ones to go. I can imagine the preselection battles. But the nicest part of Senator Macklin's suggestion is that Queensland would move from 10 to 18 senators. So his proposition, put with the highest degree of statesmanship as only a statesman could put it, would mean that all the populous States of the Commonwealth would lose senators. New South Wales, with its four million people, would come down from 10 to six senators. Senator Reid's State, with 200,000 people, would go up from two to six. Queensland, however, would go from 10 to 18. I understand that the honourable senator says that he is a north Queensland boy. I can believe him after that altruism, thinking only of the good of the Commonwealth, thinking only of the good of the Federation. We are looking forward to the book of which he says he has been the editor, and I would say that with that kind of logic I am glad that it is not a book on selling motor cars.

I should like to set down in a very calm way the events of about a week or so ago as I recall them. Senator Colston's Bill has been before the Senate for approximately two months. The second reading speech was made in August or some time thereabouts.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. It was first put down in March.

—Last week we tried to list for debate and for determination Senator Colston's private member's Bill. I believe that it was listed for debate during last Thursday afternoon in a program that should have allowed us to commence the debate and to have made some kind of decision. We were quite serious in our desire to discuss the Bill. I had advisers present and I had received advice. I had in fact advised Senator Colston of the course that I intended to take in dealing with the Bill. I made it quite clear and open to him what we intended to do. I had indicated to him our desire not to reject his Bill because many of the arguments that have been put are arguments that we find quite attractive.

SPEECH.PARA: What I did put to the honourable senator at that stage was that we were seeking to delay the Bill for a short period, and I will set that out later. If one reads the Hansard of last Thursday and examines the way in which the proceedings were conducted and the time spent on resolving matters one will see that at 5 p.m. we had not even got anywhere close to dealing with the Bill. We had hoped to have it through before the dinner break last Thursday. We were ready to do so. What has happened since then is that with the absence of Senator Harradine from the Senate this week a fortuitous majority has developed. This is an attempt-I do not blame people for their desire; they are members of parliament-to make use of that situation. But I still say that the course which we have proposed to Senator Colston is a desirable course to take.

I do not believe that one can look at the stated purpose of the Bill which is to ensure electoral justice and find that unattractive. Certainly we do not find that unattractive. The Bill does attract us. The problem with Senator Colston's Bill is not so much a problem that has to do with the substance of what he has proposed, although I will mention later in my remarks some concerns that have been expressed on expert advice we have received. But they are things that we can look at given some time. Our concern is not so much with the substance of the Bill but rather with the construction of the Bill-I will mention that point later-and with the problems of speed and timing and the proper way in which we should proceed. (Quorum formed).

I was developing an argument about Queensland's Senate representation. I started from the point of Senator Macklin's ingenious suggestion for almost doubling Queensland Senate representation. I had stated that the problems that we see with Senator Colston's Bill do not really relate to the concept, to the idea, of what he is trying to achieve. As I said, they relate to the construction of the Bill and to problems we have with timing and the proper way in which we should move so as to show courtesy to everyone involved and so that we can show, what one might call, fair dealing between governments.

Mr President, we know-you know, I know, we all know-what the numbers are in this place. I have no doubt that Senator Colston can look to a majority of senators, at some time or other, supporting his Bill and giving it the imprimatur of the Senate. The question that concerns us is: When is that proper time? Like Senator Macklin, I was attracted to the background of the Bill. Like Senator Macklin, I went back and looked at section 7 of the Constitution which, of course, has given rise to the concerns which have been expressed today. Section 7 of the Constitution states2
The Senate shall be composed of senators for each State, directly chosen by the people of the State, voting, until the Parliament otherwise provides, as one electorate.

I immediately make the point that this Parliament has the capacity to provide the worst kind of gerrymander in any State if it so wishes. That is stated in the Constitution. This Parliament could, if it determined, elect nine senators from Cape York and one senator from the rest of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —We couldn't do any worse.
—I think Senator Haines's colleague from Queensland might find that statement a bit difficult to wear. The Constitution provides--
—Read it all.

—I want to read the rest of section 7. The Constitution clearly provides for a gerrymander by the Federal Parliament of the Senate electorates. I find that one of the curious provisions of the Constitution. If we are going to look at the kinds of reforms which Senator Colston wants us to look at, the kinds of improvements he seeks to make and the kind of electoral justice he wants, should we not also consider the need for some kind of constitutional referendum to pick up this anomoly which would provide for a gerrymander by a corrupted national parliament, and should we not seek to deal with that as well. That is the first point that occurred to me on reading that section of the Constitution.
—It is a much more difficult proposition with the Senate, isn't it?
—Senator Macklin said that it is a much more difficult proposition with the Senate. I think it would require a simple resolution of both Houses.
—No, in political complexion.

—Well, it would require a simple resolution of both Houses to bring about an alteration. As I read that sentence of the section, it could be varied election by election. One could determine a certain electorate distribution for 1980 and an entirely different one for 1983. I say that that provision of the Constitution gives me some concern when I read it.

SPEECH.PARA: Section 7 of the Constitution further states:

But until the Parliament of the Commonwealth otherwise provides, the Parliament of the State of Queensland, if that State be an Original State, may make laws dividing the State into divisions and determining the number of senators to be chosen for each division, and in the absence of such provision the State shall be one electorate.
The remainder of section 7 makes a number of other observations which are not immediately germaine to what we are discussing.

I have been attracted, like Senator Macklin and other senators, to examine the way in which this section came to be written and in the way it was written, to try to examine the pressures which came to bear, which led people to put this quite extraordinary provision into the Australian Constitution and to examine what the consequences of that have been. Some quite interesting observations are available.

It would appear that the reasons for this special provision, relating to the election of senators for Queensland, lie in the historical conditions existing in the 1890s. In the Annotated Constitution of the Australian Commonwealth, Quick and Garran said that the provision was inserted in section 7 of the Constitution because of:

. . . the special circumstances of Queensland, its vast territory and scattered population, coupled with the fact that its population seemed to be naturally growing and developing in three divisions which may hereafter become separate States.
I found that quite intriguing. I will come back to that comment later.
Two other authorities on the Constitution, Lumb and Ryan, in the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia-Annotated said something quite different. They stated:

. . . the provision was designed to assuage the feeling of separateness prevalent in the northern and central areas of the State-feelings which had adversely affected Queensland's participation in the convention activities.
Of course, not everyone takes such a view of section 7 of the Constitution. Professor Colin Howard in his discussion of Australia's Constitution in a penguin book published in 1978 said on page 84:
The second paragraph of section 7 was a transitional provision for special conditions existing in Queensland.
He further said:
It is no longer of any force or effect.

I was quite attracted to the proposition that Professor Colin Howard would make a statement that most of us here would say is quite patently incorrect in view of the analysis we heard from Senator Colston first and then Senator Macklin, that is, that it is no longer of any force or effect. I think it probably is still of force.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was threatened to be used about four years ago.
—It was mentioned publicly in 1979. There was a fair bit of newspaper talk about it. I do not think that there has ever been a serious proposition that it should be used.

SPEECH.PARA: The question might then arise whether there is any validity still to section 7 of the Constitution. Is Professor Colin Howard correct when he says it is 'no longer of any force or effect'? That is a fair question to ask and it was asked of the Solicitor-General when this Bill was presented. The Solicitor-General was asked to advise whether the Parliament of the State of Queensland may still make laws dividing that State into divisions and determining the number of senators to be chosen for each division. He was also asked to state what steps would need to be taken by the Commonwealth Parliament should it wish to prevent such action. That would be an appropriate opinion to seek. He developed the argument at some length-probably at too great a length to read it to the Senate. However, he concluded by agreeing that probably the section does still have effect but he does not believe the State has been denied power under it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will it be possible to incorporate that advice?

—I will not seek its incorporation in Hansard but I will discuss it with the honourable senator and show it to him later if he wants to study it. I went back and looked at Quick and Garran's Commentaries on the Constitution. At page 421, in paragraph 70, they discuss Queensland in the context of section 7 and the concerns that have arisen. They say:

SPEECH.PARA: The circumstances which conspired to prevent the representation of Queensland in the Federal Convention are detailed in the Historical Introduction . . .
They give the appropriate pages. The first point that I wish to pull out is that Queensland was not represented at the Federal Convention. Difficulties arose out of the non-consultation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one was it?

—I think they are talking about early 1891. Queensland certainly was present in 1899. That is where the Premier of Queensland made the intervention that the honourable senator mentioned in his address. I shall continue the quotation:

SPEECH.PARA: At the Conference of Premiers which met at Melbourne in January, 1899 . . . Mr. Dickson, the Premier of Queensland, pleaded hard for an amendment in the Constitution enabling the Parliament of that colony, if it became an Original State, to divide it into divisions for the election of Senators and to determine the number of Senators for each division. The Conference decided that, although this concession would involve a departure from the fundamental principle, yet the Conference, considering the special circumstances of Queensland, its vast territory and scattered population, coupled with the fact that its population seemed to be naturally growing and developing in three divisions which may hereafter become separate States, and considering also that Queensland had not been represented in the Convention and was therefore deprived of the opportunity of having her views and interests adequately considered, decided to recommend the insertion of the special provision which now stands as the second paragraph of the section.
That Queensland would be an Original State was ensured by the affirmative vote of the people of that colony . . .

The problem which made this necessary was that Queensland had not been involved during the 1890s in discussions and had not been represented at the conventions. I am not saying that it had not been permitted. As Quick and Garran said, Queensland 'was therefore deprived of the opportunity of having her views and interests adequately considered'. That view was given sufficient weight in 1899 when that amendment of the Constitution was sought. I come back to where I began. We find considerable merit in what Senator Colston says. We believe that this provision has been present in the Constitution for 81 years. We understand that Senator Colston has set in train a process, but we do not want to go back and repeat the mistakes of the 1890s. I believe the saying is that people who fail to learn the lessons of history are doomed to repeat them. If it was inappropriate not to involve Queensland in the conventions in the 1890s, if it was inappropriate then that she was denied the opportunity of having her views and interests adequately considered, it is equally inappropriate now.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was by her own choice.
—Senator Macklin says that it was by her own choice.
—There was conflict between north and south as to who the representatives should be. That is why they were not there.

—I am merely drawing attention to the fact that it was not desirable then that the views of one of the States had not been heard on a matter which, in the end, affected it as it did the other States. I am making the point that the lesson we learned from 1899 is one that we do not want to repeat now. If ever Queensland might have used this power-if it had been a State capricious enough to want to use it-surely the political divisions and tensions of the last Senate election, which I mention with deference to my colleague, might have provided an ideal opportunity for seeking political advantage. There is no doubt about the result which would have been obtained had a certain division of the State been undertaken-no doubt whatever. It would have ensured a representation of senators that was different from the one which emerged. The State Government, despite its capacity to interfere, chose not to do so because, like us, it values the electoral process and did not want to interfere.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter does affect Queensland. We are interested in the views of that State. We are interested in knowing how the Queensland Government will respond to the proposition that there should be Commonwealth action as provided for in the Constitution. At this stage it is not a matter of confrontation between the Commonwealth and the State. What Senator Colston has done is to set in train a process. The only matter for us to determine is how that process should now be taken on. We are interested in knowing Queensland's view.

A good deal has changed since Federation and it has been suggested that it might not be unreasonable to conclude that the conditions which led to the insertion of the special constitutional provision no longer exists. For this reason, the general subject matter contained in Senator Colston's Bill has been, and is, one of the matters under consideration as part of the general review of electoral legislation by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman). I do not know whether we have made that clear to Senator Colston, but the issue which attracted his attention and led to his drafting a Bill has also attracted the attention of the Minister and has been under Government study for some time.

Given these facts, as a responsible Government, the moment Senator Colston's Bill was introduced we sought advice as to its legal and constitutional efficacy. Again we went to the Solicitor-General and obtained his advice. The advice we received-I have not the details-can be summarised as follows: First of all, the Bill as drafted, if enacted, probably would be effective to negate the power of the Queensland Parliament to legislate under section 7 of the Constitution. Secondly, significant improvements could be made to the drafting of the Bill to enhance its constitutional validity. I put it to Senator Colston that that is a very important consideration. He would not want any legislation passed by this Parliament in pursuit of a goal which he has identified as being desirable, as being appropriate, to be found to contain a drafting inadequacy which renders it open to challenge. Thirdly, such improvements would be desirable, though not essential, if there were a challenge to the validity of the Bill when enacted.

It was the view of the Solicitor-General that, generally, there would need to be some substantial reconstruction of the Bill. I do not have to point out to honourable senators, who no doubt have been following the passage of this Bill very closely, that it is in fact a brief Bill-it contains only two clauses. I think that for the Solicitor-General to say, nevertheless, that the Bill should be reconstructed has to do simply with the way in which the safeguards have been put into the Bill to achieve the goals which Senator Colston wanted to achieve. I merely relate to Senator Colston those concerns which have been expressed by the Solicitor-General. The Minister for Administrative Services, with that information, has been examining ways in which the Bill might more appropriately be couched if, in fact, it is desired to proceed.

However, the Government is of the view that before undertaking to exercise our rights under the Constitution and deciding to determine under section 7 how the electorates should be set up in Queensland the concept of the Bill, restricting as it would the legislative power of the State of Queensland-that is what we would be doing-should at least be fully discussed with Queensland. It should at least be discussed with the Queensland Government. At present discussions are being arranged between the appropriate Ministers of the Commonwealth Government and the Queensland Government. It is our view that those discussions should be expeditious; they should take place. But, pending the outcome of those discussions, the Government is of the view that it would be quite irresponsible for us to proceed further before Queensland has had an opportunity to express a view on a matter which would restrict its legislative powers.

Those honourable senators who believe in co-operative federalism might say that, whilst perhaps it is appropriate to consider moving in the direction in which Senator Colston wants to move, it is not inappropriate for us to consult Queensland, to advise it of what is proposed and to advise it on how we would like to move. It is not inappropriate for us to get the views of Queensland. It may be that Queensland has valid points to put to us which otherwise we would not learn of. I cannot see that there is any need for us to proceed quickly with this legislation before that consultation can be undertaken. The Minister for Administrative Services is out of the country this week. Before he left I asked him about the negotiations with the Queensland Government. He was able to inform me that contact had been made and that arrangements had been made for those consultations to take place. They are under way. They are required by the Government and they have been set in train. The Government is attracted to the proposition put by Senator Colston that there should be some tidying up of that section of the Constitution. The Government wishes to do two things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Back down to Petersen. What is the other one?

—Senator Walsh is very talkative tonight. It is a pity he does not attend all the divisions. I thought that members of the Australian Labor Party were not supposed to walk out and miss divisions. Perhaps he was occupied somewhere else. We will not ask too many questions. The Government wishes to do two things. It wishes to observe all appropriate courtesies. These involve at least discussing with the government of the State that will be affected the implications of what is proposed. It involves also an examination word by word of the proposed Bill in the light of some concerns expressed by the Solicitor-General.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not pretending that these concerns are an insuperable barrier. I mention them to Senator Colston because I know that he would want any Bill which went forward from this place to be impeccable in a constitutional sense. He would want it to be able to withstand any kind of constitutional challenge from any individual or any group that may wish to test it. This concern does not detract from our interest in the proposal, our interest in what Senator Colston has put forward or our appreciation of the service that he has done. What we are saying, however, is that we should delay a little while. My proposal is, since we think that we are coming towards the end of the session-well, we can think these things, if not this week or next week; certainly we are close to the end of session-to agree that at the beginning of the next session we will come back to Senator Colston's Bill. We will determine it and thus give the Commonwealth Government a known and finite period-two or three months-in which it can do those things which I have said are desirable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that an undertaking?

—Senator Mason, I am perfectly happy to give such an undertaking that we would bring this matter back early in the session. I come back to that section in Quick and Garran. They made the point that, whatever the reasons-Senator Macklin has pointed out that there were reasons-it was the fact of non-consultation which made some problems. It is my belief that they are problems which can be overcome. To give time for this kind of consultation to take place makes a lot of sense. I am not attacking and have not at any time in my remarks attacked the concept of what is in this Bill or the desirability of ensuring fair electorates for Senate elections.

SPEECH.PARA: It was in my mind to propose an amendment-I am not moving this amendment-to leave out all words after 'that' and to insert the words 'that this Bill be not further proceeded with until the first sitting day of the Senate in 1982 to provide an opportunity for appropriate and necessary government to government discussions'. The reason I will not oppose this amendment at this stage-one of my colleagues might do so later but at this stage we are not proposing it-is that if agreed to it would have the effect of taking Senator Colston's Bill off the Notice Paper. I think that is correct. Again, it is not our desire to have the Bill taken off the Notice Paper. Senator Colston would then have to go through the procedure of the introduction of his Bill, the second reading speech and everything else. That seems to us to be an unnecessary imposition on a colleague. One of my colleagues at a later stage might seek to adjourn the debate. If we could secure the adjournment on the basis of the undertaking that I have given this would enable us to keep the Bill on the Notice Paper and that would enable it to come back for debate at an appropriate time early in the next session.

I submit to the Senate that the course that we have outlined is really quite eminently reasonable. We are not opposed to what is being put up by Senator Colston in the Bill. We are attracted to the arguments which he advanced but we have a need to follow some procedures as a matter of courtesy and fair dealing. On that basis I am going to leave it to honourable senators opposite or to honourable senators who have taken part in the debate to respond to what I have offered. One of my colleagues who will be following me in the debate may wish to move an appropriate procedural motion at some later stage that would enable us to make some appropriate disposition of the Bill without, I hope, taking it off the Notice Paper so that it could come in for determination before too long.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Because the hour is late I think that perhaps we should not proceed tonight. I suggest that the debate be adjourned. I am not quite sure who adjourns the debate if that suggestion is taken up. Although I would like to see the Bill passed through this place and perhaps the other place in this session I would also like it to be passed in a spirit of co-operation on both sides. On that basis I am willing to accept the assurance of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) that if debate on this Bill is adjourned at this stage we can bring it back on for debate next February. I would like to have discussions with the Minister in relation to the drafting of the Bill. I received expert advice in relation to the drafting but I realise that experts can differ. I suggest that at this stage the debate be adjourned and we accept that assurance of the Minister that the Bill will be brought back on in February next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the debate be now adjourned.

I note that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) who is responsible for the Bill has given the assurances sought by Senator Colston with respect to bringing the Bill back in February. There is no misunderstanding.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives acquainting the Senate that it has agreed to the Senate's requested amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a third time.

I wish to speak briefly to that motion. The response to the message indicates, of course, that the House of Representatives has considered the request of the Senate. That would indicate also that the Government has considered the request of the Senate for the deletion of clauses 18 and 21 from the Social Services Amendment Bill 1981. That was what I indicated the Government would be prepared to do, that is, to consider the requests if they were made when I spoke at 8 o'clock this evening. The Government believes that these provisions should be enacted into law. It does not accept that the provisions relating to unemployment benefit should be used to protect trade unions against the effects of their actions.

Whilst the Government wishes to maintain the ability to provide the special benefit in cases of hardship it does not believe it is fair to the Australian taxpayers that they should subsidise the cost of strikes in Australia through their social welfare system. I therefore make it absolutely clear that the Government intends to pursue this proposal. However, to have pursued it by refusing the request would have penalised over 200,000 unemployment and special beneficiaries. Increased payments to them would inevitably have been delayed if the Government had rejected the requests and sent the Bill back to the Senate. This Government has no intention of allowing vulnerable sections of the Australian community to suffer because of the failure of the Senate to accept one aspect of the Government's proposals. Accordingly, the Government has accepted the requests but at the first available opportunity it will introduce fresh legislation containing the provisions which have been deleted pursuant to the requests. The House of Representatives will be asked to pass that legislation as soon as possible and in due course no doubt we will have it before us again in the Senate. I am sorry that the expeditious way in which the legislation was dealt with in the latter part of this evening did not occur during the afternoon. If that were the case we might have had an earlier rising. In any event I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the motion moved by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). I find his speech incredible. We are, of course, very gratified that the House of Representatives has accepted the requests sent to it by the Senate, requests arrived at in a very reasonable way and which will result in a much more reasonable Bill. I find it extraordinary that a Minister in another place and a Minister in this chamber would suggest that this legislation was delayed and that the House of Representatives agreed to these requests as a result of any action by the Government.
—I agree. Another Freudian slip.

—As I said, it was not by any action of the Government. The Government did what it could to bulldoze this legislation through this chamber. It expected the Opposition and, I assume, the Australian Democrats to accept the blackmail which Senator Chaney repeated in the speech he just made-blackmail to the effect that unless we pass this legislation 200,000 people will not receive the increase in their unemployment benefit. The fact is that the only thing that would have happened is that the increase in their unemployment benefit would have been delayed. The length of that delay would not have been dependent upon any action by the Opposition, but upon action by the Government. If the Government, through Senator Chaney, had been willing to indicate to the Australian Labor Party and to the Australian Democrats at 8 o'clock tonight or at 5 o'clock this afternoon that it would accept those requests the legislation would have gone through at that time without trouble. Senator Chaney was unwilling to do so. He was unwilling to give such a guarantee. Therefore we had to ensure that legislation which was introduced into this Parliament last Tuesday and into this chamber today was not bulldozed through without proper consideration and without proper scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind you, Mr President, that today this legislation passed through the Senate following contributions to the debate from the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. The only contributions from the Government were a four-minute speech from a back bencher and a slightly longer speech from the Minister. Tonight's result, however it occurred, happens to be a triumph for civil liberties, a triumph for democracy and a triumph for decent legislation in this country. For that reason we are grateful that the Bill has been passed. I feel that it is a sad thing that the Minister in this place and the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) in another place should have tried to paint this as an example of reasonable Government behaviour. In fact it is an example of reasonable behaviour on this side of the chamber in insisting that legislation which is discriminatory and which penalises the innocent should not go through this chamber. If Senator Chaney and Mr Hunt wish to put up this legislation again and, as Mr Hunt suggested, turn it into a Bill for a double dissolution, we will be perfectly happy for them to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats I endorse Senator Grimes's comments. We agree that it is indeed a triumph, but we applaud the Government's actions in taking the stance that it has taken. Despite the odd moments of confusion, farce and delay that have occurred during today, the Government is to be congratulated on the stand that it has taken. However, having said that, I wish to make it perfectly clear that we will undoubtedly oppose whatever legislation is brought forward as a substitute for the two clauses that have been deleted from this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chaney) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Due to the lateness of the hour, I intend to speak for only one minute. I think it is about time that some of the people in this Senate recognised the importance to staff and senators-particularly to staff-of adjourning at a reasonable hour.
—Hear, hear!

—The honourable senator can say 'hear, hear'. After Senator Chipp had a heart attack, Senator Mason could easily have moved for a change of hours, but what did he do? He sat there on his tail doing nothing. He should not say 'hear, hear!' to matters that I introduce.
—What do you want me to do?

—The honourable senator knows very well what he should have done. The situation is that, since 1974, we have had nearly three dozen nights on which the Senate has sat past midnight when its usual time of adjournment is 10.30 p.m. or 11 p.m. On the average, one would presume that one dozen of those nights would have been on nights with an 11 o'clock adjournment and the other two dozen would have been on nights with a 10.30 p.m. adjournment.

SPEECH.PARA: It should not be thought for a moment that I mind sitting here for as long as is necessary. But I think it is about time that this Senate considered when it should sit. I do not suggest that it should sit less hours. If it is necessary I will sit more hours or longer hours, at any time of the week that is required. The times at night until which the Senate sits are crazy. No one in the rest of the community does it and I think it is about time we stopped. I would support any motion proposed which suggested that we sit on Tuesdays from 12.30 p.m. to 7p.m. continuously, on Wednesdays the same hours as we do now and on Thursdays, 10.30 a.m. to 7 p.m. It is time this Senate paid due regard to the health not only of the people in here-many members of this chamber have died, since I have been here, due to the stress that has been on them-but also to those others involved in the operation of the Senate. It is very important that we do this before somebody else has a heart attack and dies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take the time of the Senate for very long. I place on record that Senator Townley is not the first person who has raised this matter in the Senate. Repeatedly over the years I have fought with Senator Carrick, since he has been Leader of the Government, over his deliberately keeping this Senate back to the early hours of the morning to get legislation through. Senator Townley had the remedy in his party room; he could have done something there rather than come in here tonight and grandstand about trying to do something for the attendants in this place. He is not the first one who has done it. Honourable senators on this side have raised the matter repeatedly; for years they have tried to get decent hours.

SPEECH.PARA: The hours that Senator Townley now suggests will make it harder perhaps not for attendants on this side of the building but for the people who work in the dining rooms. He is going to ask them to work longer hours. He will keep the Senate sitting until 7 o'clock and people will be in the dining room until 9 o'clock or 10 o'clock at night expecting waitresses and cooks to attend to their needs. I say finally that he is not the first person to raise this matter. It is a pity that he has not raised it in his party room because the Government parties have had the numbers in years gone by which would have enabled them to do something about it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 1.14 a.m. (Friday) until Tuesday, 10 November, at 2.30 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following papers were presented, pursuant to statute:
Defence Act-Determinations 1981- No. 45-Married Trainee's Allowance.
No. 47-Emergency Evacuation Overseas-Allowances and Compensation.
Lands Acquisition Act-Statement by the Minister describing land acquired by agreement under sub-section 7 (1) of the Act, for specified public purposes.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Committee of Inquiry into Public Libraries

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did the Committee of Inquiry into Public Libraries, otherwise known as the Horton Committee, tender its report to the Government.

(2) When did the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment announce that a review would take place of the current level of library resources following consideration of the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Public Libraries.
(3) Has a report on the review been presented to the Minister; if so, when.
(4) Does the Government intend releasing the report of the review committee.
(5) Does the Minister intend advising Parliament of the Government's decision on the review report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) 27 February 1976.
(2) 13 November 1979.
(3) Yes; the report was presented to my predecessor Mr Ellicott in September 1980.

(4) and (5) The report of the Interdepartmental Working Group, Policy on Assistance to Public Libraries, was tabled in the Senate, together with a text of the statement by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment on 13 October 1981. (Hansard, page 1096).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions in what ways will any departments or instrumentalities under the Minister, contract more work out to the private sector.
(2) Is it estimated that this measure will save those departments or instrumentalities money; if so, how much is it estimated that it will save.
(3) In what way will those savings break down into component savings.

(4) Can the Attorney-General give an assurance that the services to be contracted out to the private sector will not contribute to inflation or the Federal deficit by costing the government more than would the same services provided from within the public service by salaried officers.
(5) If the Attorney-General cannot give that assurance why have these moves been made without more comprehensive investigation and preparation.
(6) What investigations were made to ensure that the proposed action is economically sound.

(7) In the course of investigations that were made did the Minister receive any advice that in fact the proposed measures would cost the government more money than they would save and if so, what are the details.
(8) Has the Attorney-General received any advice since the measures have been proposed that they would cost the government more money than they will save and if so what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Acting Attorney-General has supplied the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Arrangements are in hand for some work of the Crown Solicitor's Division associated with statutory authorities to be transferred to the private sector.
(b) The scope for other work of that Division to be contracted out is under consideration.
(c) More reporting work will be contracted out by the Commonwealth Reporting Service.
(d) Consideration will be given from time to time to the scope for contracting out the development of computer software and technical advising.

(2) to (8) The arrangements mentioned in 1 (a) were made after taking into account, among other things, the fact that the statutory authorities concerned were, in general, conducting business undertakings. In this regard I refer the honourable senator to the explanation provided to Senate Estimates Committee A by the Attorney-General ( Hansard, of 21 September 1981, pages 376-7).

I am satisfied that the decision was economically sound but it is not practicable to provide a break down of savings into components.

Any further decision to contract more work to the private sector will take account of the considerations referred to by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in the answer to Question No. 765 (Senate Hansard of 20 August 1981, page 239).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister for Finance, on p. 6 of the Budget Speech, state that the Government was seeking to remove approximately $1,000m from the money supply in an effort to fight inflation.

(2) Is the gross non-farm product, on present indications, growing at an annual rate of probably less than two per cent and certainly less than three per cent; if so, and in view of the contradictory nature of the 1981-82 Budget, how can the Minister forecast a growth in gross non-farm product of three per cent or more.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Page 6 of the Budget speech indicates only that the total Budget deficit in 1981-82 would be reduced by almost $1,000m. The Budget deficit, or more accurately the domestic Budget deficit or surplus, is only one of the factors determining the overall growth of the money supply. Nevertheless, the reduction in the Budget deficit will make a major contribution to the Government's policy of slowing monetary growth so as to exercise appropriate restraint of inflationary pressures. In keeping with this objective, the Government is seeking to achieve growth in the monetary aggregates consistent with growth in the M3 definition of the money supply of 10 to 11 per cent over the course of 1981-82.

(2) The latest national accounts estimates are that real gross non-farm product grew by 4.0 per cent in 1980-81, and at an annual rate of 1.6 per cent, after seasonal adjustment, in the second half of that year. In the notes to the published accounts, the Statistician has pointed to the special problems affecting estimates for periods of less than a year and to the fact that the estimated change in gross non-farm product is liable to substantial revision. Allowance also needs to be made for the sources of the slowing in the growth of GDP in the second half of 1980-81 as measured by the national accounts. Stock movements, which can be particularly volatile at times, contributed importantly to that measured slowing. Final domestic demand, which grew at the very strong annual rate of 6.9 per cent in the first half of 1980-81, continued to grow firmly at an annual rate of 3.5 per cent in the second half. Private business fixed investment continued to grow in the second half of the year at the extremely strong annual rate of 21.2 per cent. As to the outlook for 1981-82 and the Budget forecast of growth in non-farm product of 3-3 1/2 per cent, I refer the honourable Senator to the considerable supporting detail to be found in the Budget documents, particularly Statement No. 2 of Budget Paper No. 1. Developments since the Budget was brought down-for example, the figures published recently by the Commonwealth Statistician relating to his most recent survey of private business fixed investment expectations-remain consistent with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 August 1981 (Hansard, page 48), Senator Watson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs the following question without notice:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 September 1981 (Hansard page 636), Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The report to which the honourable senator referred was, I understand, based on information included in a paper that was prepared for the Australian Financial System Inquiry.

The Foreign Takeovers Act applies to acquisitions by a single foreign interest or associated foreign interests of a substantial shareholding in an Australian corporation (this being defined as 15 per cent or more of the voting power or 15 per cent or more to the issued shares of the corporation) and to acquisitions by two or more foreign interests of an aggregate substantial shareholding in an Australian corporation (defined as 40 per cent or more of the voting power or 40 per cent or more of the issued shares of the corporation).

The information in the paper referred to above indicated that the estimated 21.8 per cent foreign ownership of BHP was of a fragmented nature. As such, the shareholdings do not exceed the relevant threshold of 40 per cent laid down in the Foreign Takeovers Act.

The foreign portfolio equity investment that has been undertaken in BHP and other Australian companies has the advantage that, by comparison with foreign direct equity investment, it provides Australia with access to overseas funds on a basis that does not involve foreign control.

For this reason, the Government does not require foreign investment approval to be sought for investments of a purely portfolio nature. The Government is, of course, concerned to ensure that Australians should have opportunities to participate as fully and effectively as practicable in the ownership and control of the country's natural resources and industries, and considers that the present features of the foreign investment policy are being effective in achieving this objective. These features include the Australian equity participation guidelines, which provide opportunities for Australian ownership and control of natural resource projects, and the naturalisation provisions, which provide an incentive for companies that are predominantly foreign-owned to introduce higher Australian ownership and Australian control. It should be noted that the Australian equity guidelines are not primarily concerned with levels of Australian equity in particular companies, but are directed towards ensuring that appropriate levels of Australian ownership and control of natural resource projects are achieved. Careful consideratoin is given by the Government to cases where the size of foreign portfolio shareholdings in a participant in a foreign investment proposal is of potential significance for the purposes of consideration of the proposal against the requirements of the foreign investment policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September (Hansard, page 894), Senator Bonner asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, a question without notice regarding a report in the Sydney Morning Herald of that day headed ''Genetics must come first, says economist''. The Minister for Science and Technology advises as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There have been no cuts in the funding of basic research and in particular in the areas of genetic engineering and related sciences.
The funding of Australia's research effort was reviewed in the budget context and the following levels of funding established for the current financial year:

The allocation to the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) was increased from $19.2m (which included $0.5m for the provision of a new building for the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research) in the 1980-81 financial year to $23.27m for the current financial year, an increase of 21%.

Direct appropriations for CSIRO in 1981-82 will total $281.1m, an increase of 23.1% over 1980-81, of which $49.5m is for major capitad projects including $35m for the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory and $6.9m for a laboratory complex for the Division of Chemical Technology. It appears that the 1981-82 appropriation will represent a slight reduction in the level of activity for CSIRO compared to the previous year, as the increase over 1980-81 will be mostly absorbed into the CSIRO's employee's superannuation scheme.
The allocation to the Australian Research Grants Committee (ARGC) was increased 12.5 per cent from $16m in 1981 to $17.98m which will maintain the same level of activity in 1982.

Through these agencies the Government has been supporting a wide range of activities which will contribute to our stock of fundamental knowledge essential in the long term development of genetic engineering.

Furthermore, the Department of Science and Technology in association with the Bank of New South Wales and the Australian Institute of Management (NSW Division) is organising a symposium to be held in November entitled-Genetic Engineering: Commercial Opportunities in Australia.

The symposium will aim to alert companies to recent developments in recombinant DNA research and to potential commercial development in Australia. It will provide an opportunity for interaction among industry, research, marketing and finance personnel; assessment of the opportunities and problems of Australian commercial exploitation of genetic engineering techniques and for discussion of the principal issues likely to impinge on such developments.

In addition, provisions have been made under the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act for universities to be classified as approved research organisations for the purposes of the Act. The Minister has recently written to universities and colleges of advanced education pointing out the advantages of this provision. This mechanism will allow universities to make research expertise and facilities available on a contract basis to firms involved in high technology industries and in particular to firms involved in genetic engineering.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Exports: Revaluation of the Australian Dollar

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 September 1981 (Hansard, page 986), Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning revaluation of the Australian dollar. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia's exchange rate at any time is determined in the light of both domestic and external economic considerations, and with a view to maintaining and strengthening the overall health of the economy. As far as is appropriate, exchange rate policy is intended to support the anti-inflationary stance of the Government's economic policies. However, the net appreciation of the Australian dollar over the past twelve months emerged, in large part, as a natural consequence of the marked strengthening of Australia's balance of payments over that period.

It is certainly true that one effect of this appreciation would have been to lower the prices received for exports in Australian dollar terms, including exports from the rural and minang sectors, below what they would otherwise have been. But an offsetting effect would have been to reduce the price of imports in Australian dollar terms, including imports destined for the agricultural and mining sectors. More generally, appreciation tends to have beneficial price effects domestically. The appreciation of the Australian dollar in 1980-81 improved, directly and indirectly, the cost situation for all Australian industry, including the rural and mining sectors.

Without pursuing the matter in great detail, it seems reasonable to conclude that any net reduction in the income of exporters which may have resulted from exchange rate movements in 1980-81 would have been a good deal smaller than might appear from focussing only upon the exchange rate effects on their gross returns.

Of course, the more recent slight decline in the trade weighted value of the Australian dollar, associated with the seasonal deficit in the Australian balance of payments in the recent September quarter, will have tended to reverse the effects outlined above.

In implementing its exchange rate and other policies affecting the external account, the Government will continue to pay attention to the important interests of Australia's traditional export industries. However, the Government also has to take into account the interests of all sectors of the community, exporters and importers, producers and consumers. In particular, it has to pursue exchange rate policies which will be helpful in returning the Australian economy firmly to a non-inflationary and hence sustainable upward growth path.

As to the particular aspect of the matter which has been raised by the honourable senator, it is worth noting that changing the mix or basket of currencies used in the process of exchange rate determination would not, in itself, necessarily mitigate the trend in the value of the Australian dollar, whether up or down.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 October 1981 (Hansard, pages 1156-1157), Senator Keeffe asked me a question without notice about compensation payments resulting from the Government's call for a boycott to the Olympic Games and sanctions imposed against the Soviet Union and Iran. I responded on the same day (Hansard, page 1166) to three of the matters raised by Senator Keeffe and undertook to have an investigation made of the remaining matters, namely, the total income lost by Australia as a result of the Government's decision selectively to ban various exports to Russia.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

It is not possible to advise on the total income lost by Australia as a result of the Government's decision to ban various exports to the Soviet Union. This is because claims relate to unrecouped expenditure, not income foregone, and it is not clear whether the claims received represent the full effects of the Government's actions. It should be noted that the Government's actions would also have resulted in a loss of income by the Soviet Union.

However, I am advise by my department that only two claims relating to prohibitions on exports to the Soviet Union were received. In one of these cases the export subsequently proceeded and in another the commodity was disposed of at a higher price on the domestic market. Where claims were not lodged, it is probable that commodities affected by the Government's actions were able to be disposed of at a profit on alternative markets.
